151427914.review:
So much to love.  So much to hate.  Steep difficulty at the end makes the game impossible to beat.  Not for the Casual player.

I got this game for the reviews and for the most part, its a great game.  Interesting story, Music is phenomenal and not a short game.  However its also an infuriating and frustrating game.  Especially late game.  Its not easy by no means and i'm not new to the metrovania genre, but the late game stages and bosses are almost impossible to defeat.  Really to the point of where i just gave up. Leveling up and getting items and relics don't do much as your progression doesn't match the enemies strengths.  Last 2 bosses, Captain Julius and the end boss can one shot you.  Whats worse is that if you make even a minor mistake, you might as well just start the fight over.  The regular enemies are whatever, not easy by any means, but you normally can make it to the next save and restore area.  

I can't tell you the number of attempts i made with Ulv the mad knight and Julius but it was 2-3 hrs for each and wasn't able to beat either of them.  Just gave up, uninstalled and watched the ending and story recap online.  I won't be revisiting this game unless they rebalance the game.  Either drop the boss' health by 20-30% or make the hero stronger and decrease the damage you take.  

Game isn't bad but its not for the casual player.  More for the season players.

151394151.review:
A pretty good game.  I didn't find it as spellbinding as some people did, but it was fun.

The spirit weapon mechanic is really neat once you start getting enough useful ones that you actually feel inclined to swap your loadout around.  I actually had the sword guy entirely unequipped for a while-- his damage had fallen behind since I hadn't find any ancient souls for him, and just used Silva as my "basic attack" for a while, and i thought that was fun!  I kinda wish he hadn't just rocketed back up to being the best unlimited-use weapon and it'd been a more level playing field between him and the other major bosses.  

Most of the miniboss spirits just felt basically useless, unfortunately.  Sharply limited uses, long cooldowns, unimpressive damage, and niche attack patterns.  The only ones I got memorable use out of were: [spoiler]Fallen Archer (deals massive damage to large airborne enemies), the dog and the bird (helpful on the 2 bosses that spawn ads), siegrid (kinda useful airborne AOE pattern, does lots of small damage so it synergizes with the immortal's crest i guess)[/spoiler]

Fantastic soundtrack, though.  Holds the whole experience together from a story and aesthetic perspective.

150507284.review:
Ender Lilies is an overall pretty good metroidvania. I personally had the pleasure to 100% the game, over the course of a little less than 18 hours. It is a nice experience on sale, and definitely worth 12 euro. There are however distinct positives and negatives to outline. This review has occasional spoilers. 

There is one fairly major issue that should be highlighted early: [b] Boss fights are not particularly impressive or intriguing. [/b]

As a person who has completed other metroidvanias such as Death's Gambit or Salt & Sanctuary (or even roguelikes whose bosses could be loosely described as metroidvania bosses, such as Dead Cells or Skul: The Hero Slayer), the bosses in Ender Lilies have often great visual designs with intriguing stories to them. Especially the latter point is improved by the cutscenes that play after defeating each boss. But there are clear missed opportunities on multiple bosses. 

For example [spoiler];
- There is no boss in the game that allows for platforming in their arena; each room is entirely flat, with no platforms.
- New phases typically mean *one* extra attack, and perhaps a quicker animation speed on previous ones. That's it. 
- You can typically have the exact same relic setup for every single boss (although which spirits you want may vary slightly).
- Even if you could change spirits to optimize some boss fights, it is entirely possible (and rather simple, even on the harder difficulty) to beat every single boss in the game by just left clicking them to death. 
- Every single attack from a boss in this game is red. It may be slightly different tones of red, but nontheless red. You can only dodge so many red orbs or red waves from so many bosses before the attacks start to look similar. [/spoiler]

Without direct spoilers, these issues were clear on every boss. I do mean every single boss. [spoiler] Typically, I look forward to the last boss of a game, and here the excitement was only due to story and music aspects. Not the combat [/spoiler]. 

There is one more thing that could be brought up as a flaw. The platforming is overall fairly simple for a metroidvania. Compared to titles such as Salt & Sanctuary or Death's Gambit (or again, even roguelikes such as Dead Cells or Skul: the Hero Slayer), there are very few moments where a player in Ender Lilies have to push their limits when it comes to platforming. Although there is a lot of platforming in the game, it just is not very hard. 

There does exist platforming puzzles, and a small amount of them could be challenging. That is where the myriad of movement abilities in Ender Lilies leads to a high skill ceiling with some cathartic moments (as there are secrets that are physically impossible without some awareness of the games platforming). But those moments are few and far between, especially for a player who is not going for 100% completion and likely will not even see those platforming puzzles. 

-------------------------------

With that out of the way, we can look at some of the [b] positives [/b];

1. Exploration in this game is fantastic. The map is designed in such a way that a player can easily determine where the are paths yet explored, and where there could potentially be hidden items. Rooms are actually described as "complete" or "incomplete" on the map. Unless a player wants to save an hour or two of searching, then it is absolutely not necessary to use guides to find every secret. 

2. Weapons (spirits) are quite varying. Yes, they all have red animations, but many have different roles to play. It's not just "ranged attacks" and "melee attacks" due to a couple of reasons; [spoiler]
- Different attacks have different amounts of charges, so they're not all spammable in the same sense as a left click sword swing
- The environment (specifically the positioning of enemies) pushes the player to try spirits with different attack sets, to reach enemies in awkward positions or to hit multiple enemies in multiple directions at once. Some attacks are more powerful, but with a long wind-up time. Other attacks are automatic, which is useful when the context forces the player to always be on the move. [/spoiler]

So the enjoyment of combat rarely or never comes from difficulty (as it is comparatively simple for a metroidvania), but instead from the large amount of different moves that a player could use to clear an area. Optimization becomes the new source of enjoyment, not the challenge itself. 

3. The music is very atmospheric. Although there are not as many stand-out soundtracks as you would think from a list of 50, there are at least some that are quite nice and draws attention. 

4. The story! Due to the quality of life included in the game through minor mechanics (such as the map or the fact that players does not lose any progress on death even temporarily), it is quite possible to experience most if not all of the story without having to go through many hurdles. I would describe the story as bittersweet. It is also rare for a metroidvania to explore an environment where there truly are [spoiler] no friendly or even neutral NPC:s. At all. The world is more than just figuratively dead as every character besides the player is dead or wishes they were dead. [/spoiler]. Because of that, Ender Lilies is a fairly unusual metroidvania.

So to reiterate, Ender Lilies can be quite enjoyable in the right circumstances, with some areas where there could have been more. For me, it was specifically bosses and platforming that were underwhelming. As written above, it is recommended on sale for any metroidvania fan that craves an intriguing, dark story.

150445215.review:
Me arrepiento enormemente de haber comprado esto. Para empezar, el mapa es una mierda, no sirve prácticamente para nada, el peor mapa que he visto en un metroidvania. En vez del clásico sistema de mostrar el laberinto unido con tu posición que caracteriza a esta clase de juegos, en este se nos muestran únicamente casillas unidas por líneas, como si de un mapa conceptual de lo más rudimentario se tratase. Me parece cero práctico y, aunque lo usas a la fuerza porque si no es que no hay manera, sigue siendo el mayor problema que ya de inicio te tira para atrás.

Vengo de jugar Aria of sorrow, el que se ha vuelto, para mí, el metroidvania perfecto; y es perfecto porque te sientes poderoso no porque sea fácil, sino porque sientes cómo el juego te recompensa conforme avanzas en el mismo, cuanto más subes de nivel menos daño te hacen los enemigos y más daño les haces tú. En Ender Lilies lo único que mejora al subir de nivel es el daño que infliges, pero tú sigues siendo más endeble que un mojón blando.

Jugando a Ender Lilies sientes estar pasando por un calvario nada gratificante, puesto que no disfrutas, solo estás con los nervios a flor de piel y el pulso acelerado porque cualquier cosa te puede matar y tirarte para el último punto de control, eres de mantequilla. 

Casi todos los jefes son una total falta de respeto al jugador y a su tiempo: tienen varias fases, cada cual de ellas más hija de puta, y la pelea consiste, básicamente, en esquivar una y otra vez y en cualquier descuido te vas a la mierda y vuelta a empezar, así dos eternas horas. Cuando por fin los matas no sientes la gratificación que sientes cuando matas a un jefe de un Souls, por ejemplo, sientes hastío y ganas de cortarte las venas por haber invertido 13 euros en esta basura mal diseñada y de mecánicas horribles. 

La dificultad no es un obstáculo para mí, he superado Hollow Knight y los dos Blasphemous sin problemas, pero esto es sencillamente frustrante. El único motivo por el que lo sigo jugando, aparte de haber apoquinado los 13 culebros mencionados, es por la banda sonora y el arte, que son las dos cosas más destacables, pero siento que la frustración y los nervios a los que estoy sometido me pasarán factura y no volveré a ser el mismo. Quiero pegarle a algo.

150370368.review:
I 100%d this game. I want to like it, but I can't. The art direction is good, but the gameplay ruins it for me completely.

This game doesn't respect your time. Unless you have lightning reflexes or watch all bosses on YouTube first, you will waste hours on attempts. Poorly telegraphed moves, constant and unrelenting reaction checks, severe punishment for missed attacks - it has them all.

I also 100%d Hollow Knight and Elden Ring. Both felt easier and more forgiving. How do you like the fact that Ender Lilies boosts enemy HP and damage based on the number of bosses defeated? You toil away expecting it to become easier, but it only keeps becoming more difficult and slower-paced until the very end.

Leveling and exploration are seldom worth it. There is no sense of accomplishment. Dodging is 75% of all combat. Parrying is generally unrewarding and often stunlocks or flings you away from the enemy you are supposed to stay close to. What's even the point? Oh, and whittling down enemy stamina breaks their stance for, like, half a second. Enjoy your one free strike.

Level design is hot garbage. The art is good, but the levels feel generic, disconnected and purposefully constructed as training rooms. There is no feeling of consistency throughout the world - just very basic levels, like in the old NES or SEGA games. Ori, Hollow Knight, even Bloodstained did it better.

I'll admit my reflexes are slow (always have been), but this game is brutal to players like me. It offers very little in terms of cheesing enemies - you can't just compensate for the lack of skill by exploring or leveling more. Changing the loadout helps, but you still have to study every boss's moves religiously to even stand a chance.

Malenia was less ridiculous and more entertaining than most bosses in Ender Lilies.

The story is not bad, just difficult to piece together due to the texts you find having no in-universe dates. It takes a while to figure it out.

The music sounds like something that belongs in a much, MUCH better game.

I mostly picked it for the atmosphere, art, story and music. I left feeling spent and miserable. I work full days, and nearly any game in the evening feels like a welcome break. Ender Lilies felt like more hard work. So many poor design choices, so little to compensate for them.

Never again.

150299224.review:
Sadly, I dislike this game. It looks great, the music is good, but the combat is awful. 
Every attack roots you in place, killing all momentum. This gives me the feeling that none of the attacks have weight. This is amplified by the stagger mechanic, which only staggers enemies when their respective bar is filled. Enemies seem to also have a lot more health that they would have needed. 
Bosses (so far) also suffered from this. The fights took longer than I'd have liked, especially since the move set of those bosses is very limited, and they take longer pauses in between to not do anything or reposition. 
The spirit system is a nice idea, having multiple tools and being able to adjust for the area you want to conquer, but since you have to level each spirit individually, there is not much incentive to experiment. 
While the assets look well-designed, the levels often feel like large boxes with some platforms in between. Rarely did I feel the setting of the level matched the room I was in (why would every room be 6-10 meters high?). The metroidvania style looking of areas behind required abilities is also a bit overused. I constantly encountered different types of "cannot go there yet"s. Maybe there are too many abilities or the devs locked too many paths? Hard to tell.

If you're a fan of metroidvania games, you're gonna love Ender Lillies.

Pros: 
Amazing 2D visuals
Great audio effects,
AMAZING music
Moody and Atmospheric story

Cons: 
Souls-like inspired save mechanic and difficulty.

150170490.review:
Good game, definitely worth a play (very minor spoilers).

Pros:
- Excellent soundtrack
- Combat is REALLY good, so many good abilities to choose from, and multiple playstyles. 
- No penalty for dying, you lose nothing, I appreciate this, a lot of games are putting that in their games just for the sake of it.


Cons: 
- The map itself (the look of it) is lacking, and it doesn't tell you where each area starts (its name) and where the next one begins. So doesn't highlight each separate are, like Hollow knight for instance. 
- So many areas are way too vertical sometimes, with so many enemies, and some you have to dodge, so you end falling a lot.  (You get a tool for it, but very late in the game). 
- Too many enemies in a place, some hit way too hard for a mob for some reason, like a third of my health, and it's decent length where I am at at that point, so it makes no sense. 
- Add to that, most areas have more than one way to go, so you get lost having to fight a lot of enemies, and if you die, you have to go over there AGAIN, which becomes a bit boring and frustrating, and makes the next rest point feel way too far, even though they are decently scattered.
- Healing petals are a really good idea that could have mitigated the frustration of the points I listed, they introduced it and put a few in the first level, after that, they are VERY VERY scarce! 
- I dislike getting hit from touching the enemies, I know, a lot of games do that, I dislike that. 
- Healing takes a little too long to take effect than it should, I died way too many times because of it (You get an artifact for it, but very late in the game). 

I know I listed too many cons, lol, but it is a good game, a little tainted by some of the points I listed, but still worth a play.

Solid play; Only one boss was a real problem and that may be because I did it out of order. Story is... decent.... Wish it had voice overs during memories but that's a minor complaint. World building is 'what you see is what you get' Levels seem a bit forced for the sake of justifying damage values that increase. Most of the time I found myself running past enemies since it was just easier. It utilizes a point based accessory system where you'll just min-max the best for what you're doing.  If you don't have a good sense of direction you'll get lost. The map as a whole feels disconnected between rooms. Overall, I'd say it's satisfactory.

PROS:
[list]
[*] There are many different kinds of weapons
[*] There are a solid amount of enemies that each have a thing that they do.
[*] Bosses mostly feel fair if you're patient;
[*] Exploration is adequate; it's nice they mark rooms where you've collected everything
[*] Progression is steady for the most part. 
[*] Bosses slowly ramp up as you damage them letting you learn how to fight them
[/list]
CONS:
[list]
[*] I didn't really find a point to fighting enemies except for the achievement or combat rooms
[*] Sure there are lots of weapons but you'll default to like.... 3
[*] You're going to be locked into animations; which is weird since you're not the one attacking.
[*] Some bosses break the simple rule they establish of 'Eye Flash means unleash attack` so you're gonna get hit by cheeky attacks
[*] Particle overload so you're going to going to get hit by cheeky enemy attacks 
[*[ Bosses slowly ramp up as you damage them meaning the hardest part where you have the least practice will take awhile to get to....
[/list]

149968366.review:
Quería tomar un momento para compartir mi experiencia con Ender Lilies, un juego que recientemente tuve el placer de completar. Desde el primer compás, la banda sonora me envolvió en un ambiente que no puedo más que describir como exquisito. Las melodías, tan serenas como melancólicas en ciertos momentos, añadieron una capa emocional que enriqueció cada momento del juego.

Como aficionado a la poesía y la escritura, me sorprendió gratamente encontrar fragmentos reflexivos a lo largo del juego. Los recuerdos revelaron pensamientos profundos que resonaron más allá de la pantalla. Fue un toque poético que añadió una dimensión adicional a la narrativa, algo que aprecio profundamente en cualquier forma de arte.

Aunque las comparaciones con otros Metroidvanias como Ori and the Blind Forest y Hollow Knight son inevitables, Ender Lilies logra destacarse con su propia originalidad. La trama envolvente y las mecánicas de juego desafiantes se entrelazan de manera magistral, creando una experiencia que, aunque familiar en algunos aspectos, se siente única en su ejecución.

Recomiendo encarecidamente Ender Lilies a aquellos que buscan más que solo un desafío de juego. Es una experiencia que va más allá de la pantalla, dejando una impresión duradera. No es simplemente un juego; es una obra que combina arte, música y narrativa de manera magistral.

149900835.review:
Clearly a lot of passion went into his game, but passion does not equate to good decisions. 

The map is horrendous, you have no clear idea of the layout of specific areas even after you've explored them because they represent entire sections of the game by a blank rectangle. And they give you no helpful indicators to make it easier to explore once you have new navigation abilities. You end up having to retrace the entire map, going back to the same areas over and over, every time you get some new ability, because there is no way to tell from the map if that's an area worth visiting. 

The combat is okay but the enemies and scaling are terrible. They reuse the same sprites all over the place so areas bleed in together and barely have any identity beyond the backgrounds and these reused sprites aren't even pallet swapped or get new abilities. They do however get more HP and more damage. What this leads to is you never feeling like you're getting any stronger. A slug creature took 2 hits to kill and could kill you in 5 hits at the beginning of the game, and the exact same slug creature in a different section of the map will take 2 hits to kill and kill you in 5. Even if you now have a health bar that stretches across the screen and have upgraded your abilities to max so they do better damage, it doesn't matter. You will never feel like you're more powerful, and because of the way they scale damage and health it makes upgrading either, and tougher enemies, pointless. All the numbers change, but the game fundamentally stays the same. 

Combat is fun for the most part, but you'd best get used to making endless use of the dodge button. While many games have a dodge, you only need it in certain circumstances. The ability to simply move away from, block attacks, or stun enemies, allows for many avenues. This game doesn't really have that. You CAN stun enemies but my experience has been you either kill them before they attack, or you can't deal enough damage to stun them before they attack and take a hit. And many, MANY, enemies don't even have the sorts of attacks that can simply be avoided by moving out of the way, so many enemies you HAVE to use the dodge to engage with them. 

Between the frustrating scaling and the endless dodging it got to a point where I wasn't even fighting unless I had to. 

Last thing worth talking about is the abilities. There are 2 kinds of abilities, the sort you get from main bosses, the the sort you get from mini-bosses. A lot of abilities end up being rather useless because their hit boxes are really only capable of hitting certain enemies, or, you throw out an ability that deals damage over time and the enemy simple leaves the area and you end up doing so little damage you might as well have hit them with your sword one time. While I did find some abilities that were handy, after several hours in the game, even though I'd been upgrading them, the damage fell off very harshly. It got to the point they were almost useless in boss fights, and eventually I had so many main boss abilities that worked better I never used the other ones. After 13 hours in the game if I got a new mini boss ability I wouldn't even bother checking it out. The main boss weapons typically do more damage, are less specific (so way more versatile), and usually have WAY more uses. 

All that said, 90% of the time you'll just use the starting sword. Its the best weapon in most cases especially once you master the dodging and you'll probably make use of the giant club attack for its overhand swing (good for enemies above your head and not much else) and the energy ball attack which you can throw out pretty fast, you get like 80 of after you've upgraded, has good range, and good damage. 

All in all, its a pretty game with a few good ideas but not enough to carry it. It really has the feel of a 5 hour game that was padded to heck and back to make it longer with littler thought given to how the game plays. There are better options, I wouldn't recommend at any price.

149892401.review:
Opinión corta: 
Si bien no lo llamaría obra maestra, es un juegazo de muy alta calidad en muchos aspectos. Vale completamente la pena. Denle la oportunidad.

Opinión profundizada:
Un día, explorando bandas sonoras, me encontré con la de este juego. Al escucharla me sentí completamente maravillado, me pareció sublime (salvo por muy pocos temas, pero no me quiero adelantar). Luego averigüe sobre el juego. Si bien me atrajo sus jefes de dificultad "souls" (patrones bien definidos, timing y un esquive con invulnerabilidad) y el ambiente oscuro, no me terminaba de convencer la (como le dicen mis amigos a Lily) "mona china" con la que uno juega. Por otro lado, el apartado gráfico también me pareció sublime y si bien jugar con una niña indefensa no está entre mis preferencias decidí darle una oportunidad.

Lo que me encontré superó con creces mis expectativas. 
La banda sonora: no solo es excelsa, sino que acompaña, y potencia, las zonas y los jefes; incluso esos pocos temas fuera de mi agrado (2) acompañan perfectamente la zona con su opresividad. Por poner algunos ejemplos: Rosary intro, Harmonious y Bulbel (el excelente tema de los créditos)
La jugabilidad: lenta al principio, va tomando con cada jefe un ritmo mayor y aunque las zonas no me parecen lo mejor del juego, cumplen con ser diversas, entretenidas y que no solo se pueda ir a lo loco. La mecánica de los espíritus, que se obtienen al explorar y derrotar enemigos, aporta muchísimo al gameplay y, aunque se puede pasar todo el juego con los mismos, sin duda se da la variedad suficiente para que, para cada zona y para cada jefe, haya una configuración que se adapte mejor; algo que favorece muchísimo al progreso y la estrategia. Como aspecto negativo debo mencionar que hay zonas sobrecargadas de enemigos.
El apartado visual: bellísimo, oscuro y melancólico. Sorprende como se encuentran tanto lugares preciosos, como otros sin duda horrorosos.Y no solo adornan sino que cuentan una historia.
La historia: si bien esta no me termino de llegar en un principio (y es difícil de enlazar, ya que se cuenta a través de documentos que uno encuentra, de los objetos, jefes y zonas, como ya saben que juego) al dejarla decantar cumple con ser una buena historia con sus toques profundos: el final verdadero toma mucho peso y emoción al comprender lo que pasó en ese mundo. Al entender el peso, esfuerzo y sacrificio que impone el limpiar la impureza; y lo que implico nuestro viaje en esa aventura. 
Lo técnico: nunca sentí tirones, ni bajadas de fps (y juego en una tostadora), siempre sentí que la respuesta era muy buena y mis muertes justas. 

Hay muchas más cosas que podría decir pero concluiré diciendo que: fue una viaje que realmente disfruté. Es un juegazo, recomendadísimo.

149802745.review:
The combat is too simple and when combined with the lackluster level and enemy design it just sucks any interest or fun to see what's further. Combat is like playing 2D mario where you have to hop around and awkwardly dodge mid-combo having to "wait your turn" trying to line up the perfect combo or application of spirit skills without getting hit. One on one the enemies are piss easy due to the barebone combat mechanics and movesets, but in order to pump this up to a "souls-like" difficulty the game bundles enemy types together because otherwise the game would be too easy. Ranged enemies having homing projectiles was a lame cop out, as I could not be more annoyed facing two melee enemies repeatedly chaining staggered attacks while two crows are sending homing projectiles in a alternating fashion basically suppressing me and forcing me to keep my distance while boringly tossing a spirit skill from afar repeatedly while constantly dodging the crow ranged attacks.

The art for the characters, enemies, spirits, and cutscenes were good, but the world design was fairly basic and boring save a few key locations for the time I played. I think for games like this they only have such high ratings because given the genre, style(art and it being 2D), and gameplay it's clear that all the gamers that would enjoy playing this game will have played it and the rest who wouldn't enjoy it would never play it. I thought there'd be more depth to the combat and level design, but the game failed to deliver that for me hence me refunding it. An indie game of this caliber and type is filling a niche which shows in the ratings how badly gamers wanted a game like this. If you liked the game then great you're exactly the gamer this game was made for, but I'm not one of those gamers.

An older game that does what Ender Lilies does but with better art, level design, enemy design, rpg mechanics, and much more fun combat in an arcadey hack-and-slash fashion would be "Astlibra Revision"(A remaster of an old browser game). Astlibra was my first "Metroidvania" game and it was just so stellar and refreshing that I expected Ender Lilies to have a combat system to at least scratch that Astlibra itch.

Ender Lilies es más que un simple videojuego de acción y aventuras. En su oscuro mundo, podemos encontrar una alegoría de la lucha contra la corrupción y la restauración de la pureza. A través de la protagonista, Lily, exploramos temas filosóficos profundos, como la redención y el poder de la esperanza en medio de la desolación.

El juego nos sumerge en una reflexión sobre la dualidad de la vida y la muerte, representada por los espíritus de caballeros caídos que luchan a nuestro lado. Ender Lilies nos invita a cuestionar la moralidad y los sacrificios necesarios en la lucha contra el mal. La narrativa nos plantea dilemas éticos y nos sumerge en un mundo donde las decisiones tienen un impacto profundo en la historia y sus personajes.

Hermoso juego <3

149547099.review:
On balance, I would recommend Ender Lilies but the game had some real ups and downs for me. 

Ender Lilies is a Metroidvania-style platformer with lite-RPG elements (levelling up). It has a large world, many parts of which are closed off at first until you obtain certain upgrades. These come in the form of Spirits (weapons basically) and Relics (passive/slotted abilities). There lots of Spirits and they all do very different attacks. 

The RPG-lite element/gimmick is you can level up your Spirits and therein lies my problem with the system. There are effectively finite currency for levelling them up, which is disincentive to try out different ones because once you decide to invest in a spirit, that will be much stronger than lower level ones. Some maps/enemies really need certain Spirits or you will be frustrated - it's the 'levelled up wrong' issue. The character also levels up gaining a bit of HP and I think there's also some scaling involved vs enemies but otherwise just adds nothing to the game. All-in-all I felt the levelling up system was just a detriment. At best, you would question why it even existed. 

The levels are a mix of somewhat interesting spread between some quite long but dull areas. As the map is quite basic, it is frustrating to go revisit all the old areas again to try find which parts are now accessible every time you gain a new traversal tool. The bosses also have some balance issues. Depending on your Spirits (and which ones are levelled), can be immensely frustrating. They either crush you or you use some cheese combination of spirits/relics to brute-force it. I found half of them just not fun at all. 

Despite all the above negatives, it isn't a bad Metroidvania. It's "okay". What elevates it for me into Recommend is the presentation is top notch. The beautiful character design and animation work, decent music and writing, really sells the atmosphere and mood. Absolutely gorgeous. 

In short, it's an OK game with some problems but if you are a fan of the genre and don't mind some frustrating design then it's still worth a try.

149267637.review:
I really enjoyed this game! The environment, the music, the combat, and the lore are excellently done.
My favorite part in this entire game is actually learning about all the characters in the game. I wanted to find and save every spirit because I wanted to know about their lives that led up to the Blight Rain via their description, dialogue, and flashbacks. I loved seeing glimpses of the lives of the different Priestesses that tragically perished in the end. I wanted to locate and read every Note in order to know the Spirits' backstories, the Priestesses' backstories, and the stories of the other characters.

If the creators every decide to make an Ender Lilies 2 or make a game similar to this, I have some suggestions for fleshing out the Spirits more:

1. Bonding Events
Lily could unlock cutscenes of her having conversations with her Spirits by enhancing her Spirts. So when she enhances a particular Spirit, she will unlock an event where Lily bonds with that Spirit and learn more about that Spirit.
You could also have the bonding event show the interaction and relationship of the Spirit with the other Spirits. For example, we could see the strained relationship between Siegrid and Silva or the troubled relationship between Faden and the other Spirits.
Since Lily is supposedly mute, the cutscene could have Lily expressing her thoughts through gestures and facial expressions. She could pout when she's mad, she could tilt her head when she's confused, she could have her eyes sparkle when she's excited, etc.
However, I recommend that you don't give a Bonding event for the Spirit's final enhancement/upgrade because the cost for that enhancement is so expensive that it is impossible for a player to fully enhance all the Spirits in a playthrough unless they spend an absurd amount of grinding for all the needed Blight.
I also suggest that certain Bonding events be locked until Lily accomplishes certain conditions. For example:
- Siegrid's later events are unlocked after purifying her sister Silva
- Fungal Sorcerer Melville's later events are unlocked after purifying Floral Sorceress. It's the same for vice versa
- One-Eyed Royal Aegis' later events are unlocked after purifying Julius
- Ulv's later events are unlocked after getting the Snowdrop Bracelet
- Faden's last events are unlocked after getting the Aegis Curio

2. Quests
Lily could get quests from the Spirits by unlocking certain Bonding events or advancing the story. These quests are used to further flesh out the Spirits associated to them and reveal more of their backstory. The player can earn Blight for enhancing Spirits, Relics, Amulet fragments, and Chains of Sorcery from completing these quests.
You could also use these quests to challenge the player by requiring the player to equip the Spirit(s) associated with the quest while that quest is active. It can be the Spirit is only equipped in one set or equipped in both sets, depending on the difficulty of the quest. And player could be required to equip multiple spirits for a particular quest.
The tricky part is how to code these quests into the game because, while these quests are active, the quests could change the Blight enemy placements and other factors in an area depending on what area Lily will end up in to progress the quest.
As for examples for possible quests:
- Cliffside Hamlet Youth's quest is finding out what happened to his mother
- Headless Defender's quest is challenging Gerrod to a fight with the former as one of the equipped Spirits
- Verboten Champion's quest is learning why he had the urge to go into Verboten Quarter in the first place
- Dark Executioner's quest is Julius trying to help the Dark Executioner with his dream of becoming a knight
- Chief Guardian's quest is locating all the dead priestesses and providing them a proper burial
(This quest can also be used to explore more about the priestesses)

These ideas were thought up by me because of how much I wanted to learn more and bond more with the Spirits of the game.
I hope that, if you ever consider making another game like this, that you would find ways to have the main character bond with the Spirits and learn more about them.

149246082.review:
[ENG/ESP]

[h1]Ender Lilies ~ Quietus of the Knights ~[/h1]

[ENG]

Ender Lilies is a short metroidvania game, taking several elements of some games like Castlevania, Hollow Knight and the Dark Souls saga. In this title, we are a mysterious girl who awakens in a hostile environment in the continent of Finisterra. An endless rain covers almost the entire map, and every single creature you will face is blighted with a strange disease or curse, known as the Impurity. With the initial help of a Black Knight, the girl will face a lot of dangers while she purifies and saves these fallen beings, discovering the secrets this world has to offer along the way.

[u]-First, this is a metroidvania game,[/u] so you'll find a 2d, scrolling game with enemies to defeat, items to interact with and secret paths and objects. And even if you can't find every single thing in your first visit (the map will indicate in blue colour if you haven't found everything in that area), don't worry, because as you keep exploring, you'll get more abilities that will let you move and enter where you couldn't before. 

[u]-Purifying is the name of the game, but you'll get rewards for it:[/u] Defeat minibosses and bosses to acquire their abilities and use them at your heart's content: with a maximum of three skills per set (having 2 different sets of abilities you can swap and use), you can have six skills to use while you explore Finisterra. 

[u]-This game takes several features from other games,[/u] such as the narrative of Dark Souls and the mechanics of the bonfire, or banks (as in Hollow Knight), allowing you to rest, but the enemies you have defeated will respawn. You can equip a lot of accesories (Hollow Knight) and there you will be able to equip accesories and skills and even enhance skills with items you will find while exploring. Also, the narrative is divided: your first friend, the Black Knight, will tell you some things as the game progresses, you will see cutscenes (memories of several enemies), and you will find pieces of paper and notes with messages, telling you more about the story of this fallen country.

To sum up, with Ender Lilies ~ Quietus of the Knights ~ you'll embark on a journey filled with secrets, dangers and mystery, while you defeat and purify enemies and acquire more knowledge about the past of Finisterra, all embellished with overtaking landscapes, a beautiful soundtrack and a good story. Being myself a huge fan of metroidvania games and all previous features, [b]I definitely recommend this game[/b] to those of you who enjoy a good story, being surrounded by mystery, a desolated background and good music. 

[ESP]

Ender Lilies es un juego corto del estilo metroidvania, que toma muchos elementos de varios juegos como la saga Castlevania, Hollow Knight y la saga Dark Souls. En este título, seremos una chica misteriosa que despierta en un ambiente hostil en el continente de Finisterra. Una lluvia eterna cubre casi todo el continente, y cada criatura que te encontrarás estará infestada por una enfermedad o maldición conocida como la Impureza. Con la ayuda inicial de un Caballero Negro, la chica se enfrentará a un montón de peligros mientras purifica y salva a estos seres caídos, descubriendo los secretos que este mundo tiene que ofrecer.

[u]-Primero, este es un juego metroidvania,[/u] así que te encontrarás con un juego de scroll lateral en 2d con enemigos a los que derrotar, objetos con los que interactuar con recompensas y secretos. E incluso si no puedes encontrar todos los secretos en tu primera visita a la zona (el mapa te indicará con un color azulado si no has encontrado todo en esa zona) no te preocupes, porque mientras sigas explorando y avanzando, ganarás nuevas habilidades con las que moverte y llegar a sitios a los que no podías llegar antes.

[u]-El juego trata de purificar seres impuros, pero te darán recompensas por ello [/u] Derrota a minijefes y jefes duros para adquirir sus habilidades y usarlos como te venga en gana: con un máximo de 3 habilidades por set, (teniendo dos sets distintos de habilidades que puedes cambiar y usar siempre que quieras) puedes tener hasta seis habilidades para usar mientras exploras Finisterra.

[u]-Este juego se inspira en otros juegos y toma varias de sus características,[/u] como la narrativa de Dark Souls (encontrarás diferentes objetos y papeles y notas con mensajes, contándote más sobre la historia de este país caído), las mecánicas de la hoguera de Dark Souls o el banco de Hollow Knight, permitiéndote descansar, pero a coste de resucitar a los enemigos que ya derrotaste antes, etc. Puedes equiparte varios accesorios y habilidades e incluso mejorar estas habilidades con objetos que encontrarás a lo largo del juego.

En definitiva, en Ender Lilies ~ Quietus of the Knights ~ te embarcarás en un viaje lleno de secretos, peligros y misterios, mientras derrotas y purificas enemigos y vas aprendiendo más y más sobre el pasado de estos enemigos y de la propia Finisterra, todo esto embellecido con paisajes sobrecogedores, una banda sonora preciosa y una historia bastante buena. Siendo yo un gran fan de los juegos metroidvania y de disfrutar un buen juego, [b]sin duda alguna recomiendo este juegazo[/b] a aquellos que disfruten una buena historia, que les guste estar rodeados de paisajes desoladores, que les guste escuchar una buena banda sonora y que disfruten de buenas peleas.

149225198.review:
[ Español / English ]

SI TE GUSTAN LOS METROIDVANIAS Y TIENES DUDAS SI COMPRAR ESTE JUEGO, SIGUE LEYENDO:

Como fan de los metroidvanias y habiendo jugado tanto muy buenos títulos como malos, este juego es notablemente bueno y totalmente recomendado. De hecho, considero que está infravalorado como referente de este género. LA RESPUESTA "SI" ES MUY RECOMENDABLE.

Pero tiene algunos aspectos que podrían mejorarse:
   - El mapa es poco intuitivo y confuso.
   - La comunicación entre áreas podría ser mejor.
   - El rendimiento está muy mal optimizado en la zona "Witch's Thicket" (se nota una caída considerable de los fotogramas por segundo).
   - Algunas mecánicas podrían estar mejor explicadas.
   - El Parry es poco satisfactorio, ya que utiliza el mismo botón que el Dash.
   - Las habilidades opcionales de defensa son muy similares y poco útiles.


English 

If you like Metroidvanias and have doubts about whether to buy this game, keep reading:

As a fan of Metroidvanias and having played both very good and bad titles, this game is remarkably good and highly recommended. In fact, I consider it underrated as a reference in this genre. The answer is "YES", highly recommended.

However, there are some areas that could be improved:
   - The map is not very intuitive and confusing.
   - The communication between areas could be better.
   - The performance is poorly optimized in the "Witch's Thicket" area (noticeable FPS drop).
   - Some mechanics could be better explained.
   - The Parry is unsatisfying, as it uses the same button as the Dash.
   - The optional defense skills are very similar and not very useful.

149000363.review:
One of the better Souls-like games out there, definitely worth the price for the Music and Art alone. The lore isn't as vague or as hard to piece together/understand as most titles in the genre and the BGM/OST adds weight to the somber and dreary atmosphere of the game. It also gives further strength to the heart stirring lore of the game, the story pacing is, in my opinion, just right in the sense you are not overwhelmed by the lore dump or you are not completely clueless on what is going on. Also, for those perceptive ones, you get a foreshadowing of the "BOSS" you will be encountering at the end of the general area you are in as well as learning more of what happened to them and how they ended up the way they are. 

Combat-wise, it is unique that the MC cannot attack by herself but instead relies on the spirits of those she has defeated to gain new attacks, combos, passives and utility which in turn helps in the progression/exploration of the game in general. You get 2 three attack slots that you can alternate (for a total of 6 spirits) throughout your journey which you can change with any spirit combination in rest areas so to say that there are a lot of spirit combinations you can do is an understatement. My advice, you do you and test them all out to see what fits your playstyle though sometimes, you might have to slot in some of the ones you don't like just to get through certain areas. 

Lots of pros (which I won't get into much as the reviewers here already got it) but a definite con for beginners and veterans alike is the quite substantial damage received by being touched by enemies (not attacked, TOUCHED!). While you can avoid this and their attacks by using skill based abilities (parry/dodge) and timing, it is worth noting that the farther you go the more damage the enemies can do and the relics to reduce damage are, in my opinion. next to worthless and it is more apt to use those relic slots for something else (ie. better movement, more heals, lifesteal, etc). 

The game is definitely worth the dosh if you can afford it though I always advocate getting games on sale. Not just for the monetary reasons but games on sale (esp. those on 50% above) means that it has been quite some time since its release and any/most bugs and all that has been patched and fixed. Enjoy!

The story wasn't very clear at first, but by the end I had understood most of what happened, although you'll probably have to find some youtube video if you want to understand the lore

(the default ending), and went on with my life, with the vague suggestion that 'I'll probably come back and see the others later'. I did enjoy the game back then, all the same. But going through it again? Knowing what I'm doing, getting to see every nook and cranny, and besting every obstacle to finally, FINALLY, after more than 2 years away, get to see all of the endings, and everything else that the game had to offer?

Even though my experience with this second playthrough is very skewed with personal anecdotes, I can safely say that Ender Lilies is now my new favorite metroidvania, unfortunately dethroning Momodora: RUTM after its exceedingly lengthy, and well-earned rule over this list. This game has so many things coming together to weave the perfect storm, and it's truly beautiful. Musical composition, gameplay, an immaculately perfect blend of difficulty that I wouldn't dare change (and even if I wanted to, I can! Another nice thing to note that the devs threw in for finishing the game.), an enthralling plot that evokes deep emotions and powerful melancholy... It makes it such a unique experience that I think I'd struggle to find elsewhere. 

I actually started this second, new playthrough because I was feeling burned out while going through Lies of P, and I wanted something, in my own mental words, "more relaxing". Though that's probably not the first thing that comes to mind when seeing promo material or gameplay of EL:QotK, I truly feel that it is still accurate. The game, for lack of a better term, is utterly relaxing. It's comfortable, and subdued. This deadened world that the narrative invites you into is so declined that it invites you to adopt the same mentality. Like stepping through a graveyard as the last light of day slips beyond the cloudy mountains. 

Ender Lilies really is worth all the time that it asks of you. In my mind, it doubtlessly and effortlessly reaches the lofty achievement of "I wish it wasn't over yet." Check it out if you even have an inkling that it might be your style, I don't think you'll be disappointed.

148222336.review:
I just could not get into this game. Metroidvania's are my favourite genre and while this has good music and good combat it just didn't feel good to play. I think it comes down to a couple of main issues and a bunch of smaller ones. 

The biggest issue is that the combat and movement in this game just didn't feel satisfying. Killing an enemy or a boss never felt fun, just felt like I pressed some buttons to make my character do some stuff. I think it's partially due to the animations just not quite being crisp enough. Also the bosses have way too much health. Their attacks are easy to dodge but you just have to do the same rinse and repeat move like 30 times to end a fight. It gets boring really fast.

Another major issue is the lacklustre platforming. The platforming in this game is pretty terrible. Mainly because there's just not much of it and when it is there it's super simple. Basically, it's an afterthought. The main draw of this game is the combat and ambience. And I didn't find the combat that engaging either.

Now onto the smaller issues. Most elements of this game are mediocre to good. It's not that they're bad, they're just not great. 
- The music is good but each area has one track that plays over and over and over. I loved the music at first but got sick of it within a couple of hours.
- Animations look a little clunky and make everything feel a little off, decent animations but not good
- It's very difficult to run through areas that you've already been through without methodically taking out each enemy in the way, this can get really annoying as backtracking is necessary and becomes quite lengthy as you have to replay several sections that give you nothing in return just to get to the part you actually wanted to reach
- Literally the worst map I've ever seen in a Metroidvania. It could work for a more linear game but for something this open world the flowchart map is really lacking. Just rectangles and lines. No idea what possessed them to make such a bad map.

I've tried to play this game on two occasions a year apart. Both times putting in several hours and then getting bored of the game. I can see why people like this game but it's not my cup of tea and it's certainly not a masterpiece by any stretch of the imagination. 6/10

148219317.review:
[spoiler]Paid:$12.49[/spoiler]
There is no denying [i]ENDER LILIES: Quietus of the Knights[/i] is drawn from the same vein as [i]Hollow Knight[/i]. Respectively, the former is a notch less challenging than the latter due to not having death penalties, more distinct enemy telegraphs, and no insane achievements that must be obtained. Although, [i]ENDER LILIES[/i] really does hold its own and could easily go from a 20 hour game to a 100 hour game with no death and speed run achievements. I, for one, greatly appreciate that they are not in this game. There is something about the melancholy atmosphere that depresses me enough to warrant a break after couple of hours. This is not a bad thing per se, as I feel it speaks to the effectiveness of the atmosphere created. I just personally wouldn't want to play it more than 20-30 hours. That being said, the game is great but don't expect it to be easy.

148203795.review:
This is an absolutely gorgeous game with fun and varied combat.
The combat is very flexible, with some spirits (basically your weapon summons) being better than others (the 1st one you get i kept with me through the whole game, she's great) - and even then the ones you'd think to ignore have some use (exploration, clearing out enemies for you while you explore, etc). Relic system is fun as well, it's pretty easy to figure out and make builds, so you don't have to spend ages min-maxxing it.
Big fan of the map too, you can quickly see at a glance if you've picked up everything (absolute life saver when running out getting all the collectables).
Story is simple but it works with the medium, and there's some themes and such you could analyse too if you wanted to, spoilers: [spoiler] How the entire burden of the blight is placed upon a single bloodline of women, with their suffering starting when they're only 14, or how disposable the soldiers are. [/spoiler]
It's not really the type of story where you'd want a massive complex thing with loads of storylines, since it'd get confusing especially with how its told.

Difficulty wise I had loads of trouble with two bosses [spoiler]The witch and Elv[/spoiler], and the rest were challenging but very easily doable (I think i did also overlevel a bit by routinely clearing out areas once new abilities were unlocked though, i was level 95ish at the final boss)

Some good features to implement:
A zoom in! I played on steam deck to 100%, but I wish I could zoom in at will so I could see the art better. Could probably do a hacked version by changing the resolution but it wouldn't look as good I think.
Saved relic/spirit sets to swap out (eg for exploration/bosses etc), though it isn't too bad having to re-do them.
Clicking on a respite on the fast-travel screen rather than selecting it from the menu

148174099.review:
在玩《終結者莉莉》的時候會不自覺地拿來跟《奧日》系列作比較。畢竟個人是因爲《奧日》系列才入坑類銀河戰士惡魔城的游戲。但隨著游玩深入，慢慢的也會發現兩個作品之間的不同。

奧日系列是以奇幻世界爲背景。在拯救森林的路途中結識各種 NPC，瞭解他們在森林裏的故事。整體敘事偏溫馨感動。而終結者莉莉則是以類中世紀爲背景。在一片末日的場景中尋找真相，並在路途中瞭解到發生在白巫女各位替身上的悲劇。劇情上偏壓抑，但最終的好結局也是讓人感動。

戰鬥系統方面，莉莉可携帶兩組（每組共三名）替身，給戰鬥帶來不少多樣性。每個 boss 都有不同的攻擊手段和機動性，而且還會根據 boss 自身血量進入不同階段。所以打個 boss 會死幾次也是正常事，死幾次自然就能夠掌握 boss 的性質，和帶哪種替身最適合。游戲也很貼心的在每個 boss 的房間前設置休息點，所以你各位也務必要養成有機會就手動存檔的習慣啊。 [spoiler]（對一周目直接解鎖全結局也有幫助） [/spoiler]

對於游戲的結局，個人認爲算是相當完整了。雖然也很希望會有續作，但也想不到會怎麽接下去講故事。要是能出個 動畫還是什麽的補完末日前和結局后的故事也行啊。

總而言之，要是你喜歡類銀河戰士惡魔城的游戲，喜歡這種偏黑暗的故事情節，那這款《終結者莉莉》值得一試。

148085339.review:
What a game.
I supported it when it was still in early access and I am glad I did. In fact, this was the first early access game I gave a try.

Now it has its cons, [spoiler]like an entire bloody area, called the twin spires,[/spoiler] slightly overkill backtracking for me and a lack of "spirit interaction at respites" with each other and Lily. Would have preferred for them to at least share brief looks with one another. [spoiler]Especially spirits that knew each other, when they were still human.[/spoiler]

However, the vast majority of the game was awesome. Like the pacing for example, which was just great, especially how the game kept on escalating, the environments kept getting more extreme, darker [spoiler]and alien like.[/spoiler] However, this isn't just limited to moving through areas, defeating bosses and reading the lore, but also the character progression and what that really means in this game, for the main character.

One of the highlights was definitely the lore, which was on par with dark souls lore for me. Reading about a place, or the notes of a character, only to end up at that place and meet the character were a real treat[spoiler], especially the final one.[/spoiler] Although some parts of the lore could, have been explained better and more clearly. [spoiler]Like the war between the "settlers" (aka the people under the king of the first age) and the Ancients. Was there ever a war, against the Ancients? Or was it just the "settlers" against the blighted? The king wrote, that the attempts to coexist with the Ancients failed, but did they? Were the Ancients already blighted, when the "settlers" arrived?[/spoiler]

Another highlight is the art, especially the background/environment art. This is one of the most beautiful games I played. The art also serves both the lore and story, through environmental story telling[spoiler] and later helps with the shift of the game's tone.[/spoiler]

All of this was supported by the third highlight of this game, the music. Just starting the game and listening to the main menu theme, was quite something.

The combat was also pretty good, especially around the middle of the game, where I already knew what I was doing and could get in the zone. Some boss fights were challenging, but in an enjoyable way, it was no Sekiro though, obviously. I have definitely enjoyed this combat system far more, than Tails of Iron's combat, particularly because Ender Lilies is way more responsive.

Lastly, this game had probably the most satisfying [spoiler]true[/spoiler] ending, in any game I have played so far and the buildup to getting to the final boss, was something else alright. I wasn't even sad when I finished it, just grateful that I got to play this amazing piece of art.
It was almost a masterpiece for me, almost, with just a little bit more care in some of the lore bits, one nasty area improvement, some better backtracking rewards and some simple character interactions at the respites, it could have been one. Alas, it isn't, but that's fine, as it was still an amazing experience that I got to enjoy, sometimes multiple days in a row, just playing this game and nothing else.

147960515.review:
I previously 100%'d this game on Nintendo Switch and currently plan to do so again on Steam. At a glance, it's easy to label this game "another Metroidvania" or "yet another Soulslike" though I strongly believe this game has an identity all its own when you actually play through it.

The atmosphere is an absolute 10/10 for me. The art style, music, and world really come together to beautifully and though this is a wildly different game from Metroid Prime, it's one of very few games in the decades since to really bring me back that feeling of being a small child exploring a daunting, seemingly endless world of mystery.

Of course, Ender Lilies has some solid gameplay to back up the presentation, though the combat can take some getting used to. Most of your attacks are very disconnected from your player character, behaving more like trapping tools such as those found on a character like Snake or Duck Hunt in Super Smash Bros. As a result, maximizing my damage output often seemed like less a matter of getting in and smacking an enemy and more a matter of understanding the exact AOE of my current attack set, how long each lasts, and how they compliment my current primary weapon choice. Also, bosses are by far the hardest part of the game, so expect to die a fair few times on all of them your first time through.

Beyond that? I just thought it was just a really fun time and I would love to see how a hypothetical sequel could push the presentation further and polish up some rough corners present in the game design.

If you are a lore enjoyer and love to challenge yourself, I recommend this game.
The game tells the story of the journey of a young girl named "Lily" who sets out to find her memories and purpose in life. The younger one will have a follower as a spirit. that must work together to overcome many obstacles Along the way, we will learn the story of the boss through notes within the game. The further you travel, the more you can explore. The more Lily's truth will be revealed.

147853377.review:
Not a godly masterpiece, but it's a good game to say the least. Another reviewer is correct that it seems like the dev team is imbalanced. The music fits well and improves the game. The art is above average and somber just like the music. Randomly the animations are much worse than most anything else which exhibits this uncanny cheapness that damages the mood. Level design and enemy placement is also definitely worse than the art and music. Nice selection of spells and weapons. And let's say the combat is generally pretty good. 

It's all good enough, and I was in awe at times even if not particularly often. It did manage to suck me in, usually through art and music, but occasionally through a close boss fight.

3 significant complaints:
- Map sucks (no detail or accurate room shapes). Seems intentional but grew on me. They probably want you to have to pay attention during exploration. But lack of info and no markers means you're going to be wandering endlessly at times. Also makes some areas feel like an unnecessary pain to traverse.

- Bosses not fair sometimes. Still mostly great fights, eventually, but some have one shots or near-oneshots that will cheese you for no meaningful reason. Annoying. Wastes a lot of time with sucker punches as the boss transitions to another phase and does some new thing to immediately kill you that you can't really predict or react to until some failures.

-  Most annoying thing about the game: overabundance of enemies takes away from the nicely made environments and pacing as you explore. There are WAY too many enemies on every single screen. It's tiring and gets really old. I started just sprinting by stuff. It would be better if there was more enemy variation but it's kind of lacking. Otherwise cool areas just become annoying due to this.

Either way this is better than almost any metroidvania I can remember in recent years. After Hollow knight (basically the best similar game ever), the only same-genre games I remember impressing me at all are blasphemous and this. 

Happy that I played this.

Gorgeous metroidvania game with an emphasis on visuals, OST, and souls-like gameplay. Its biggest weakness being the default generic map. With a game that requires so much backtracking, this almost made me drop the game. I would recommend anyone who plays this game to use the steam community map. Trust me, it will save you a lot of time and frustration of the ridiculous amount of backtracking required to progress the story. It made my overall experience playing Ender Lilies so much more enjoyable.

The combat in this game felt satisfying due to the stunning visuals. Though I would've hoped they made the character be able to move while casting spirits to make game-play smoother. Even so, the combination of jumping, parrying, and SP abilities; along with a wide variety of Spirit combos available made the experience feel engaging and non-repetitive.

The OST is honestly so beautiful, though it can get old sometimes with the amount of times you get to hear it and backtrack through these areas.

The story is dark and interesting. Fitting of the scenery. The map itself tells a story on its own. A classic feature of souls-like games. The only problem with that the telling of this story and its plot could have been much better. Witnessing the animated cut-scenes after the boss fights was a treat, but they were either too short, or too vague. And the only thing left for the player is to fill in the blanks of the plot by reading scattered notes through exploration, In my opinion, its a rather messy and boring way of storytelling.

Overall, I had a good time playing Ender Lilies. And I would recommend this game to anyone willing to put some time into a new metroidvania or indie title. It is definitely not a must play, it has significant flaws, such as the terrible mapping provided. Luckily, this can be remediated with the Steam Community Ender Lilies map guide.

Follow the story of Lily, the last remaining White Priestess. Endure the pain of purifying the Blighted and restoring peace to the corrupted wastelands.

147629983.review:
El género "metroidvania" desde hace unos años se ha revitalizado, recuerdo aquella recreativa del famoso "Bar de Vicente" en la que por las tardes nos gastábamos un dinero en monedas de "5 duros", esas eran aventuras de media hora como mucho, para el negocio, estos nuevos metroid son juegos relativamente largos, para disfrutar y evolucionar con personaje e historia, Ender Lilies es un buen ejemplo.

Nos metemos en la piel de Lily, una Doncella Blanca cuya misión es acabar con la impureza que asola su mundo, aunque la historia es muy manida, el desarrollo es interesante, nos vamos encontrando páginas que nos cuentan detalles del mundo, de ciertos personajes o los desvelos y elucubraciones de otros. Se nos va desvelando a base de pinceladas y cuando vencemos a ciertos enemigos o jefes finales, que no son obligatorios pero ayudan a comprender la trama, hasta llegar al final (o posible final de tres diferentes), un buen aliciente para completarlo de varias formas.

La jugabilidad es muy clásica metroid, manejamos por los escenarios a Lily, respondiendo el control de forma correcta, por medio de "habitaciones" llenas de enemigos y objetos a encontrar, una vez exploramos podemos pasar a la siguiente o buscar otra posible salida, el consultar el mapa será una constante a cada paso que demos, para saber hacia dónde debemos ir o qué habitáculo nos falta por explorar a fondo. Muy agradecido el hecho de que cuando falta algo por recoger el cuadro del mapa es azul, y cuando está explorada por completo cambia a naranja. Buen detalle. Los mapas se van interconectando poco a poco según avanzamos por los niveles. 

Es importante el manejo en cuanto a saltos y acceso a zonas difíciles del juego, pero quitando algunos lugares remotos muy contados, no supone especial desafío tipo "Guacamelee" o similares, con el tiempo iremos adquiriendo nuevos poderes y así llegar a zonas antes imposible, otro clásico de estos juegos. El combate es otra de las partes que sustenta el juego, se hace de forma amena, rápido, ágil y directo, podremos equipar dos conjuntos de tres habilidades diferentes e intercambiar, algunas infinitas, otras limitadas en usos, aparte, encontraremos reliquias muy útiles que nos ayudarán al equiparlas (más vida, ampliar usos, mayor daño), es importante saber cuales equipar en cada momento pues las ranuras son escasas y habrá que gestionar el inventario según convenga en cada zona o enemigo. En cuanto a estos últimos mencionados, hay bastante variedad según la zona, engendros impuros desde simples espadachines a aberraciones enormes, junto con los subjefes que nos dan píldoras de historia al vencerlos así como nuevas habilidades, y los jefes finales que nos dan mayores detalles y una habilidad indispensable para acceder a nuevos lugares. Los subjefes son sencillos (normalmente se encuentran escondidos en zonas de difícil acceso) y los jefes basta aprender sus patrones para que tampoco supongan un reto frustrante. El diseño está bien pero tampoco resultarán memorables. Al eliminar adversarios subimos de nivel pero eso se traduce solo en un poco más de energía y un poco más de daño, testimonial.

Gráficamente nos encontramos ante un juego con claroscuros, algunos escenarios son realmente bellos (todo hecho a mano) como zonas boscosas o la zona inundada, con fortalezas, aldeas, acantilados, y otros con un diseño que me ha parecido horrible, como la zona oscura o la infestada de gas tóxico, pero todo muy clásico, destacando los tonos oscuros ante todo, el negro, rojo o verdoso. Puede hacerse repetitivo a este nivel pues normalmente se transita varias veces por los mismos lugares, y más teniendo que acabar en general con los mismos enemigos una vez descansamos para recuperarnos (como el subgénero "souls like")

En cuanto al sonido, nos encontramos con efectos sonoros básicos y una elección de melodías que aunque alguna en un principio puede resultar hermosa al oído, al cabo del tiempo al repetirse sin cesar según donde nos encontremos acaban resultando irritantes, y como en el diseño de niveles algunas son horribles. No tiene voces el juego, lo único que se ofrece es texto en perfecto castellano.

En definitiva es un "Metroidvania" de corte clásico, a veces te encantará explorar algunos de sus escenarios y otros se atragantaran por el diseño, estaremos dando vueltas en busca de algún objeto, otras luchando contra enemigos que vuelven a reaparecer al descansar o intentando descubrir hacia donde hay que avanzar. Lo recomiendo, pero alguien que no tenga simpatía por este tipo de juegos dudo que le pudiera entusiasmar Ender Lilies.

NOTA 7`5/10

147583380.review:
ENDER LILIES: Quietus of the Knights is beautiful, in the truest sense of the word.

It's just delightful to look at almost everything - the backgrounds, the characters, the cutscenes. The original soundtrack by Mili is fantastic and compliments every moment exquisitely. So many great songs have found their way into my heart and my playlist.

I love the dark and gritty world and atmosphere. I thoroughly enjoyed unraveling the story piece by piece and learning more about the people, their relationships, their mostly tragic demises and all the other events that took place here. I really felt immersed and touched a lot of the times.

The main boss fights are magnificent. Normally bosses stress me out, but these I really liked to duel. They're all unique, well-balanced and with an interesting backstory, and after beating them they present you with new abilities as they join your ranks as Spirit summons. Since your player character isn't the one actually fighting and traversing the increasingly difficult terrain, but your Spirits, you constantly unlock new combat moves, tools and movement options.

The aforementioned fighting and traversing are heaps of fun when your portfolio is steadily expanding and you can mix and match dozens of Spirits and other upgrades to suit your play style and to reach new areas. In the beginning, the game is rather linear, but soon the world opens up to you and leaves you to choose how and when to approach certain obstacles, at least to an extend.

Even though the platforming isn't exactly something to write home about and the overall complexity and depth of the game can't be compared to something like Hollow Knight, the whole package is definitely a worthwhile endeavor.

In the end, if I want to experience a delightfully bitter sweet story in a gloomy but also dreamy world, equipped with my trusty Spirit companions and some of the best music I have witnessed in a game, I will gladly come back to ENDER LILIES.

147562455.review:
this is a heartbreaking but well made game.  
the music sets a melancholy tone and the ambience only enhances this masterfully.
the game has a great set up for difficulty. it definitely feels more on the easy side (aside from bosses)
only because it is more methodical then reaction oriented. 
the way you battle is not on you're own. it is by the spirits that aid you. to get a new spirit you must beat and purify it first. 
there are 2 types of spirits. red spirits which are the main skill you will use and option spirits. option spirits only have a set amount of uses before you have to find a place to rest before you can use them again. red spirits generally have unlimited uses. you can have a total of 6 different spirits on you at once.
you only can heal 3x per life. you can get them back by resting.
when you rest like most souls like all enemies reset. (they do not respawn otherwise)
if you die the only disadvantage is mobs reset. even that being the case you will die alot anyway.
bosses are varied and difficult. which was worrisome in the beginning.
a very solid game with outstanding lore, music and ambience. 
i would say more but i don't want to spoil anything. i went in blind and am loving it silly so far. there is quite alot of hidden things to discover and explore.
9.5/10
p.s still not finished game yet but been through 3 major zones. will update when i progress more
p.p.s if you are in some safe areas and do not rest the song will get audio but be instrumental when resting
p.p.p.s the game play keeps getting better and better so far.

147496653.review:
I never finish a game with all achievements and 100%, but I did on this one, so it has to matter for something. 

Ender Lillies is a game that will not necessarily revolutionize your gaming experience, but I guarantee that you will remember it. It has an ambience, and even though I don't think the story or the narrative is of the best writing or epic, it drives the point home and sometimes nails it nicely. 

You might get a bit lost sometimes, especially if you don't remember how the rooms are, and the game won't take your hand and tell you where to go. If you're getting tired and you're like me, you'll wander aimlessly like an idiot trying to find your way. Just go to bed and come back the day after, it's not especially tough to find your way. 

As for the difficulty, I found it quite fair. I'm not the best gamer in the world and this game doesn't expect you to be. However it holds a certain standard, and will challenge you progressively. I liked a lot the fact that it doesn't punish you for dying, like Dark Souls or Hollow Knight. Instead you're put back in the last bench visited, and there's a reasonable amount of them. You can even teleport very early, which makes the game easier to complete (that and the fact that the rooms are telling you if they're completed or not). 

All in all I think you'll have a good time there, sometimes a tad frustrating but I don't think that's necessarily the game's fault, in the sense that its doing the job well. 

There's also a nice NG+ and stuff to customize after you finish all the endings, so go for it! I'm not a challenger runner myself but if you're one of those, you'll find something to chew on after your first playthrough.

147476906.review:
The only reason I'm taking my time to write this review is because I've never been baited so hard by an "overwhelmingly positive" score on steam.

Ender Lilies (EL) is a metroidvania in which you play as a little girl, who is the chosen one to cure the world of "the blight", a disease that makes people transform into monstrosities and lose their minds.

So let's start with the good aspects of the game:

1. The artstyle, I guess? Just like the story, it isn't exactly charming or stands out on its own for it to be a big selling point for this game in particular (or any other game, to be honest, as graphics are something that should only complement the gameplay, which is the most important aspect of any game)

And that's the only redeeming quality for this game. Now, the bad aspects:

1. Story. Mediocre and unoriginal. It tries to do its storytelling through EXTREMELY quiet cutscenes, with no voice acting and barely any sound effects or music, and pieces of text that you find throughout the world. However, the story and setting is so unimaginably bland that after 30 minutes of gameplay, I couldn't be arsed to read or pay attention to anything related to lore.

2. Combat. It's bad. Very bad. Considering that combat is supposed to be one of the main aspects of the game, I can't imagine who in their right mind would design combat like this. Unlike Hollow Knight (which I assume this games was heavily inspired on), when you attack in this game, you are stuck in the animation until it ends (including when you do aerial attacks). So there's no animation cancelling, no fluidity to the combat, making it incredibly clunky and an overall unfun experience. Also, the spirits that I got in my short playthrough are so useless that I couldn't be bothered to use them.

3. Bosses. Keep in mind that I only fought the first 2 bosses. The first one was kind of ok, maybe a bit too easy. The second one was such a slog to fight against. Even though I defeated it first try, the boss had such a massive health pool that it made the experience miserable. Extremely easy to dodge attacks, accompanied by a 5 minute fight that overextends itself for no apparent reason.

4. Exploration. VERY large and empty stages with little to no incentive to explore, as the upgrades that I found were so uninteresting that after 20 minutes of playtime, I didn't want to explore anymore. I mean, +5 max HP permanent upgrades and relics that increase my damage while in water (???) and that increase my max HP by 5, just like the permanent upgrades? Might as well just delete these relics, they add absolutely nothing to the game. It also doesn't help that, after the second boss, the game already made me backtrack to "explore" more the game with the ground pound attack. I know that one of the main selling points of metroidvanias is the backtracking after acquiring new powers, but making it happen so early in the game is kind of strange.

5. Soundtrack. To be honest, it isn't that bad. However, one of the songs was so unbelievably repetitive, spanning across multiple screens of the game, that it made me mute in-game music. I've never had to do this in my entire life playing video games, ESPECIALLY considering this was under the 2 hour mark of gameplay.

I sincerely don't understand what makes people enjoy or even recommend this game. There's no saving grace, no selling point, nothing interesting or original about it. It has to be one of the most bland experiences I've had with video games so far. It absolutely boggles my mind that this game almost an overall overwhelmingly positive review score.

147415186.review:
Probably one of my most favorite metroidvanias of all times.
The gameplay is extremely engaging and adaptive. The sheer number of combinations with your spirits and relics leaves room for tons of experimentation and there are several opportunities for high-risk-high-reward choices to be made by the player. (I personally like parrying and meeting each enemy's moveset face-first but there's tons of options in approaching each situation.
The exploration is insanely fun. Admittedly, a few things are hidden a bit too well but finding them is always simple enough since the game tells you each area that still has things to collect which is extremely convenient for completionists like me. Additionally, I love finding bits of lore and piecing together the tragic stories of the characters you meet on your journey. 
Lastly, It's pretty conventional but the story hits just the right tones with me and I adore it a lot. There's a lot of darkness, misery and pain to the characters that you meet and the concentration of the world's despair only increases and grows as you progress through the game. As someone attempting to bear the weight of the world, there's an ever-present sense of tragedy to your journey but it's journeys like this that I find deeply moving and inspiring.
With all that said, I hope you give this game a shot. It's evidently a product of love and I would really like for more people to experience it and support the dev team.
