147253021.review:
TL;DR: it's a solid 7.5/10. if you go in expecting a masterpiece you'll probably be disappointed, but it's definitely a game worth checking out. while i found several aspects like combat or level design to be kind of flawed, it's good enough. and honestly the ost and some of the final cutscenes by themselves might be enough to justify buying the game

combat is... okay. i don't like standing still while attacking, that really put me off for a while because it made me feel like sometimes i had to exchange hits or use a lame ranged build. some other metroidvanias do this too and i'm personally not a fan, that kind of mechanic fits souls a lot since it encourages using map geometry and outflanking the opponent. but in 2D games where the enemy and you have only two directions of attacking, it can become kind of tedious and frustrating kiting back and forth. 

the bosses are great, i loved most of them because they feel like a grand duel with both sides trying to exploit weaknesses and openings in the other. except for hoenir, fuck that guy and his summons.

the level design is the biggest complaint of people and while it isn't amazing, i didn't find it to be that bad either. it's entirely serviceable, just don't expect hollow knight.

the music is really nice, definitely worth putting a lot of the ost in your playlist. it can be very emotional and chilling like:
lily, prologue, main theme, awakening, harmonious, a nocturne for all, dewdrop, grudge, bible outro, bloom intro, bloom outro, accolade intro, mother outro

relaxing and calming like: 
holy land, bible intro, debris and bugs, the white witch

and even inspiring and adventurous like:
north, pulsation

the usage of leitmotifs are also obvious, and very charming. but one emotion i feel like they weren't able to quite capture were more negative emotions like scariness/fear or tension, like compounding, the witch's breath or evil intro. that being said more melancholic/sad vibes were executed very well (mostly in the emotional songs), and it enhances the bleak atmosphere of the game

the art is okay, it does kind of look like a weird mobile game. i think the main character is cute but the enemies having similar head to body proportions as her, an anime child, just makes them look goofy, no matter how much blood they have on their ragged clothes or rotten bones and flesh sticking out of their body. none of them look intimidating or scary, which does take a bit from the experience.

as for the story, i found it to be quite cliche and edgy at the start, and the melodramatic journals you find definitely don't help. when i finished the game though i grew to like it. there are definitely great concepts in the lore and story writing, and some of those great plot points being revealed with an amazingly emotional ost in the background does make them feel a lot more special. definitely worth watching the lore videos made by Indie Xplorer

Dark, somber and beautiful game. The style of a (mostly) helpless character protected by blighted sprints who take care off attacking was new and unique for me and only added to the mood. The aesthetics of a decayed world will itch that dark souls scratch, the music is beautiful, all together really conveyed that the end of the world had not only arrived but passed. Combat can be difficult, souls-like difficulty in 2D is sometimes a pain but this game provides plenty of skills to fight with against all kinds of enemies.

It is not a very lengthy game if you know what you are doing. It took me so long because i am an idiot and actually got myself lost a few times in what should have been pretty straightforward map navigation. I eagerly await a sequel to this game/series. Cant wait what they will come up with or expand upon!

147063437.review:
Melancholy metroidvania. 

Pro
- Cohesive plot told through journals and cutscenes.
- Competent and responsive platforming. Some tricky optional jumps if going for 100%.
- Area bosses join as a 'basic attack' and minibosses join as a 'skill'. They appear in their actual forms when resting or when you stop moving for a bit.
- Effort has been made to make boss encounters memorable. There's foreshadowing of area boss identities; miniboss encounters have unique attacks and are typically off the critical path.
- Bosses and enemies are mostly unique. There aren't any recycled attacks, though two or three get upgraded in later areas.
- Beautiful levels. Several layers of parallax. 
- Soundtrack contributes to level mood. Also Mili.

Con
- Can be difficult to distinguish between your skills and enemy attacks.
- Enemy damage is high. Contact damage feels slightly unfair.

146029451.review:
Fantastic game!! In a single word, "Moving". 

I just beat the full story at 28 hours. 
Note: I will share no spoilers in this post.

I am usually more of a puzzle and Character/Story driven type gamer, but decided to try it out when I saw how much effort was put into the character sprites. 

Overall, really solid controls and mechanics. 
I had so a few bosses that really tested me and a few moments where I jumped for joy when I completed a challenge! Tight game-play for your button commands and you are also reward for each monster you fight. The battle style is really adaptable, and was able to adjust it just right to support my style of combat.

Great atmosphere and the music in one of the earlier maps is such a mood! I have found myself humming the music sometimes while I wasn't playing. I now have it on my music playlist. 

The story details are dripped in throughout your journey and consistently evolving if you look for it. Basically you get more weight to your actions the more you pay attention to the world around you. 
The effect of the story on the main character was so gripping for me, and it made me want to see her succeed- if it is even possible. Somehow they made her delicate but so strong at the same time. It makes you want to protect her and also follow her into this world. 

If you are teetering on if you should try this game, please do. I absolutely loved it!

146014788.review:
ENDER LILIES: Quietus of the Knights is not just an incredibly good Souls like metroidvania game, it's an incredibly beautiful and touching game that will make you cry a bit, so the story what is it. In a once beautiful kingdom known as Land's End is now in turmoil, ravaged by endless toxic rain and undead immortal monsters known as the blighted, a lone girl wakes up who may be the hope to ending this nightmare.

Okay let’s talk about the likes; the story is incredibly beautiful, with a great sense of melancholy and sadness as well as hope, it's the kind of story that touched me deeply and made me cry a bit, the story is also told not just through cutscenes, but with notes, item description and enemy description just like a good Souls like game making you piece together the story. 

The gameplay is very good, it's hard but fair like any good Souls like game and it also takes a bit of inspiration from Castlevania not just with its design, you see you play as a little girl that doesn't really have any powers, but she can bond with the souls of the enemies and bosses allowing you to use their powers to destroy to fight kind of like Castlevania Dawn of Sorrow where you can gain the souls of enemies and gain their power. 

There are also plenty of relics that you can find that can enhance your stats, health and or give you certain advantages. the game can also be really forgiving but still hard like after I picked up an item I was killed immediately after, at first I thought I had to go all the way back to pick up that item, but no if you pick up an item or got some experience and you die before getting to a save you don't have to go all the way back to pick up that item or experience again which I enjoyed.

The graphics are absolutely breathtakingly beautiful with an incredible use of bright yet somber colors with plenty of little details and incredible set pieces that just make you want to stop and stare at it. The levels are really good and breathtakingly beautiful, quite diverse with a wide range of worlds to explore from a cursed village to a creepy crypt to even the heart of the blight, all of it was breathtakingly beautiful to look at and explore with nice touches here and there that just makes the world feel alive.

The characters were very good, now there's only two main characters in the game the little girl and her protector, but through little dialogue and subtle gestures you really get to know them as people.  You also get to know the enemies and the bosses through cutscenes, notes, enemy and item descriptions which helped to endear these characters. The enemies and bosses are really good each one with their own horrifying designs, like undead demonic nuns and undead knights, I can see a lot of thought was put into these creatures designs and abilities and functions.

The cutscenes were really good very cinematic and detailed with a great use of shades of gray and atmosphere. The atmosphere is really good depressing but in a beautiful way as you wander through this corrupted and blighted land, it even got a little creepy near the end of the game. The music was magnificent each soundtrack incredibly beautiful and just fit the game so well, I especially loved the ending song it was well written and very beautiful to listen too.

The game also has some interesting little side bits like after defeating a boss you can fight that boss again when you go to a save, there's also notes in the game and you know I love notes because it can help with the world building and these notes do exactly that, you can also find out more about the world through enemy and item descriptions like any souls like game and after beating the game completely there's also a mode where you can make the game harder or easier if you're interested in a challenge.

Okay let’s talk about the dislikes; this game is almost perfect, but the only thing I would say it needs is voice acting, in certain parts of the game like when your companion talks I did miss a bit of what he said due to the dialogue being a little fast.

Okay now that I've told you all this ENDER LILIES: Quietus of the Knights is not just an incredibly good Souls like metroidvania game, it's an incredibly beautiful and touching game that will make you cry a bit, it just has so much to love from the incredibly beautiful story, very good gameplay and magnificent music, I highly, highly recommend this game if you're a fan of souls like or metroidvania games you must get this game.

145811543.review:
7/10

Ender Lilies is a metroidvania with some souls-like mechanics. You explore the world looking for the next boss and power-up that will let you explore more of the world. The combat is difficult to the point of punishing, but death has no cost.

[b]The good:[/b]
The game is gorgeous. The hand-drawn art is just a joy to look at.

The music, while fairly simple at times, is somber, and sets the mood perfectly. Not everything needs a full orchestra, and I really enjoyed some of the piano-only BGM.

The combat offers a pretty good range of options, and none of them feel underwhelming. Plus, you can use so many at once, it allows a great deal of flexibility in how you approach things. Great game feel in that regard.

[b]The bad:[/b]
The map. The map is just a series of rectangles with dots and lines connecting them. The only thing to distinguish each room is the shape of the rectangle. Rooms can be one of two colors, but that's only based on whether you have found everything in the room, not it's location.

Leveling. This game didn't need a leveling mechanic. The combat feels great, but losing because the boss is just too high level doesn't feel good. But on that note:

Backtracking. This is a thing in every metroidvania, I'm not opposed to backtracking. But this game had me so frustrated. The map is so unclear, I would visit the same rooms over and over to figure out if I had the power I needed now only to find that no...I don't. Or worse, I do have the power to make progress, but the room after that requires [i]another[/] power, so the disappointment just hits harder.

The biggest frustration is the loop I found myself in: Get frustrated by a boss I'm under-leveled for. Go exploring instead. Get frustrated because everywhere I explore requires a power I still don't have. But I've gained a few levels so I give up on exploring and go beat the boss. So I get a new power, which (after searching half the map because I can't remember where that power is needed) leads me to the next boss where the cycle begins again.

[b]The meh:[/b]
The story is alright. It's not pushing any boundaries. There is nothing profound. There is not a lot of hidden mysteries by the end. But it's well written for what it is.

The penultimate boss took me like, 50 tries at least. I had use nearly all of my abilities to their fullest. It was frustrating at the time, but in hindsight, a really satisfying challenge. But the final boss? It took me 3 tries. It stays in one spot and spawns enemies. Its attacks are infrequent, very telegraphed, and easy to avoid. Just a weird way to end a difficult game.

Overall, if you like dark, moody atmosphere and art, and you enjoy getting your ass beat, this might be worth it. But get ready to level grind a bit and maybe take notes or just look up a proper map online.

Cada minuto de juego es una alegría, es imposible aburrirse con este juego, su profunda historia, el arte que tiene, los personajes, la exploración, todas las partículas que acompañan tanto a los ataques como a los movimientos. 145584349.review:
Ender Lilies is a visually unique and stylish dark fantasy themed platformer with metroidvania style progression. If you are into this kind of games, be warned that game is pretty difficult and some boss fights are very difficult - there is no easy mode, which is quite bad in accessibility sense, not all gamers can get through such boss fights, and some don't want to stress too much to see the full story. Game is slightly rough around edges with a lot of good moments and also some quite average moments which is a shame, this game could have been a real master piece.

I was originally drawn to game by its visual style, but I think in the late game old school level design style sort of breaks the illusion of the style developers were going after, I couldn't care less how some castle looks if game goes to 80s style platforming with all the antics of that era. If you compare Ender Lilies to a game like Hollow Knight, it does challenging areas way better without resorting into in my opinion bad design choices. 

Gameplay and character movement is pretty smooth, although it can feel in the beginning slightly laggy due to animations. Helper spirits that grant you new skills are visually neat, but also can cause hard to read moments in tight combat situations. Game protagonist is also (on purpose) weak and frail, and this theme is also there in every enemy encounter and boss battle, this can be a source of frustration, especially in early game.

Slight spoilers ahead - game progression is quite uneven, there are several endings, although the first one comes suprisingly early without much effort, later endings requires visiting all the areas game has to offer, but the last one was way too grindy for me, so I resorted to using guides to get 100% instead of jumping from every ledge to find out if some hidden object is there or not. There are also some jumping puzzles which are actually quite neat.

I wish the developers would have put more effort into level design and balancing the leveling up and overall flow, and making it match the visual quality of the game. Music and audio too in general are very good, especially in the toughest boss battles. I would recommend getting the game in sale, unless you are a metroidvania enthusiast.

145558278.review:
[h1]¿Que es ENDER LILIES?[/h1]

[b]Ender Lilies[/b] es un plataformero tipo metroidvania en un mundo devastado por un suceso llamado "Diluvio Mortal". Tomaremos el papel de Lily, una doncella blanca encargada de purificar las almas afectadas.

Es un mundo melancolico y triste con un lore muy interesante.

145554330.review:
The area designs, graphics, and general storytelling are all super nice. 
The art style is absolutely gorgeous and captures the world amazingly. It's definitely the best that I've seen in a long time!

It's a very linear game with a clear path in mind but with so much exploration.
Exploration rewards you with titbits about the story and how the world came to be, as well as buffs to make progression easier.

Oh, and I can't forget about the wonderful soundtrack that follows you throughout the game. It's so beautiful and each area-specific OST fits so well. I could listen to the music all day!~

Overall, this game is as beautiful as a game could be. I can't wait to fully beat it!

Hated some of the bosses and level design, loved the art and the soundtrack might be one of the best I’ve ever heard.

Another thing I didn’t like is it was all enemies or dead spirit allies. A few NPCs or something would have made the world more lived in, even if the entire point is the whole world is dead I still think some interactable characters would have gone a long way. Its somewhere between a 7.5-8.5 for me I haven’t decided yet. But yeah I’m better for having played it if nothing else than for the soundtrack so yes it was worth it.

145520933.review:
Ender lilies starts a little slow . Once you get a couple of powers it becomes very fun to play and explore. There are 4 powers that you can equip on each weapon . Only a total of 2 weapons can be equiped. However you will need to switch weapons to use all 4 powers. Every weapon has 2 powers on them that you can mix and match! You can find more than 15+ powers. There are some fun combinations that will kill and stagger enmies realy quick! later on you will get a super kill move for  every weapon that you need to charge up by killing foes. all combined its a fun combat system.

I didnt like that you can´t place markers on the map for important rooms you want to revisit later in the game, its hard to rember everything. The bosses are good but not amazing. Ender Lilies over all is definitely worth your time if your looking for a fun metroidvania game.

145515900.review: A really captivating game that is both challenging and immersive both in terms of story and game development. Really worth checking out if you enjoy 2D platformers and dark, beautiful aestethics which does not take too long time to see through. Also, the music is really great.

145507997.review:
I'm a sucker for this kind of "escortee" game, where you're the weak(er) and (more) helpless one being protect by a collection of fighters you command more than control. It's a very cohesive setup, little girl who's giving these ghosts a physical form. Explains why they can attack through walls and enemies can't, gets you attached to your weapon loadout like the characters they are, helps your get invested in helping this world by getting to know the victims of its plight firsthand.

Overall a very emotional experience, making use of Dark Souls-esque mechanics without trying to make the game punishingly difficult, and pulling from some beloved Metroid-likes like Aria of Sorrow, but every inch of this world feels thought through; nothing here was borrowed or inspired from somewhere else without a reason. I feel like you'll know whether you'll love this game and its myriad of pleasant surprises from the moment you beat the first boss - I was definitely hooked from go.

145503167.review:
Very solid game. This may be a personal take, but the art style is great, and the player character is objectively cute. On top of a gorgeous art style, the animations feel polished from a game play perspective as well. The music is also stellar, there's a great sense of tone set by the environment, and power-ups all add to the lore. Speaking of the lore, I found the story to be interesting and fun to piece together, and 
Ender Lilies drip feeds it to you at the perfect rate. The platforming is nothing out-of-this-world, but I think it works because it lets you focus on the combat which is more engaging anyway (at least for me). TLDR, if you're on your last 2 ounces of sanity waiting for Silksong, then this game is for you

145492213.review:
Recomendable.

Buena banda sonora que pega con el estilo del juego.

Hay algunas salas "secretas" que se pueden acceder desde mucho antes aprovechando las mecánicas del juego, sin necesidad de desbloquear la habilidad que te piden para esa zona. 
Pisos de carne: Caída + X
Muros de carne: Dash + X
Lamparas: C (si no mal me acuerdo)
Varias de estas salas que se podían acceder usando las lamparas se pueden saltear usando diversos combos, el que descubrí yo usando la habilidad del martillo es: Salto + Martillo x2 + Doble salto + Martillo x2 + Dash + Martillo x2. Manteniendo el ataque del martillo para mas potencia y apuntando para atrás de donde saltemos para que nos impulse en la dirección correcta. 

Los primeros 2 o 3 Bosses tienen buena dificultad ya que no tenias tantas variedad de ítems ni habilidades, y se dificultaban. Ya luego de esos, todos los demás son bastantes sencillos, con 1 o 2 intentos ya los tenias hechos y no tenían un patrones de habilidades tan grande. La segunda parte del ultimo si que se me complico un poco, pero tampoco fue mucho, una media hora o así.
En general al juego le falta dificultad, aunque luego de completartelo te dan una opción para modificar las estadísticas de los enemigos y las tuyas, para aumentar la dificultad del juego mucho mas, pero no probé esta característica así que realmente no se que experiencia de juego de.  

No esta nada mal, me complete el juego al 100% en 23h. Si no jugaste ningún metroidvania antes, este seria una muy opción para empezar. (Aunque técnicamente el juego no es un metroidvania xd)

145481341.review:
Having played a decent enough number of Metroidvanias, I can say for sure that this game feels like one the easiest one you can find out there.

There's really nothing that gives you a real challenge. the environment, the enemy attacks, the bosses, the checkpoints, everything is very forgivable towards you (you can actually travel between checkpoints for free by just entering the menu and teleporting to the last one so you can go wherever you want, not even dying gives you a single penalty) and you don't really feel the "danger" around the corner like many other Metroidvenias.

That being said, I can settle down for a seat-back experience like this. The music and the whole ambient sounds are very good, the art direction is sublime and the level design makes good use of the few traversal mechanics the game gives you.

I certainly enjoyed my time with it, even tho I would have loved a bit more in terms of difficulty.

This game was so damn good. I love a Metroid-Vania style game, it just gets the dopamine flowing. the art style is lends a believable personality to the game and works with the music/sound design to really make the setting. the combat can be brutal at times, but that's usually due to you not paying attention to the enemy's tell. You can get all endings in 1 play through which I greatly appreciate as a quality of life mechanic. The story is told through the environment and collectible "logs" scattered about. It's nice because I had some revelations right when the story seemed to want me to have them, which is honestly a nice change of pace. a lot of games feel a bit predictable these days. 

I can't say enough good things about this. it's definitely worth a chance

145370594.review:
Ender lilies is very underrated.  This was an amazing game with great visuals, very solid controls, and a great sense of challenge but isn't too hard. I picked this game up thinking "oh hey, this seems like it might be like hollow knight!" and boy, was I correct, but wrong at the same time. Although it is quite similar to hollow knight, the bosses are definitely a bit more challenging, which is nice because I fully went into this game thinking i'd clear the game with ease. spirits make the combat feel unique compared to other games, giving you a very wide range of different attack you can use, and some can even be used for traversing the game easier. The game has a great sound track that matches the areas very well, and the boss fights definitely feel quite balanced, but difficult. The areas do sadly feel a bit over populated in some areas, because the enemies will kill you in 3 hits if you aren't too careful. The controls feel very tight which is nice because the bosses require some slightly tight timing. Definitely a must get game if you enjoyed hollow knight, time spinner, or any metroidvania really.

145294511.review:
This is a story about the downfall of a cursed kingdom recounted from scattered ephemera one will inevitably encounter through exploration. It is Hollow Knight, but a lot more accessible. 

After having played both games, I think I prefer Ender Lilies overall. As stated, the game is easier and more forgiving than Hollow Knight: no frustrating mechanical checks, convenient fast travel, and less punishing trial and error loops.

The story itself is archetypal and possibly confusing if you are not used to the medium/format. However, it is definitely touching and serves as a good platform to delve into deeper topics of fidelity, innocence, and legacy - to name a few. 

Definitely worth checking out =)

145277416.review: Recomendadisimo, le falta un poco al apartado sonoro por lo demas excelente.

145254734.review:
It's got a nice aesthetic, and the music is nice even if it doesn't necessarily fit with what's going on all the time. The story is alright, it doesn't really go anywhere surprising or different than what you'll expect after the first hour or two. My only real problem with the aesthetic / music is that they're very monotonous, and after a while I want to look / hear something different and the game just doesn't offer that.

My main issues, and the reasons for the negative review, are the combat and back tracking. The combat is really clunky, with most attacks feeling like they're having no impact at all and most enemy attacks land before the animation even goes off. Things like parry or skills that do similar things can sometimes result in a blocked attack that still deals damage. Your own animations cover up enemy attacks and animations, which can lead to you missing things and easily dying given how fragile you are, but overall the combat is not too hard, just again, monotonous. 

Back tracking takes a long time even with fast travel, and usually what you find is very...meh. I'd rather have more power ups be available when you get to them, but make them trickier to obtain.

Overall, it's not a bad game, but given how many well polished metroidvanias are out there, your time is better spent elsewhere.

145219585.review:
At first, I wasn't too impressed with Ender Lilies. I only noticed the things that pointed out that it was a small indie title (despite loving Hollow Knight). Things that needed a bit more polish, like the menu sound and its mastering, some animations, and the first 5 areas especially. The first zone didn't particularly grab me. The game seemed to lead me in a straight line across the map, most branching routes seemed inaccessible. But the more I played, the more I began to enjoy it. I think my mindset shifted from comparison to enjoying it for what it is. 

I got stuck a couple of times, and were mostly (if not completely) my own issue. I didn't realise I could walk up the chain for a while in the Witch's Forest. Then, I didn't search an area with water pools which ended up having the green crystal I needed to break to lead me to the swimming ability. 

The story is thin/generic but enjoyable for what it is (from what I've seen so far- In the Twin Spires at time of review). Some dialogue ties in with notes you find lying around. I like that touch and attention to detail. The art design is awesome. I love it. Clearly a strength of the developer's. 

This game is a good stopgap while waiting for Silksong.

145195954.review:
Proof that even being a bit paint-by-numbers can produce a very good result if it's done with care and effort.

You've seen it before - an indie metroidvania with:
[list]
[*] A lone child in a dark world!
[*] A fallen kingdom plagued by a curse that turned everyone into undead, monsters, and undead monsters!
[*] A ruler that made the matters worse w/r/t said plague!
[*] Tragic bosses, including one that tried to contain the calamity all by themselves!
[*] etcetera
[/list]

I might sound like I'm mocking it a bit (I am), but it's genuinely good! The controls are good, the movement upgrades allow for impressive maneuverability in the late game (and some fiendish puzzles that require those). You gain new attacks by absorbing enemy spirits a'la Aria/Dawn of Sorrow, but rather than grinding basic enemies you have to find a miniboss version. The art direction is nice, if very animesque. The animation is like if you took the skeletal animations of old Flash games (or Aquaria) and polished it to the highest degree. And it doesn't overstay it's welcome, I've managed to 100% it in the time shown above.

145189263.review:
I was recommended this game by a friend who said that "this isn't as good as Hollow Knight, but is pretty similar".
Lol
Lmfao even
This game exploits the most trivial metroidvania mechanics such as dashing and double-jumping, while the rest of the game stays terribly unpolished.
The combat is as clunky as it could be, with unreadable animations and iffy attack hitboxes that sometimes persist for longer than 1 tick while being single impact attacks, like a ground slam. The enemy placement is also bad, and you can't slash them vertically, even though there are situatioms that clearly require that.
Can't make a balanced combat? Just add a leveling system that boosts stats every time you reach a new level, all until you become a walking hazard that kills enemies by your sheer presence, as shrimple as that.
The art, the music and the atmosphere is literally the most generic Japanese crap you will see in any JRPG: a radiant being fighting eldritch evil, with medieval background that looks like it was taken from an RPG Maker asset store, accompanied by the most boring orchestral arrangement that sounds like it's royalty-free music.
It's funny how the very term "Metroidvania" stems from two Japanese games, yet modern Japanese games, like Ender Lilies or Bloodstained, fail to become decent representatives of the genre.

145132388.review: Quality metroidvania.  Lots of customization available through your choice of spirits and relics, and the movement gets pretty fun once you start acquiring new abilities.  Lots of bosses that are generally a good challenge.

145128902.review: Beautiful story. Lore were explained minimally but were clear enough to understand. Great art direction and soundtrack with smooth-sailing level design. 145127790.review:
Una grata sorpresa, es un metroidvania simple en general, exploración y combate, no hay mercadeo, no hay moneda, no hay secundarias..., pero es que es que esas dos cosas las hace muy bien. Cada área requiere un par de habilidades y artefactos equipados diferentes lo que hace que tengas que adaptarte un poco cada vez. Los jefes finales son muy divertidos, tienen tres fases y de nuevo hay que intentar tener la configuración que mejor se adapte a cada uno de ellos. En otros del género que he jugado cuando estaba cómodo con una configuración con esa iba a muerte, o si acaso una para explorar y otra para jefes, pero lo divertido de este es realmente acabas usando casi todas las cosas que vas cogiendo, y con un sentido. El combate tiene cierta exigencia, los enemigos te pueden matar en dos o tres golpes así que hay que jugar mucho con el dash, el parry y las habilidades.

Sobre la exploración, hay bastantes puntos de descanso y ninguno alejado de jefes ni cosas así para complicarte las cosas sin más. Pero lo que más me ha gustado es que en el mapa se te marcan las habitaciones con un color diferente si tienes aún cosas por descubrir, y eso a mí personalmente me ha gustado bastante. No te lo ponen fácil, hay que fijarse en paredes, hay jump puzzles, mini bosses y requiere volver cuando tienes nuevas habilidades, pero es muy gratificante después de cada jefe con una habilidad nueva irse de paseo y cómo te lo recompensa.

Otros detalles chulos el que las armas que vas cogiendo son espíritus que te acompañan y son ellos los que realmente ejecutan el ataque. Y la banda sonora.

Cosas a mejorar: la historia es la típica con bastante poco interés, la paleta de colores un poco monótona y me molestaba que ciertos eventos ([spoiler]la purificación[/spoiler]) no tuviesen efectos sonoros.

144939729.review:
This scratched so many itches,
Map design was great, interesting chose to have maps with connection points and not in a direct grid i think this paid off for making each map feel interesting and not dependent on what was adjacent; while at the same item still feeling both connected and flow from one to the next.

While overall boss fights were great, a bit more tuning needed to be done on some of the bosses, Ulv lower it a bit, Blighted Lord up it a bit, Miriel up a slight bit, Hoenir up quite a bit.

I wihs more areas had music there were places that just seemed empty due to the lack of it. but those that did it fit the theme perfectly.

I loved the map auto tracking system, without it giving it fully away, was nice to NOT need pen/paper along side my play session.

Really loved the relic system and ability to customize my play style.

Overall the game did nearly everything right, and the few things it didn't were minor and didn't detract from the overall enjoyment. 

10/10 would buy a sequel.

144899745.review:
Ah Yes, The story of a child in a torn world out to get them. The fast track acclaim a la, Limbo, Little Nightmares, Inside, Song of the deep, Shadow of the Colossus and arguably Hollow Knight. Ender Lilies catches me in the feels games have not hit for a long time.

I want to know more about the curse, the blight, that makes you immortal but causes you to rot and suffer.

I want to know more about the Knights stricken with guilt, lost to the madness. Their final thoughts and wishes on what they wished to protect and how they failed to do so.

I want to know more about the girl who can possibly bring and end to this pain. 

10 hours in these stories have been as beautiful as they are sad. The memories from the knights, the notes from the people, the small wishes you catch a glimpse of before you lay the undying to rest. It is a wonderfully crafted experience that many of the "small child, big world" simply don't match. I have gotten 1 ending so far and i can't wait to dive back in and explore more. 

This games going on the wall with Shadow of the Colossus, and Lost Odysseys One Thousand Years of Dreams (Hanas Departure). If you know what those are and loved them you owe it to yourself to get this game.

144827128.review:
The Fact of the Matta:

The visual style and soundtrack are by far the strongest parts of the entire experience, often elevating the best levels and scenes to greater heights. And will probably be what I remember this game for in years to come. The gameplay, while not without some frustrating flaws in the design and execution, is great fun and a good place to start in the metroidvania genre. The ability to create builds with up to six different attacks and skills gives the player a lot of flexibility, and options to try should they get stuck.

The story on the other hand is tragically weak, with its most impactful moments being only in the very beginning and the very end(s). The cinematics in between suffer from repeating already-known information or following a B-plot barely connected to the protagonist and her goal, and often feel like padding to fill the gaps betwen the A-plot's major moments. When finding Healing upgrades carries more emotional clout than defeating a major boss and learning their past, there's something amiss.

All that being said, the gameplay is still fun and engrossing, and the visuals and music are stellar, so it's not like it needed a perfect story to be worth anyone's time. You will still enjoy this game if metroidvanias interest you. or if you want to see the best of what this game has to offer.

143870134.review:
The Short Of It:
Game has great writing, solid mechanics, and a great sense of exploration. Definitely worth a play if you love metroidvanias.

The Long Of It:
The game's world is dark and grim, and doesn't get any brighter. You're not there to save the kingdom, you're there to either do your duty or do your duty well. It's not a game to go into to expect a happy ending, but a good and satisfying ending - and it's all the better for it.

The best way I can describe the overall feel of this game is "Weighty", be it either in the world that we're playing in or the combat. Everything has weight to it. If you chose to initiate an attack, know that you're dedicating yourself to that animation until it's done.

As such, the game is definitely more on the challenging side; but aside from a very few bizarre choices - it's extremely well balanced and fair. Just use the skills at your disposal, knowing that some are better for situations than others. That at times, it's better to experiment to find a proper strategy for what's ahead. Rather than beating your head against a wall.

If this sounds good to you, then buckle up. You're in for a hell of a ride.

This is a wonderful gem of a game with a really touching story that may not reveal itself fully right away, but if you give it time and patience and roll with what it's telling, you'll find something plenty memorable. Yes, it can be a bit of a janky game. Hell, to 100% the game you have to embrace some of the jank for some of the things they want you to do. I was quite excited to try this one, because Metroid type games are one of my favorite genres. I like how many different abilities there are to choose from. I enjoyed some of the boss fights. The unique art style was something that really caught my eye when I first heard of the game.

The biggest issue I had with the game was that it wasn’t very fun. Normally in these games the story or the idea of exploring the world keeps you playing. I never had the urge to learn more about the story or to keep exploring the world.  

The map system is not great. The map is worse than Super Metroid, a game made 30 years ago. One of the other major issues I had with the game was the leveling system. I don’t like having character levels in real-time action/RPG type games. I think these types of games should mostly be based on skill. And ideally should have difficulty options available.

I would not recommend this game for most people. As a fan of this genre, I would say this game needed a lot more polish to compete with similar types of games.

It's somewhere between great and OK, yet I recommend it for trying.

Good:

- Dark Souls-y themed metroidvania
- nice music and visuals
- a variety of spirits, items, locations

Neutral:

- bosses are fair, mostly if don't count some having one-shot attacks with very narrow evasion window, [spoiler]Julius[/spoiler] has enormous health pool, making his boss fight quite tedious.
- level number is just there, it doesn't scale any of stats and purely cosmetic (but has achievements related to it).
- informative map with showing which segment has missed collectibles and exits, yet can't put marks on it that makes backtracking more pointless and time consuming.

Bad:

- in about middle of the game it gets quite hard to understand where you have to go, like you clearly missing certain item to progress but you have no clue where to find it and map doesn't help either.
- most of collectibles require mid/late-game upgrades to collect, yet you encounter them very early in the game, there's high chance you would likely return to those places just to find out you still don't have upgrade to pickup them yet.
- almost every spirit has its own "counterpart", notes mention their relationships, yet they don't interact at all, neither when bringing them to the boss fight, neither when equipping them together, feels like it was scraped, only one that ever talks to us is Umbral Knight.
- "challenge rooms" aka (kill all enemies otherwise door won't open) don't keep progress, making you to clear them every time you pass throigh, there's not many of them, but it's just tedious during revisits.
- big horizontal and vertical barriers actually require additinal momentum, yet you may assume you need to upgrade spirit to break them (upgrades don't affect skills though).

143277281.review:
I won't beat around the bush with my recommendation: Ender Lilies is a must-play for any self-respecting fan of Metroidvanias and/or dark fantasy media. If I could hit that "Yes" button more than once, I would do it at least 10 times. I will now tell you why, in Spoiler-Free fashion.

The gameplay is very challenging in many ways, but never unfair, and especially never too punishing against player mistakes. Not losing your EXP or other resources on death and having fast travel available from very early on are two particularly big aspects that, honestly, surprised me, going in with minimal knowledge and expecting a 2D Souls-like that wouldn't show that type of mercy. The only real punishment being physical progress and, in the case of bosses, having to fight them from the beginning again, really minimizes any frustration of having to go through a longer section full of powerful enemies multiple times. All the EXP you gather stays with you, and checkpoints/shortcuts are plentiful.
The Spirit system in particular is a very nice take on equipping weapons and skills, reminding me of the Iga-vania Soul/Crystal system, but instead of relying on plain luck that a random enemy will drop the thing you need, all of your Spirits are gotten from boss fights in specific parts of the map and the Blight pieces necessary to upgrade them aren't hard to come across. With just a bit of time given to leveling up and upgrading your Spirits, you may eventually get yourself a really good party to take on most of the game with, only occasionally switching to your B set if it's safer for some situation or another, or at least that's how I approached things

The story is pretty light, which I feel just kinda comes with the territory of an extremely pretty dark fantasy Metroidvania game at this point, but if you just pick up the lore notes that are in the beaten path or in save rooms, as well as watching the bosses' memory cutscenes and going through the game, obviously, you'll get a clear enough picture of what happened to this kingdom, who all these characters were, why they did what they did and how you'll right their wrongs, but at the same time the game never spells every last thing out and leaves a handful of elements open to interpretation, and any reason to think more about a good game is welcome in my eyes.
Obviously not getting into spoilers, but it was honestly a story that made me quite emotional at multiple points, and that is certainly a very good thing.

The presentation, both audio and visual, is possibly tied with gameplay as Ender Lilies' best aspect. On a purely practical sense, the main character being a pale white in this dingy, dark world is perfect, as is every big attack being clearly telegraphed with orange flashes that are consistent enough across most enemies and bosses that if you can time one you can probably time every other. As for the plain beauty and spectacle of it? This game is an absolute FEAST of breath-taking medieval landscapes and architecture, from run down cathedrals, to bloody and broken castle halls, to a surprisingly bright and colorful sanctuary of witches (Or what remain of them, at least), every area in this game feels sufficiently unique and interesting just to look at. I feel it really says something that the developers added a "Hide UI" button to your save points, they were all but directly asking people to screenshot this game and its wonderful backgrounds and character designs.
Bosses take on grotesque powered up forms that range from a change in palette to morphing into complete abominations, with attacks that fill up the entire screen with their blood red and orange Blight, and every area and major battle is scored by some beautiful piece of music. This game has it all, with location themes being dark and somber or at the very least melancholy, and boss themes being intense orchestral pieces and tragic solo instruments that help tell their story.

My biggest critique of this game might be the map. It certainly shows the rough size of each room, and roughly where they connect to other rooms, and the squares do change color depending on if you've collected everything there or not, and it also marks rooms with save points... But that's about it. Where specifically the collectibles might be is not something you ever even unlock (or at least I'm pretty sure it isn't) to slightly help with 100% completion, you don't get to see your exact position, you don't get to see the actual shape of the room you're in, and you don't even get to place down your own in-game markers. I very much get what it's going for, being less of a clear-cut in-game guide to follow wherever you go and more of a set of hints and notes for you to look to as you explore, and it's somewhat like the old Castlevania maps that also had no color coding and minimal extrinsic pointers for where you should look for things, and while I can meet it on it's own terms I generally just prefer detailed maps over vague ones, and other people's opinions may differ in one direction or another. Although, that this is the only real issue I had with the game should speak volumes to its quality.

As I said at the top, if you're a fan of ANYTHING this game has going for it I cannot recommend it enough, at least not just in plain english. If you, like me, are always after new Metroidvanias to scratch that itch? Ender Lilies will give you the full dang Spa treatment. This game is a masterpiece, play it as soon as humanly possible.

143236804.review: One of the best modern metroidvanias out. Combines the rich combat of hollow knight with the emotional weight of Ori while having a deeply somber yet dynamic score. If you are fan of the genre you owe yourself to play this game (maybe bring some tissues).

143194452.review:
Absolutely beautiful game. If you are a metroid-vania connoisseur, you owe it to yourself to play this.
 
In an odd step, it is much more focused on tight, difficult combat, rather than smooth exploration. But it works! Extremely well in fact. There are obvious influences from FromSoft's Souls series. Boss fights are very hard, until you get the patterns down. Extremely satisfying too. When you get a bosses 'number' and dash around them like they can't land a single it, it feels great.

The scaling is well done. There are areas you technically 'shouldn't' be at, but you can still explore them if you're careful enough with combat. I think one issue I had is that [spoiler]doors opened by Faden aren't signified on the map. You should take a notepad and make sure you remember where they are.[/spoiler] I say this, because I had to figure out how to manipulate the game with certain spirit combinations to get 100%... when it was clear that, after entering the final room and obtaining the spirit of a Verbotan Champion, they gave me what was essentially a triple jump. Would have made my struggle so much easier. Still! You could say this is a testament to the game's fluidity. You CAN figure out a different path, you won't be blocked by it. In a sense it's a bit more fun that way. I had to use specific spirit combinations and very tight timing to get where I wanted to go. Woulda been so much easier with triple jump.... haha.

The visuals speak for itself, I think. The game is beautifully made. Lily and her spirits all have fantastic animations. I do think, however, that it isn't always obvious where you can go or what you can break, at the start. For example, the game never outright teaches you how to break floors that aren't marked by blight. Just gotta figure it out. And further, entering doors or other areas aren't always obvious- the map will tell you, but I think it shouldn't be necessary. There are things you would assume you can jump on, but are background pieces. Not a huge gripe, but it is to be noted.

All in all, the game is amazing! I think the fact that so many people have 100% it is proof of this fact. I kind of miss it, having finished it weeks ago.

Give it a shot. You'll likely be taken away by it's beauty and gameplay. I know I was.

143194002.review:
[h1] A melancholic story of life, death, and a ruined kingdom [/h1]
If you wish to experience a story that deviates from your typical "Monster are evil", then Ender Lilies is the one to try~
A journey through a world plagued by blights. Played by a frail young priestess accompanied by the spirit of an ancient knight~
It challenges a very opposite narrative from your typical, "Wicked boss, evil minions", or a simple "Save the world!" goals~
You're merely out to find the truth. What happened to the world when you were sleeping? You'll do what you can~
Not everything is as it seems. The blood, horror, abomination that lurks the kingdom has not always been that way~
You will find beauty in the somber atmosphere and compassion for the beast~
It emits the feeling of peaceful sorrow in your discovery. Akin to the feeling one might get when death have been accepted.

[b] Gameplay [/b]
The gameplay style is reminisce of hollow knight with it's feather-weight motion, smooth flow~
Yet the difficulty is very souls-like. Not too hard, but just the right amount of challenge in the right place~ 
Defeat is not a punishment. There is no "Game over", no item drops. You'll merely "wake up" in the closest resting spot, ready to continue~
The layout of the world is very much metroidvania. And as such, fast traveling is an option~
The map is one to be appreciated. Each is separate by blocks of interconnecting lines to indicate different layout. It starts as blue, then turned yellow when all possible collectible have been found for that specific room. That alone helps getting 100% achievement in the game, a breeze~ 

[b] Level-up Progression [/b]
You'll encounter "Spirits" to help you throughout your journey. Should you choose to search for them and "help" them~
They're mostly separated into main attacks, and skills. One being unlimited usage, and the latter having rechargeable usage limit~
I will warn, that the resource required to upgrade your spirits is limited. It's not possible to get full upgrade of every spirits, so try out the one that fits your playstyle, and focus on those~

[b] Scenery [/b]
The environment is very somberly serene. The environment tells as much story as the collectible lore scattered around the place. Take your time whenever possible to soak up the art in the bg~
The music is beautifully composed by MILI. Environmental OST accompanied with vocal is quite rare, even more so that fits so well as bg music. And the ending music is the perfect finale to wrap up the emotion portrayed in the game~

[h1] In my hunger for Silk Song I found Ender Lilies and I am so glad I did. [/h1]

Ender Lilies I feel is a great metroidvania with many amazing parts. 

Lily is adorable, the enemies are grotesquely stunning, and the backgrounds are beautiful.

The story is pieced together through fragments, pages, letters, and boss's memories as you beat them. It is nothing groundbreaking, but I enjoyed the sorrowful tale of this decayed world.

Combat and bosses are difficult but fair, learning the patterns of bosses felt rewarding! (There are also saves right before a boss which is [i]so[/i] appreciated) 
 
Exploration did get a liiiitle tedious as everytime I got a new ability I would try to get everything I couldn't beforehand (but this may be a me problem) but in the end game I feel like getting everything is very rewarding and in my opinion worth it. 
I did get 100% but it certainty took a good chunk of my play time. The great thing is that the game shows you when there is something still available on the map.
However I will note I felt like some skills were way too late game [spoiler] There are 2 skills that are needed to gain access to some of the final items but being unable to get those items was making me crazy because you can [i]almost[/i] get a lot of them [/spoiler] 

One thing I will note is that I felt like there could have been more platforming puzzles, perhaps this comes from my Hollow Knight experience but I did feel like there were only 2 or 3 of them and I wanted more.

Overall I am very happy I played Ender Lilies and hope you enjoy it if you get it too :))

142742336.review:
Really got the hollow knight vibe from this one (that's a positive)

-Gameplay : the combat is really smooth, you can give yourself a challenge but also make the bosses easy if you equip the right things (the power-ups can really change how you play), there's no hard platforming sections. I liked the implementation of some rpg mechanics (when you kill ennemies you get exp which increase your base damage). If you're a completionist this one is really easy : the map indicate if you've found everything in a given area.

-Story : It has your typical post-apocalyptic/doomed world with clues from item description like your average souls game, but : this game tells a story that is easy to understand and that doesn't leave you wondering what happened and I really liked that.

-Graphics : They are good, at first I thought I wouldn't like the art style but I think it has been really well done, still I find some npc models to be a little weird. A major complaint is that I really wish that the cutscenes were actual cutscenes and not just images, but it doesn't deteriorate the experience.

-Music : It's really beautiful : there's one for an area with a woman humming that I really liked and one for a boss that was a absolutely beautiful violon solo. Those are just two that I loved.

In conclusion : 9.0/10, I wish it were longer.

It's fairly hard until you learn each boss pattern, you will also die quite quickly while each boss can take a heavy beating so can't just rush them thus you actually need to learn how to read each one and know when it's time to dodge or attack.

Nearly all attack tells are well telegraphed, some added attacks you will have to learn from fighting (Mage boss 3:rd phase teleports after certain attacks, you won't know of it until it hits you a few times) you will likely die quite a few times on each boss until you learn what each phase does as some attacks can only be dodged in certain positions -> if you don't know you likely die from it (Knight boss covers the screen, can't jump over or dodge, need to be behind him to avoid it)

There are some points i personally don't like but nothing that would affect the majority of people (It really likes to Cut to a stark white screen, have photofobia so quite painful but it only happens during cutscenes and purification so learned when they happen and can turn away.)

142672119.review:
This is a borderline review.  This game isn't bad, but it's also not really that good.  This is an ungraceful interpretation of the action platformer genre - It's riffing off games that are executing its ideas way better, but it's also fairly competent in its own right.  At the end though, it's highlights don't make up for its many faults.  I played up through the 'bad' ending, though it's unlikely I'll revisit it.

The theme here is 'Clumsy'.

Starting with its strengths:

[b]Art, Animation and Presentation[/b]

The assets here are well done.  The 'hand painted' aesthetic is executed well, and the background art is a major strength of the presentation.  The music is above average, with a couple banger tracks mixed in.  The bright and colorful particles effects scattered throughout work as an effective contrast to the otherwise matte tone of the game.  A lot of this works very well and it seems obvious this was a game whose foundation started in 'art'.

Less impressive is the actual animation work, which tends to be very rigid and more haphazard.  Some of the animation work is clearly in service of the art first and the gameplay second; the swing lines don't always match up with hitboxes, etc.  It's not 'bad', but it's an obvious outlier against the assets themselves.

Animations also fail to sell impact and force very well.  This is also partially a problem with audio design, but these things need to work together to more effectively sell momentum and weight.  This game struggles with this a lot.

Contrast is occasionally a problem, where reading what's happening becomes difficult.  Using the Orange Glow as a universal previs mitigated this problem A LOT - well done to whoever made that call - but the problem is not completely remedied due to the relative noisiness of the assets and animation at times.

[b]Building a World[/b]

The storytelling here is among the places where larger cracks start to form.  I understand folks want to define their world and show it to you, but how much you do this with words needs to be very carefully considered.  There is a sequence where an NPC forces dialog on you, then you pick up a note, then 3 ft later more dialog is forced on you.  This is bad world building - I want to hit shit and you just delivered 3 chunks of exposition with a second of game play in-between them.  This is part of that 'Clumsy™' that is ever-present here.

I want to draw a comparison to Hollow Knight here, which uses exploration and its environment to tell an effective story.  There are a few 'tablets' in the world, and all but a half dozen NPCs who will spew dialog at you, but even with what is but a couple hundred lines of text, it has created a compelling, haunting and deeply engaging world.  Opening the Abyss in Hollow Knight and getting to the bottom is so much more powerful than reading a note you picked up describing it.

[b]Combat Systems - Confused Design[/b]

The core combat systems are where the Clumsy™ comes to a peak.  This is a 2D action platformer with combat to match - that is to say the majority of the technical elements are expressed by how you move and position yourself ((e.g., SotN, Hollow Knight, etc.) as opposed to how you explicitly respond with your toolkit (Soulslike, DMC).  Moving around the Y-axis is a big part of both how you traverse the world, and you how engage enemies.  In fact, many enemies are actually flying and are inviting you to do combat in the air.

Despite this being the framework being clearly setup here, you have no access to attacks to strike above or below you.  Your default attack can only strike roughly in front of you and while it has a generous hitbox, it's not an adequate substitute for matching your scenario design with a player kit that matches.  Again, it's hard not to draw comparisons to Hollow Knight here, but you can also look at a game like Symphony of the Knight - a game that also lacks a lot of vertical attacking options - but the difference here is the vast, vast majority of enemies are grounded.  SotN's player kit is paired well with its scenarios.  The same cannot be said about Ender Lilies.

Because of this, combat on sloped terrain is difficult - you can easily swing right over monsters you are right next to on a downhill slope, and you just have to understand to not engage here or to use an extra attack

--

This game also features a leveling system.  Levels just translate to damage, and so you can convert Time into Player Power which is...not great, but enemies of the same type actually start getting more HP as you advance in the game.  Providing 'Avatar Power' to player via levels is a choice, but to nullifying it by just scaling enemies up with more HP and more damage as you get more HP and more damage is asinine.  This isn't even serving the purpose of having a level system at this point.

[b]Scenarios - Bosses[/b]

Bosses are actually a highlight and are generally fun to learn.  They were definitely my favorite part of the game and the feeling of progressing with each attempt was great!  They had generally interesting designs and felt fair and fun.  It is a major strength of this game and probably the tightest aspect of its gameplay.

[b]Scenarios - Everything else[/b]

The same cannot be said for the world you traverse.

Many enemies in the world are both designed and placed haphazardly.  The level design is not in agreement with the enemy design in ways that allow the player to feel like they are just cheating the entire way through.  For example, attacking enemies from below is a powerful option and enemies frequently have no way to respond to this, making this a risk-free option for players.  Since many places are laid out with several layers of thin floors, this isn't a strategy you can employ on a handful of enemies - this is a strategy that is ever-present and frequently available to players.  Whole scenarios are just compromised by allowing the player to hit mobs through walls and floors while they just stand there.

Another example:  There is a mob that disappears and reappears behind you before taking a swing.  Instead of fighting them, just find an edge and face the mob.  When they disappear and reappears, they will just reappear on nothing and fall to their deaths.  This particular moment is one where you get to feel clever as a player, but these kinds of issues are so omnipresent in the game that I'm not convinced this was really a designed solution.

There are also several monsters that fall apart to certain Spirits (spells).  Ranged attacks are readily available and trivialize a non-trivial portion of the world scenarios.  Some allow you to *really* cheat the system and swing several feet through walls and floors.

Again, this is part of the very Clumsy™ implementation of scenarios in the game.  At its best you feel clever - like you solved a puzzle, but at worst, this ends up being tedious as you spot more and more cracks in the rules of the game.

[b]It could be better.[/b]

There are a lot of strong Metroidvanias these days, and many of them with a focus on technical combat.  If this was released 10 years ago, I think I would have a lot of great things to say about it but the bar is a lot higher today then it was then.  A lot of the problems on display here were acknowledged and solved long before this game came out.  It's worth saying that none of these problems are necessarily a deal killer per say, but the sum of the problems are a lot to get over if you notice these kinds of things.

There are too many issues that have been adequately understood and addressed by other games for me to ignore.  The strength of it's boss fights and (most of) it's art direction is not enough to overcome the misses on combat design and world scenarios.  The game isn't overtly bad, but it sure is Clumsy.

If you are looking for combat-focused Metroidvania to play, then you could do a lot worse then Ender Lilies...but you could do a lot better too.

142508726.review:
Incredible. 

In modern gaming, a good Metroidvania is often really hard to come by. This one took its role seriously. 

=== PROS ===
+ Graphics are clean and just the right touch of foreboding and eerie
+ Controls are instant and feel really smooth and well thought out (played with controller only)
+ Sound effects are top-notch, with every damage dealt and taken feeling like it has a real impact
+ OST is one of the best I've ever heard. In my opinion, only beaten by FTL's OST
+ Difficulty scales really well, maintaining a constant challenge throughout, while leaving past areas easier
+ Storytelling is out of this world. The simple cutscenes do their job and the scattered notes tell a vibrant and rich story
+ Hidden objects kept me scouring every wall for secret rooms and hidden items and lore
+ Frustratingly, the game always made it feel like it was my fault when I died to a boss... which it absolutely was, never once did I blame the game for something, it was always me who needed to improve.

=== CONS ===
- Hitboxes make jumping puzzles rough at times
- Beautiful music made me cry

=== Conclusion ===
Metroidvania fan? [b]BUY[/b]
Platformers with secrets fan? [b]BUY[/b]
Need to kill 20 hours and enjoy every challenging minute of it? [b]BUY[/b]

Seriously, this game kept me going and wanting to come back to it every free moment I had from work. It was an absolute joy to play and I will be keeping my eye out to these developers for more hits like this in the future.

142280774.review:
[h1]A hauntingly beautiful-in-motion Metroidvania seeped in death.[/h1]

With its gothic aesthetic and challenging gameplay, calling Dark Souls a 3D homage to classic Castlevania isn’t that far fetched of a comparison. This may be partially responsible for why there are a few games in existence that had to have been concocted when the developers had a conversation along the lines of let’s make our own version of Dark Souls, but as a 2D metroidvania (Blasphemous and Salt & Sanctuary immediately come to mind). Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights would also be a game that could have been born from such a statement. Ender Lilies follows many of the familiar mainstays of the genre, but also doesn’t want to make it too easy for players to conquer the game.

Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights begins as a priestess named Lily wakes up in the cellar of a church. She has no memory of life before and it appears she’s the only survivor, at least with her humanity intact. The kingdom of Land’s End is in ruins as a cursed Rain of Death has transformed all people and animals into monsters who will henceforth be referred to as the blighted. Lily is defenseless and rightfully scared as she has no idea what sort of calamity has befallen her homeland. Luckily for her the Umbral Knight appears at the place of her awakening, an immortal guardian who will give his sword as Lily travels the twisted remnants of kingdom.

Lily is not a trained fighter. She’s completely defenseless and at the mercy of the blighted. The Umbral Knight is effectively her weapon, as his spectral form will appear to cut down the blighted whenever the player presses the attack button. Lily’s “weapons” come from other spirits she collects on her journey from purifying powerful blighted creatures, oftentimes the corrupted bodies of people that were important in Land’s End or former friends prior to the Rain of Death.

While thrust into a savior role, Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights doesn’t simply make a presumably pacifist priestess Rambo when she wakes up and sees the destruction that has befallen her world. Her weapons that she collects are literally the spirits of the purified of blight lending their aid to her. The Umbral Knight, when assigned to one of the three spirit slots, will appear to swing his sword at the press of the attack button. Other souls lend their power in less violent ways but provide a means of traversal, such as navigating underwater or do a horizontal lunge midair. It wouldn’t be a metroidvania if the player didn’t encounter out of reach areas or treasures and had to backtrack after getting a special ability. Other aid may come in the form of an avian familiar that spits fireballs or casting a cloud of poison gas. The spirits that aid Lily serve different functions much as different types of souls may serve as subweapons in some other metroidvanias.

The story is naturally integral to Ender Lilies but the storytelling approach is minimal, especially by RPG standards. There are a few cutscenes where the Umbral Knight or other spirits of Land’s End may fill Lily in on some of the events of the world, but these are few and far between. Most of the story and history of events is gradually revealed as Lily finds notes scattered throughout her travels. This approach works well for Ender Lilies. The lore is interesting enough where I wanted to learn what happens, but gradually revealing it this way keeps the interest level throughout the game and doesn’t break up the action or exploration.

As stated earlier, Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights draws influence from Dark Souls and as such players can expect there to be a hefty amount of difficulty. In actuality, Ender Lilies is a challenging but to say it’s as difficult as Dark Souls may be overselling it. Most regular enemies can kill Lilly in three or four hits and most bosses will probably take a few attempts to beat. The challenge is rather high but never feels insurmountable. Castlevania: Order of Ecclesia is a good reference for difficulty. Figuring out enemy patterns and how to optimally juggle the different spirits will play a large part in a player’s success. Lilly can also partially restore her health three times between rest points through prayer, mucg like the Estus Flasks in Dark Souls. Prayer does require a few seconds of stationary concentration to work and Lilly is vulnerable to damage during prayer. The map squares don’t do much to tell the player about the layout of each individual map section. Finding all the hidden treasures, power ups and notes does require a lot of exploration to find where every little thing is stashed. The map makes this easier by color coding whether the player has found everything in a particular section.

Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights is an atmospheric work of art. The fluid animation and art direction make the ruined world a thing of beauty in its desolation. The artists have taken the humans and animals of Land’s End and twisted them into horrific-looking abominations. Something that’s a nice touch in the animation that ties into Lily not being a warrior is when she summons her spirits to fight for her, her animation has her cowering or recoiling in fear, which is a small detail but it does a lot to convey the terror in this terrible world where she has awakened. The soundtrack is a thing of haunting, minimalist and melancholy it’s the perfect audio accompaniment to the Ender Lilies’ visual style. Oddly enough, the score has a relaxing quality to it, which may have been an intentional choice by the developers to help keep players calm during the more difficult sections. During the review I found myself prolonging my time in certain areas due to being enthralled with the music. The difficulty is tempered with the dodge mechanic that’s rather forgiving when it comes to avoiding attacks, as does the rather frequent checkpoints. The game mechanics are smooth, and juggling the different attacks among the two loadouts is limited by player skill and not by faulty game design. Frankly, this could be my favorite metroidvania that wasn’t made with Iga’s involvement.

Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights is a fantastic metroidvania. It doesn’t do anything to revolutionize the genre, but it does excel at creating at creating a memorable experience that follows the familiar metroidvania template while still being unique. The visual style and amazing soundtrack complement each other well, creating a sense of tranquility in a desolate and horrific world. The challenge hits that sweet spot where the difficulty is high but victory is never out of reach, learning the enemy behaviors and getting an understanding of the collected abilities will allows players who persist to see the story to its end. Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights is a must play for fans of the genre as it’s simply one of the best metroidvanias ever developed.

142204387.review:
Ender Lillies is a nice little Metroidvania style game with a pretty aesthetic, and interesting story which is discovered and completed by exploration, rather than spoon-fed. The gameplay is somewhat typical of what one should expect from these 2D platformer games, but with some interesting twists which keep it enjoyable. Personally, I did not find it very difficult, and combat is relatively straightforward, especially compared to other well known games of the same style, e.g. Hollow Knight. Exploration is rewarding, and some manoeuvring challenges are indeed challenging, but mostly doable (with the right items). 

Length wise, it is a relatively short game, taking me 20 hours for complete exploration and collection of every item in the game. The soundtrack has been praised as notable, and it is nice, though somewhat repetitive. Aside from obtaining an alternate ending, I do not think it has much replayability; a thorough completion on the first run through essentially allows you to have all play styles, experiencing with various abilities and items. Overall, a nice game to buy when on sale, or full price if you really have that Metroidvania, Hollow Knight style itch.

Ender Lilies es un metroidvania que cumple con lo que se le pide sin aportar nada demasiado especial. El combate está bien, ágil y dinámico, con una cantidad razonable de variedad de enemigos. Además tienes un buen número de habilidades de combate disponibles de modo que puedes personalizar bastante tu estilo para estar cómodo, aunque con lo caro que es subirlas al final acabarás normalmente centrándote en unas pocas. Fuera de eso y las reliquias que encuentras y permiten personalizar un poco más las builds, la progresión no va más allá, ya que la subida de niveles es simplemente mejores stats y no se nota demasiado. El plataformeo cumple bien, sus secretos tiene por ahí escondidos por si quieres rebuscar en el mapa, aunque hablando del mismo para mi gusto es un poco flojo como mapa y no todo lo útil que podría o debería ser. La historia es básica y simplona, demasiado para mi gusto.

Gráficamente el juego está bien, un poco Dark Souls con algún toque mono aquí y allá. La música cumple para acompañar, aunque me falta un poco de música más épica para los bosses. Los efectos de sonido cumplen aunque no hay voces. Y, al menos en mi experiencia jugándolo, no me he encontrado ningún bug.

Por todo ello, es un metroidvania decente para los que nos gusta el género. No inventa nada pero funciona. Un 6,5.

142043066.review:
Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights is a mesmerizing gaming experience that weaves together an enchanting tale with remarkable gameplay elements. The soundtrack of Ender Lilies is incredible. Every note resonates with emotion, 
transporting players into a world where haunting melodies blend seamlessly with the game's hauntingly beautiful visuals. 

The narrative of Ender Lilies is a work of art, crafting a melancholic and thought-provoking story that unfolds gradually as you progress through the game. It delicately balances moments of darkness and despair with glimmers of hope, keeping you engaged and eager to uncover the mysteries that lie within this hauntingly atmospheric world.

The main boss encounters are absolutely amazing, presenting formidable opponents that test your skill and leave you with an adrenaline rush when you overcome them, making each victory a triumph to savor.

Moreover, Ender Lilies effortlessly strikes a balance between accessibility and depth. The controls are intuitive, allowing players of all skill levels to dive right into the action without feeling overwhelmed. Yet, beneath its accessible surface lies a depth that unfolds gradually, providing a rewarding experience for those who seek to uncover its hidden secrets.

In conclusion, Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights is a breathtaking journey that captivates with its enchanting soundtrack, beautiful storytelling, and thrilling boss battles. Its accessibility and depth make it a game that anyone can enjoy, while its haunting atmosphere will leave a lasting impression. Whoever you are, step into this mesmerizing world and prepare to be enthralled.

142038372.review:
This game really has a special charm to it. I may be biased saying though because I have played similar games like Hollow Knight in the difficult 2D platformer department, this feels like a good stepping stone to playing those types of games as it's difficulty compared to the others is a tad easier. You still have to get used to a lot of deaths throughout the game and understand the gimmicks of the boss fights in particular, but I found it not that hard. The different spirits you acquire throughout the game allows for a lot of possibilities and approaches on how you want to deal with different bosses and enemies in the game.

The graphics with particularly the lake backgrounds and the characters are really nice, and Mili's contribution to the soundtrack really make the experience unique: Everything associated with the lake and forest-esque levels especially were highlights. I love how the story had went too as you progressed through the game.

The inclusion of the map highlighting if you found all the collectables was a nice touch as well because it can be tedious if backtracking to ensure you found every nook and cranny per area if the map didn't feature this.

Probably the only drawback I have for the game is the "shield" gimmick for the enemies that "break" them and leave them vulnerable for a short time; the major bosses are fine, but I found mini-bosses and some of the common mobs recover in less than a second, so you're not really left with a proper opening if you took the time to break their "shield" HP.

Ender Lilies was definitely an enjoyable experience, and I hope to see more from the developers in the future :)

141881505.review:
I don't typically like 2D side-scrolling platformer RPGs but this one grew on me. 

Gameplay
The gameplay is simple yet makes the game just hard enough. The world is expansive and separated by levels and small sections. You aren't told where to go but the map does let you know where you haven't been, it just won't show areas you haven't been to yet.Combat feels a bit souls-like to me personally, but is still easy enough to learn; though, hard to master.

Soundtrack
My favorite part of the game is the soundtrack, it captures the dark fantasy world setting extremely well and gives every area a unique feeling. Some parts are uplifting, some depressing, and other parts relaxing.

Artstyle
It's beautiful. It pairs with the soundtrack, gameplay, and world setting very well to immerse you into the world and its story. 

I 100% recommend playing this game, even if you're not much of a fan of these types of games.

141877015.review: In a sea of a massive amount of metroidvania types, Ender Lillies truly sticks out as a shining example of what the genre can achieve. The artstyle immediately immerses you into its dark gritty world where the only light that can be found is that that's emmitted from Lily herself, a light that with progress gets progressively dimmer. Every area has a distinct set of music to accompany it to really distinguish it from the other areas in the game. On the topic of the soundtrack the music for the games bosses is downright amazing and really adds more to the fight as it reflects the story of the boss in question. The options you have for combos with your spirits makes it so you can bully bosses at a distance with range spam or get right in their face with close range brawlers. Overall if you're a fan of metroidvanias and haven't tried Ender Lillies you're just missing out
