-- BREVE PREMESSA :) --
Consiglio vivamente di giocarci, o almeno di dargli una possibilità. 

-- RECENSIONE --
Le ambientazioni sono stupende e riescono a tenerti attaccato allo schermo sopratutto certe zone ti lasciano a bocca aperta. Il gioco non è molto difficile se vogliamo prendere come esempio altri giochi simili, volendo, al termine della nostra avventura si ha la possibilità
di godere della modalità sfida per le persone in cerca di avversità. Sulla storia che caratterizza l'obbiettivo e la nostra avventura non abbiate aspettative di un gioco AAA, comunque è davvero ( mio parere personale ) ben strutturato, in giro per la mappa troverete delle note che vi aiuteranno a capire meglio la storia che circonda i luoghi, la storia di certi personaggi e anche a capire meglio le avversità che i boss del gioco hanno dovuto passare, questo accompagnato anche dai loro ricordi.

Se avete giocato a qualsiasi metroidvania, ve lo consiglio, se ci giocate con interesse e cercate di seguire bene la storia non ne rimarrete delusi. Contate che per finire il gioco e sbloccare tutti gli achievment ci ho messo più o meno 24 ore, non dura neanche tanto.

141690438.review:
I played Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights, and let me tell you, it's a solid Metroidvania experience. The sprawling labyrinth to explore, acquiring new abilities, leveling up, and finding secrets are all present and accounted for. But what sets it apart is the challenging yet enjoyable combat and the plethora of secrets to uncover.

In the game, I control Lily, a young priestess in a world ravaged by a devastating rain that turned people into undead creatures. Fortunately, Lily has the power to cleanse them, but she's not much of a fighter. That's where the Umbral Knight comes in, serving as Lily's sword and guide. I found the combat satisfying, especially when unleashing combos and upgrading the Knight's moves.

Boss battles were a highlight, and defeating them granted Lily new abilities to access new areas. The game doesn't shy away from difficulty, and I had to be on my toes to survive. Experimenting with different attacks and strategies was key to success, and I enjoyed finding powerful new abilities that turned the tide in battles.

The map is expansive and divided into visually distinct biomes, each with its own music that sets the mood. Exploring these areas and uncovering secrets was a delight, though some items were a bit too well-hidden for my liking. Still, the game's color-coded map helped track progress.

Ender Lilies doesn't reinvent the wheel, but it's a well-crafted experience. The presentation is top-notch, the combat is rewarding, and the gothic world and lore are captivating. It's a meat and potatoes Metroidvania that showcases the value of executing a familiar formula with excellence. I had a great time investing over two dozen hours into this adventure.

141545939.review:
On a look at this game you can get a bit of an immediate grasp at what awaits you. Dark-fantasy metroidvania, a dark and blighted world in which you must maneuver through and help restore; you control a young girl, the white priestess Lily, essentially the beacon of hope and under the protection of the Umbral Knight, you embark. 

The game's thematic exposition is done well and of which may even go hand-in-hand with the gameplay elements. The character you play is Lily, not the spirits, and you command their offensive actions as Lily, so the gameplay is summoner-like; in the beginning all you can do as her is just move and dive around to evade the enemy while you exploit moments of vulnerability with attacks by your spirits. You begin with the Umbral Knight as your only ally at the start and awoken with you, and so your main attack is the basic sword strikes he provides. Basic doesn't mean bad though, he's your bread-and-butter method of attack and thus the main way to "defend" Lily on your journey onward, and what else can I say? It's an endearing theme that the deathless knight spirit is there to take care of the young girl. The game in general is about watching your movement to avoid damage and strike first or back, enemies will hit hard.

With the blight having affected the world, the only "life" you encounter are blighted enemies, so in your journey to purify the blight, you'll also encounter enemies to purify; minibosses of each enemy type and bosses will be fought, and on defeat, you'll purify them to finally grant them a release. Upon purification, an aspect of the progression system gets visibly employed as this is how you attain blighted spirits to fight for you. There is a levelling system, and the mooks you fight do boost that, so that is the other aspect. The third is collecting blighted souls; this is a "currency" you use to enhance your spirits, most often in large sum from extant corpses of blighted. You'll notice that on Lily's journey is a lot of collection and purification of blighted souls thus. It's a good and fulfilling progression system that ties in very well with how the story handles itself. 

Whenever you come across bosses, sometimes they have a brief verbal introduction, but they do always have some final lamenting words on defeat with a cinematic into their memories on their purification. Minibosses have final words too, so it's endearing to eventually acquire these spirits as they're not only your weapons, you do feel them to travel with you as not only do they literally do in their light form, they visually appear when you idle or are at a respite too, so they are able to help you in your journey despite their regrettable ends as having been blighted, though perhaps this is how they can make things better. As maybe one of their ways of thanks, defeating bosses and acquiring their spirits does enhance your abilities to fight, move and break certain walls to explore the map further. 

Sometimes you get specks of speech from blighted corpses that offer souls as enhancing currency. This, along with the superb visuals of the game and the notes you find along the way are all the ways the game develops its lore and context, and it's done incredibly well; it's non-linear and the exposition is in various places as you go along the game, so it doesn't draw you in super-fast immediately, but as you go along and piece things together, it becomes fulfilling to get what's going on and why. These bosses, these characters, they're all unique not just in how they look with the thanks of the stunning art but as well as what glimpses of their circumstances you see of them. 

The music is no lacking performer either, it's great and an important factor into how one experiences the game with its scenic dreariness, and I have to commend that it managed to give me chills and confuse me for an enemy lurking in the end-game area.

The rest is best explored and experienced. It's a great game, and a great explorative experience as a dark-fantasy metroidvania. There is difficulty, but it is fun to overcome the challenge with proper movement, combat and progression, and yet it's all thoughtfully done with regards to the setting of the game you're in, and with overcoming such tribulation lets you grant Lily hopefully the best end for all. I bought it on a whim to play on my deck and seemed to have 100%'d it in 9 days, one of the first games I've decided to 100% in a long while so you can take that as you will. It's a strong recommend for anyone who likes metroidvania games with dark-fantasy settings and the endearing aspects of having to help escort a vulnerable protagonist to restore a given-up-on world.

141523923.review:
Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights is a visually stunning and atmospheric game that offers a unique experience in the genre. With its captivating art style and haunting ambiance, it immediately immerses players in a visually mesmerizing world. The melancholic tone set by the soundtrack enhances the overall experience, reminiscent of the beloved NieR series.

In terms of gameplay, Ender Lilies adheres to genre conventions while introducing distinct mechanics. Combat requires precise timing, evasions, and strategic use of spirits obtained throughout the game. The Umbral Knight, the default and most frequently used spirit, serves as the foundation of combat, delivering reliable and efficient slashes. However, the combat lacks depth in terms of combo variation and creativity, potentially leading to repetitive encounters. Although visually impressive, boss fights may not pose a significant challenge to experienced players due to limited patterns and obvious telegraphs.

Exploration plays a significant role in the game, with backtracking and discovering new paths as key components of the Metroidvania experience. The rewards for exploration, such as new spirits and items, are well-placed and provide a satisfying sense of accomplishment. The meticulously designed world, from haunting forests to defiled castles, showcases the developers' efforts in creating an enchanting and visually stunning aesthetic.

Despite these strengths, Ender Lilies falls short in terms of narrative development. The story is delivered lightly through scattered diary entries and boss monologues, lacking a cohesive and engaging overarching narrative. This may leave players longing for more depth and connection between the individual tales.

Overall, Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights shines as a visually stunning and atmospheric game that offers a unique take on the genre. While the combat could benefit from more variety and depth, the immersive world, rewarding exploration, and captivating art style make it a standout experience for action-loving fans.

141450093.review:
ENDER LILIES: Quietus of the Knights is the best 2D side-view action-RPG I can recommend to absolutely everyone. 

One of the main features of the game is its visual style. Ender Lilies is a dark and dystopian fantasy universe filled with various monsters and dangers. The graphics is made in a drawn style, that gives a special charm and uniqueness to the game.

The soundtrack in Ender Lilies is one of its strong points. The music in the game creates the atmosphere of mystery, gloom and emotionality, combining perfectly with the visual style and the plot of the game.
The soundtrack consists of original compositions that perfectly convey the mood of each location and event in the game. The music tracks can be dark and intimidating during boss battles, as well as melodic and emotional during exploration and encounters with other characters.
The compositions in Ender Lilies often use orchestral instruments such as strings, brass and percussion to create a deep and epic sound experience. Some tracks also contain choral arrangements that add an extra layer of emotion and drama.
The musical compositions help immerse players in the game world and enhance the emotional experience.
Overall, the soundtrack in Ender Lilies is the most important element of the game that adds depth and emotionality to the game experience. It blends perfectly with the visual style and gameplay, making the game even more immersive and appealing to players.

The gameplay and story in Ender Lilies is noteworthy. Players take on the role of Lily, the last surviving priestess, who travels through the ruined kingdom, battling cursed creatures and freeing their souls. During her journey, Lily meets various characters, each with their own story and helping her on her quest. She also encounters powerful bosses, which are key obstacles on her path to saving the world (the bosses in this game are quite difficult). The plot of Ender Lilies explores themes of loss, loneliness, hope, and redemption. The player will have to uncover the secrets of the past and make difficult decisions that will affect the outcome and finale of the game.
The main gameplay feature is that Lily is unable to fight on her own, but can summon and control the souls of defeated enemies. Each soul has unique abilities and combat styles, allowing players to create a variety of combo attacks and strategies.

Additionally, Ender Lilies offers a variety of locations to explore, including dangerous dungeons, abandoned castles, and gloomy forests. In each area, players will encounter a variety of bosses that present a real challenge and require good strategy and skill.

Overall, Ender Lilies is an engaging game with an appealing visual style, engaging gameplay, exciting atmosphere and music. It promises to deliver a lot of fun to players who love metroidvania and want to immerse themselves in a dark and mysterious world.

Perhaps the review will be supplemented, most likely I will write more about the bosses in the course of further passing of the game.

My evaluation of this beautiful game is 10/10.

141439654.review:
I find myself deeply immersed in the ethereal realms of “Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights” for an uninterrupted span of four hours, and it is with unabashed ardor that I express my utter infatuation with this exquisite work of interactive art. From the moment my fingers first graced the controller, I was immediately ensnared by the enchanting narrative tapestry, the resplendent animations that unfolded before my eyes, the entrancing melodies that danced upon my ears, and the overall captivating ambiance that exudes from every pore of this masterpiece.

What distinguishes Ender Lilies from its brethren in the realm of Souls-like games is its benevolence, its graceful proclivity to abstain from relentless punishment and instead bestow upon the player a sense of agency and progression devoid of overwhelming tribulations. As an ardent admirer of this genre, I am profoundly grateful for the game's judicious equilibrium between challenge and accessibility, an equilibrium that perpetually captivates my senses and propels me forward with unyielding determination.

One facet of Ender Lilies that notably elevates the immersive gameplay experience lies in the capacity to acquire and employ the services of other valiant Knights or ethereal spirits as steadfast companions throughout the unfolding odyssey. Their invaluable presence not only imparts profound depth to the intricate tapestry of combat but also engenders a palpable sense of camaraderie and unwavering support, an amalgamation of sentiments that resonate with a resounding sense of fulfillment within the recesses of my being.

However, I daresay there exist a couple of minutiae that could potentially benefit from refinement. The animation depicting Lily's evasive drop roll maneuver, though meritorious in its intention, regrettably manifests as an incongruous semblance of a floor-bound jump rather than a seamless and fluid rolling motion. While this peculiarity bears minimal consequence on the gameplay itself, it does somewhat diminish the overall polish that otherwise pervades this opus.

Furthermore, a discerning eye may discern that bolstering one's vitality through the customary process of leveling up does not, in this particular instance, augment one's hit points directly. Instead, the fortification of one's constitution materializes through the unearthing and assimilation of disparate relics, a paradigm which, upon reflection, proves to be a negligible drawback when one considers the multifaceted strategic implications and personalized customization that it engenders.

Notwithstanding these trifling reservations, it becomes indubitably evident that Ender Lilies stands resolute in its pursuit of unrivaled excellence. Its bewitching narrative tapestry, adorned with strokes of intrigue, harmonizes seamlessly with its resplendent artistic manifestation and its sonorous symphony, captivating all senses with its intoxicating allure. This captivating experience has enraptured my very essence, etching an indelible mark upon the core of my being. With utmost confidence, I proclaim that Ender Lilies has eternally inscribed itself upon the sacred annals of my heart, forever a testament to its unparalleled grandeur and artistic prowess.

[h1](4/10) LA DECEPCIÓN DE LOS METROIDVANIAS.[/h1]
[b]Jugar esto luego de Hollow Knight, Metroids y Castlevanias es vomitivo.[/b]
[list]
    [*]No vale la pena hacerle una reseña extensa, me limitaré a nombrar varios de los apartados que conforman este juego y explicar por qué Ender Lilies me parece una gran decepción.
[/list]

[hr][/hr]

[h1]Lo reembolsé por lo siguiente:[/h1]

[list]
   [*][u][b]Combate tosco:[/b][/u] 
Lento, malos controles, las habilidades tienen usos limitados, muchas se parecen entre sí. Pero, [b]HABILIDADES CON USOS LIMITADOS?????[/b] 
   [*][u][b]Movimiento tosco:[/b][/u] 
Malas animaciones sumadas a poca movilidad. Además de un escenario que poco incentiva a la exploración y que poco esconde. Sin contar el pobre plataformeo que ofrece.
   [*][u][b]Mapas mal conectados:[/b][/u] 
Literal el minimapa no coincide con las salas, además de que su diseño y comunicación visual es paupérrima.
   [*][u][b]Historia contada a medias tintas:[/b][/u] 
Apenas se dan detalles, pasas por 15 salas antes de saber un mínimo de información. Es decir, el progreso a nivel de gameplay no es compensado con progreso en la trama como pasa en cualquier juego decente.
   [*][u][b]Mal apartado sonoro:[/b][/u] 
Los personajes hablan sin emitir sonido alguno, ni siquiera emiten ruido como para tener un feedback, a lo Zelda, directamente hay SILENCIO, arruinando momentos que podrían estar bien. Los sonidos de las armas y habilidades son de mala calidad y genéricos. Literalmente el juego es un soundtrack decente de fondo y nada más, VACÍO.
   [*][u][b]Pobre diseño de niveles:[/b][/u] 
Las salas son muy pobres, esconden poco y son como comida rápida, las pasas y listo. Hollow Knight por ejemplo tenía un secreto en cada sala y a cada una de ellas le daba una utilidad con vida larga a futuro (late game).
   [*][u][b]Apartado visual:[/b][/u] 
Buen arte, buenos diseños, HORRIBLES ANIMACIONES. Parece un juego de Android en animaciones, súper genéricas, poco satisfactorias y de poco feedback.
   [*][u][b]Progreso en la historia:[/b][/u] 
Normalmente, en los metroidvanias te dejan a tu suerte, pero dándote pizcas de información que te hacen deducir a dónde ir y qué hacer, con la libertad de explorar a tu gusto antes de alcanzar X objetivo. En cambio, acá no hay pistas de nada, no se explica nada, ni mucho menos vas a saber a dónde tenés que ir. Vas a estar constantemente tirando para delante esperando encontrar algo, como si fuera una ruleta.


[hr][/hr]

[b]Es un juego genérico, de mayoría de apartados mediocres, y minoría de apartados apenas salvables.[/b]

[u][b]NO RECOMENDADO:[/b][/u] 
Es un intento de metroidvania que no alcanza las cotas de calidad del género. Es un juego que intenta cumplir y nada más, que intenta entrarte por los ojos y la emotividad superficial para comprarte... Hermano, hasta el nombre es genérico y parece sacado de la Play Store.

[b]Dejo los comentarios abiertos, ya que dudo que puedan rebatir mis puntos.[/b]
Al fin y al cabo eso es lo que buscan estos juegos, llegar a un sector de "jugadores" superficial, fácilmente enganchable, y con complejo de tribu fanatizada.

141235600.review:
Overall Impression: 69 D+ Just unable to recommend the game if you like hardcore metroidvanias. While there are strong points to the game, there are so many minor issues that add up and take the fun out of it.

I have played through the game to get all three endings, but I doubt I will ever play it again. It left that kind of taste with me.

More Detailed Review:

Ender Lilies starts strong. The art is great. The music is solid. As you set off, it feels like it is going to be a great game.

As you progress and the map opens up, cracks show. The controls float a bit too much for the tense fights and platforming. Your foes quickly fall into three major categories: distance shooters, annoying sword and board, and fast and dirty fragile fighters. When the game wants to punish you, it throws several from each category at you. As you go further, the bosses turn into cheap tactic specialists. While you have a variety of spirits available, only a small selection of them are really useful. 

The game also commits the sin of having a section where the environment slowly poisons you to death if you do not rush through it.  

I rarely say anything about originality in games, since there is so little new in the video game world today. However, Ender Lilies lowers the bar for originality in games. [spoiler]If you have played Hollow Knight and any of the Souls games, you have played better versions of this game.[/spoiler] Combining the trappings of two popular games into a single one may seem like a brilliant plan. Doing so while adding nothing new and highlighting the flaws of both games is not.

Please, do not take this review the wrong way. The game is not bad. However, its good points are outweighed by its irritating and poor ones.

141146424.review:
A very enjoyable metroidvania. Short and sweet. If you are experienced the genre, completionist should take you about 20 hours. Some quick points:

- Art is great but a bit dark to match the setting.
- Exploration is adequately rewarded. Rooms with no more loot are marked gold on the minimap (love that).
- Backtracking is a tiny bit scuffed in some rooms due to their size and lack of placeable markers in the minimap.

[h1]Combat [/h1]

For me the game's true treasure is its combat. The game has a posture mechanic that stuns enemies when you deplete it. However, your character being a delicate little girl cannot attack with her own limbs. Instead, you get 6 slots for summons. You find these summons by defeating (purifying) them as bosses/mini-bosses. When you call them, you see the actual spirit attacking and protecting you. Very cool and fits the narrative. It also gives you great customizability in your build. There are basic attack summons with sword, hammer, claws, magic ball, throwing knives, PARRY SUMMON, poison mist, pet bird and more.

On top of the 6 abilities you get a unique "full bar attack" for each basic attack ability (red abilities). Dodging is slow to recover but i-frames feel very fair. There are also relics in the game that you equip for different effects but are mostly basic stuff like tiny hp on hit, more dmg, less dmg etc.

Combat is fluid enough from the start but it gets criminally smooth when you are in control of the flow. This happens when you become familiar with enemy attack patterns (normal enemies have 3 attacks tops but mostly 1-2) and you get some parries and crowd control in.  

Overall 8/10 if Hollow Knight is a 9.99/10. Would definitely recommend under 10€. Hope they will release a more ambitious sequel to this.

141063423.review:
Wonderful game, absolutely worth the price; possibly my favourite metroidvania to date due to the incredibly satisfying combat and the exceptional level design [strike]most of the time[/strike], the touching (if a bit cliché) story is just the cherry on top. Now, to answer everyone's first two questions:

[h1]Is this game like Hollow Knight?[/h1]
Exploration and progression are going to feel very familiar, even by general metroidvania standards. Your "build" is determined by your spirits (we'll get to that later) and by your relics, the latter of which work essentially the same way as charms in HK, only without the synergy mechanic. However, combat is a bit more slow-paced, more grounded (don't worry, you'll be fighting in the air a lot, but you can't bounce indefinitely like in HK, air movement and ground positioning are equally important; luckily, your grounded options are very good and you'll never feel "constrained"), and more RPGesque – instead of Zelda-style hit points, you have a proper healthbar as well as several stats, both defensive and offensive, that can be increased with collectables and relics. Also, backtracking feels so much smoother, partially because the levels are specifically designed to become easier to travel through as you unlock more powers, and partially because there's simply not as much walking to do due to efficient fast travel and a smaller map; the only issue is the lack of an option to mark certain spots on the map in order to keep track of what you should be looking for when you come back, but it's compensated by the fact that the map shows you whether you've fully completed an area or not. Finally, while the narration is not as cryptic, you'll still have to piece the story together on your own just like in HK or in Dark Souls. Speaking of which...

[h1]Is this game like Dark Souls?[/h1]
While combat revolves heavily around the classic invincible dodge, even more so than around jumping, it's still very distinct from Dark Souls; the pace is much faster, the mobility is much higher, and staggering enemies (think of when you deal a lot of damage to a boss in a short amount of time and they get stunned for a few seconds, except it applies to all enemies) plays a much larger role. That said, learning to recognise the enemies' animations and attack patterns is just as crucial, and once you really get the hang of it, you can start spacing some of them out instead of relying exclusively on i-frames, or parrying them for huge stagger damage. Moreover, managing your health is very important because your heals are also limited, although they can be partially replenished in some areas. However, if I were to pick just one thing that really made me think of Dark Souls – specifically the first two games – it'd have to be spirits. These are basically your weapons and spells, you can equip two sets of three spirits at once and switch between them at any time, and most of them have limited uses that, just like heals, can only be replenished at checkpoints or in select locations. Personally, I've always preferred this system to the generic mana bar, so I'm glad the developers decided to implement it this way.

[h1]In conclusion[/h1]
While the inspiration from their predecessors is clear, I think the developers have done an excellent job improving on both formulas, and ultimately giving this game its own unique identity. Expect to see some of the things that made those titles great, and some new things that make Ender Lilies stand out among its peers.

141062021.review:
[quote]
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31884377-If-It-Is-Insane/]Check out my curator page for more awesome reviews[/url]
[/quote]
[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Ender Lilies is a decent metroidvania in concept and executes very well on its premise and the basics of the genre. It took the fundamentals, gave it a Nier and Dark Souls coat, but did not call it a day.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The first thing that normally caught one's eye are the visuals, and they are extremely important for Ender Lilies. It takes the innocence and typical barrier maiden tropes for the main character, clothes her in white and combines it by her standing with these monsters which embody different tropes in a zombified state.
Ender Lilies has this 90s comic book charm of these overexaggerated works that want to be edgy, yet contrasts it with at times beautiful backgrounds which make in terms of world building less sense than they should. Although one arguably will never care as the atmosphere captures the individual while playing and only in retrospective such questions may be asked. 
The post-apocalyptic look creates a visual style which is known from games like the Dark Souls series and executes well on how a world breaks down over time and which elements may remain and even stay beautiful. It is difficult to stress how well Ender Lilies does that, especially in its (rare) mostly monochrome and simple cutscenes with a great sense of direction to back up the substance which the game has. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Now we are getting to the game part. Ender Lilies is a very basic metroidvania with the staples of the genre. Dash, double jump, wall climb and so on.
The movement feels a little weighty, but it makes sense in the context of the game as the main character is only a little girl. Who gets progressively weaker as her body breaks down, and your spirits quite literally have to do the heavy lifting. This dichotomy of how physically vulnerable you are and how much they need your willpower to even have conscience is quite beautiful and works well in the game. 
Ender Lilies has three distinctive gameplay loops in the most essential metroidvania fashion imaginable. 
The first one is to traverse the area, and loot what you can get. 
After that it is about slaying the boss.
Finally, you collect the stuff to power up with the upgrade you obtained. 
Very basic, still satisfying.
The boss fights embody different archetypes of enemies already fought in the game, but their move sets are pushed to the boundaries of what the game allows which makes for good fights. 
Bosses are by far the best part of the game as they perfectly hover between being not too easy, but also not being frustrating. 
Especially the early game is relatively unforgiving in typical metroidvania fashion, and it is important if one wants to enjoy the game, that a certain focus or mindset is needed to push through this early game. Keep in mind that not every enemy need to be fought. Just reach the next bench. 
There are times when the game takes its concepts and uses them creatively, especially with its platforming that can be quite challenging in the endgame, if you want to find every lootable object. These are relatively rare though, and it marks the biggest “problem” with Ender Lilies. 
The game has no really original ideas or gameplay mechanics that make it stand out. 
On the Shoulders of Giants
There is some clear inspiration from the metroidvania influx after Hollow Knight revived the genre. The level design, areas, relic system and so on are all carbon copies. Even some narrative beats are shared between these two games. 
There is some clear inspiration and Ender Lilies does not hide in any game, but executes it well enough that it is not too obvious. Yet, there is this unfavorable comparison to be made:
Ender Lilies is weaker than its biggest inspiration in every way, except for the music and maybe the story.
If you want to play a masterpiece, then Hollow Knight is your best pick. But after that?
Maybe Bloodstained. And when you compare Bloodstained and Ender Lilies, I think Ender Lilies is going to make the cut, depending on your preferences of course.

[h1]Atmosphere[/h1]
Now this is where the game shines. The downtrodden world with these masses of zombified enemies which showcase the different life circumstances of the inhabitants and how they got hit with the plague of this game.
There are many small touches to areas, and it showcases that the developers tried to make the game dense, despite not having limitless resources. And they absolutely succeeded. Even enemy repetition is never a problem as they are being used in different scenarios. As such it never becomes a slog to play through and keeps the player focussed and immersed.
The exposition dumps via collectibles or after clearing a boss are quite good and ask as many questions as they answer. Lore-wise Ender Lilies is not overly complicated, and every set piece gets exactly as explained as it needs to be. 
All of these elements peaks, when the music hits just right. Ender Lilies soundtrack is phenomenal and used to great effect to characterize your surroundings and give them distinctive identities.
The music is nothing less than masterpiece quality and will definitely be the most memorable part of the game of anyone who starts it. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Ender Lilies is not going to change your world or revolutionize what you understand under the word metroidvania. But it will offer you a great gameplay experience after an admittedly hard early game. Keep at it, and you will see some pure metroidvania essence, polished to a great degree.

140903546.review:
An underrated gem in the rough. Stunning presentation, competent gameplay - which is neither too hard, nor too easy, with lots of freedom; for that gameplay I came and stayed for the story and characters. Ender Lilies is all I expect from a good souls-like metroidvania. It starts a bit rough - and that section is what makes many drop out but bare with it - it gets progressively better as you continue and will keep you entertained until the very end - and beyond.

In comparison to other, similar games I'd have to say Ender Lilies is definitely in the very top in terms of artistic direction and - along with it's beautiful soundtrack - it creates one of the most moody, melancholic presentations of a fallen kingdom, with it's equally broken, tarnished inhabitants; the kind of feeling you'd expect from within Romanticism, Erlkönig being the closest one. There's a lot of sadness within it, intermixed with loneliness and glimpses of hope which make you push onwards.

Play it. You won't regret it.

140856196.review:
If you're at all into Metroidvanias like i am then absolutely yes. Fantastic OST, great combat, deeply depressing setting and tone that's all about death and decay. I love it.

You play as a child named Lily, pretty much the last hope for an already long dead world, woken up by a soldiers spirit that's sworn to protect her lineage. At first Lily can't do much but jump, command the soldier to swing his sword and "dodge" not so gracefully, she literally just dives headfirst into the dirt and it's the cutest dodge I've ever seen. 

Combat is fast but most enemies won't be too challenging, but the bosses, my lord the bosses. Talk about difficulty spikes. If normal enemies test your combat skills then bosses test your will to live. Some of them aren't too bad, but some like [REDACTED] is the game crossing its arms and going "No." I never felt like i had to grind to beat them, just focus or try a new tactic, but they demand you pay attention.

You do have plenty of options in combat though, Lily can command several spirits at once that can cause pain in various ways. For the sake of simplicity I'll refer to them as "stagnant" and "furious" spirits. You can "equip" any three of them at one time when taking a rest, some of them have infinite use and some finite. The finite charges are restored when resting so you're not gonna need to ever grind. 

All spirits can be levelled up and as you might expect, get better in various ways. Chances are you'll find whichever spirits suit you and stick with those, i did. I do recommend you save up the material you need to upgrade spirits until you find your favourites, you're not going to find unlimited material on one playthrough. 

I've done two playthroughs, with the second one i 100%'ed the game with a total of about 41 hours, so it's not that long of a game which i think is good cause there isn't any filler, it's a really straight forward game with some optional areas to explore if you want to. Every map you get to has something worth finding, more of less. There's plenty of mini bosses spread all over which rewards you with new spirits.

There are multiple endings in a very "Nier automata" style, most of which basically tell you "Yo, you're not done," and hint at where the "truth lie." 

In summary Give sequel please.

140820278.review:
I'm not really concise when it comes to reviews but I feel like I enjoyed the game enough that I want to add my own.

The thing that made me initially want to buy the game was the aesthetic of the game.  I like that the main character isn't the one actually doing the fighting (at least physically).  It's very much how I wish summoner styled classes and characters played in other games.  

I'm a fan of world settings where it's after some catastrophic event and the world your exploring is one that's either on it's last legs or has already fallen.  There's a kind of "peace" I feel as I progress and read all the lore items I pick up and piece together what happened.  It's one of my favorite parts of games like Dark Souls.  I've long grown tired of being bombarded with quest after quest and cutscene after cutscene.  This game has cutscenes but there aren't a ton of them, their usage makes sense and is usually reserved for things like after a boss.

This games soundtrack really helps set the tone of it's areas.  Sometimes I'd find myself stop moving through the level just to sit there for a minute and listen, and even going back to certain areas later not because I needed to backtrack there to get something but just because I was in the mood to hear the music.

I'd say that combat is overall pretty good.  You have 6 slots for your different attacks, 2 sets of 3.  You can either hold a button to swap between the first and 2nd set, or you can have it be a toggle.  My only complaint about this is that if you have a skill that has one of the spirits passively attack with you on one set, and you switch sets to use a skill briefly and switch back it unsummons the passive spirit but that's not a huge deal.  You don't have a guard in this game, but there are two different spirits that function as parries that have follow up attacks, and you get an upgrade later that gives you another parry that isn't tied to a spirit.  The dodge in this game does get an upgrade later on but the default dodge is suprisingly good, you can reliably use it to i-frame through attacks and to go through enemies to get behind them.

The exploration is pretty good, obviously since it's a metroidvania it has backtracking as you get new movement abilities and stuff, but I didn't really find it to be that bad because of the map.  When every collectible is picked up in an area, that area turns yellow on the map, when there's still stuff to collect it's blue.  You unlock fast travel between rest areas pretty early on, so if you need to back track it's generally not an ordeal.

Character progression was fairly straightforward to the point I didn't really have to think about it that much.  I never really had any points where I felt like I had to grind or farm,  it always felt like I could just try a different set of spirits of put on different relics whenever I had trouble fighting a boss.  You can ignore your level for the whole game, it's not very important since it's just stat increases, all the important choices come down to your relics.  Relics work on a "cost" system where relics use up anywhere between 0 to 4 "cost".  As you explore you'll find items that gives you +1 to your total cost.  Items with stronger effects generally cost more.  You can put on multiple relics of the same effect as long as you have enough cost, so you don't really have cases of one just being simply better.

My only real complaints for the game are two things, one of which isn't exclusive to it.
I absolutely hate "contact damage" in games.  The enemy walking into me shouldn't do basically the same damage as one of it's attacks.  When contact damage exists, I stop seeing enemies as a living thing in the world but as a walking hurtbox.  It's something that incentivises "safe" play styles.  If you play aggressive and with mostly melee, you'll find a lot of times where you get hit not because of an attack, but the enemy bumping into you, sometimes it'll be because you dodged an attack, but because of the attack their body is now ontop of you so the instant your dodge ends you get contact damage.

The other thing which is that a there's like, 3 areas where to reach certain things you need to use specific spirits.  Normally in a metroidvania this wouldn't be an issue, but in this game, for about 90% of it, every time you hit a point where you can't get somewhere, it's because you need to kill a main boss and get a new movement tool from it.  The reason this is an issue is because up until this point, every movement you've gotten as an upgrade has been passive, you always have it regardless of what spirits you're using, and these last 3 areas, you need at least 1 of 2 spirits you get near the end of the game.  The problem is that because of how it was handled earlier, it's reasonable to just think you needed to go kill another main boss, but these 2 spirits are sidebosses that are entirely skippable, and you can be in a situation where you've already killed the final boss and haven't even seen these 2.  If you didn't have 90% of the game need these 2 spirits for their slight movement, why not just have made it 100% and just have them be optional movement tools, rather than have stuff that literally isn't doable without them?

I have no idea how to do proper formatting on steam so to anyone that actually read all of this, sorry about that and sorry for rambling.  Overall, I had a really fun time with the game, other than two gripes, and the only things I could really ask for are obviously "more", and to be able to play the game again blind.  The price for the game is pretty fair for how solid of an experience it was, and even more so if you get it on sale.  I didn't mention this early because I didn't think of it, but I don't think I encountered a single bug, which is a little surprising these days.

El arte de ENDER LILIES es sencillamente impresionante. Los escenarios están pintados a mano con gran detalle y están llenos de atmósferas sombrías y melancólicas. Cada área del juego tiene su propia identidad visual, y los efectos de iluminación y partículas agregan una sensación de misterio y belleza al mundo del juego. Los enemigos y jefes también están magníficamente diseñados, con animaciones fluidas y detalles que los hacen destacar (como la onda de calor al utilizar ataques cuerpo a cuerpos, que para ser honestos, nunca había visto antes en ningún otro juego) 
Sin embargo, aunque el arte de ENDER LILIES es su punto fuerte, su jugabilidad y mecánicas no ofrecen una experiencia innovadora. Se asemeja a otros juegos de su categoría, como Hollow Knight, donde los jugadores exploran un mundo interconectado, obtienen nuevas habilidades y luchan contra enemigos desafiantes. Aunque las mecánicas son sólidas y el combate es fluido, no se destacan en comparación con otros títulos del género.
Una de las críticas que me permito destacar de ENDER LILIES es que su dificultad no representa un desafío significativo para los jugadores experimentados. Los enemigos y jefes pueden ser derrotados fácilmente una vez que se dominan sus patrones de ataque, lo que puede llevar a una sensación de falta de desafío y repetición. Sin embargo, para aquellos que buscan una experiencia más relajada o que disfrutan más del aspecto visual y la narrativa, este juego puede resultar atractivo.

140753255.review:
This game does one thing exceptionally well, and that's respect your time.

While it's labelled "Souls-Like" it really isn't much at all. It's not terribly difficult, for instance, and the developers seem to have made the experience as non-frustrating as possible.

That goes back to respecting your time. In souls-games, dying is meant to be a setback or to invoke tension. "What if I die before getting back to my 'insert odd currency here'?" You don't lose anything for dying here, though. You just get sent quickly back to the last checkpoint you were at. which are abundant and serve as fast-travel hubs, and you don't even lose any progression that you achieved before dying. You can also just warp back to the last checkpoint whenever you want, like having infinite homeward bones.

Heck, the game even lacks many achievements that you might expect. For instance, there's a boss rush mode unlocked at the end of the game, but no achievement tied to completing it. Or leveling all of your spirits to max, which would be quite the chore. There isn't even an achievement for beating newgame+. There is one for getting to level 100, but I only ended up needing to grind for the last ten and it still only took half an hour. It's as if they chose to exclude achievements that would have been too time consuming as to not waste the time of compulsive achievement hunters.

Even the map handily shows you the rooms that do and don't still have stuff to find in, so frantic searching for those last few pesky collectibles won't be a part of the experience. 

All this, along with the forgiving death and frequent respite points might make people think the game is too easy, but it is still a fair challenge, just not obscenely so, and, like I said, respects your time. It took me sixteen hours to 100% it, and none of that time felt frustrating, which, as someone with limited time to play games, I appreciate.

If you want a polished, compact, game with good art, music, and a decent story, this is a good purchase.

140748782.review:
I was really on the fence about this review. If you're seeing this you can consider it more of a neutral review.

Positives:
Music is fantastic. 
The overall movement between levels is really well done.
Enemy layouts are pretty well thought out IMO making traversing rooms a good balance of difficulty and ease depending on the situation.
Story was relatively simplistic, but not bad.

Neutral:
This took roughly 9 hours to complete endings A+B (final boss). Everything else is just purely backtracking through stages for completionism. 
On that note, this game requires A LOT of backtracking. For this style of game it's not the end of the world. Just know what you're getting into. If you're coming into this game because it's sold as a souls-like it might get annoying.
Cost was about $1.5 / 1hr of gameplay on sale. I'd say this is neutral for a game like this. 

Negatives: 
The absolute most frustrating part of the game is the hitboxes. You spend more time dodging the hitboxes of enemies than dodging their attacks. Some enemies have huge hitboxes. In the same way they say the camera is the greatest enemy in dark souls, the hitbox is the greatest enemy of this game. You can be charging up an attack and a random enemy from off screen casually walks into you for 50% of your HP. 
One boss has 5-6 minions with huge hitboxes that teleport around the map randomly before attacking. This can create situations where you can't move because there's a wall of hitboxes blocking your way. Most bosses have a backstep meaning that even if you successfully dodge their attack, get to their blindspot, and attack, they can just "dodge" and run over you with their hitbox. 
It may have been more apt to skin all these enemies as monster trucks and the game is just about avoiding monster trucks from running over you.
Boss healthbars are fairly large. Paired with one boss that sits there blocking for 5 minutes for the first phase of the fight, makes for an incredibly long and tedious fight. 
Parrying is useless in this game. Boss interrupts don't exist in this game. Using ring parry just gets you launched to narnia meaning you lose DPS running back across the arena. Using spirit parries is incredibly underwhelming. Low damage, no interrupts, high cooldown. Extremely underwhelming gameplay to spirit parry a hit only to get hit by a follow up attack while you're mid animation. 
I'm not a very good gamer but most bosses only took 1-3 tries including the ending B fight. I did not do any backtracking for equipment / levels either, and only 7 relic slots / lv66 by the time of completion.


Edit: 
People have mentioned that NG+ improves boss patterns. I started NG+ and it doesn't seem that there's much appreciable change. Bosses certainly attack more and add 1-2 attacks to their repertoire but the fights are still stupidly easy, just they take longer because bosses now have more AOE to attacks, leaving you with less opening.

140658720.review:
This game is a MUST HAVE.

Minor spoilers ahead!

(I never write reviews so, apologies if this is bad :( )

Overall 10/10


Now i'm going to start this review by saying that I haven't played very many Metroidvania games so be advised this review may be a little scuffed. I saw this game having a steam sale and bought it on a whim. Honestly just by looking at the trailers and pictures I thought that I might play the game for a bit but soon quit the game. Little to my surprise this game actually turned out to be one of my favorite games I have ever played. From art style to music direction this game is able to bring it all together to create a gloomy and mysterious atmosphere.

Atmosphere, 10/10 (JUST LIKE DARK SOULS FR!)
The game starts off with the main character being awoken by the spirit of a knight. You wake up with no recollection of who you are or where you are. However, the spirit compels you to leave the structure with his aid. As you exit the cathedral you run into some sort of amalgamation of something that may once be human or animal. The spirit helps you get past them and once you exit the building, you find a desolate landscape with no signs of life besides the groans and cries of who knows what is out there... This is how the game opens, the player has just been dropped into the middle of no where with no backstory and its your job to find out what is happening and how to stop it. As you continue on your search, the game shows many vast different areas from the death-filled catacombs to a whimsical magical forest. As you travel to each area, the environment tells a story be it through the tattered and broken down buildings or the uprooted forest you are able to see a story unfold, one of despair or one of melancholy.  What's more is that the music all fits each area! Onto the next.

Music 11/10
I am a tad bit bias when it comes to the music for this game. The music for this game is entirely made and composed by Mili. Mili is very well known for their song rightfully that was made to be the opening for Goblin slayer. They also made some of the music for Library of Ruina, which if you don't know what it is I suggest you take a look! Mili was able to enhance each environment by adding the most practically fitting music I could possibly think of. Each soundtrack is able to create a new atmosphere for each environment or at least enchance it. Not much else to be said here. LISTEN TO MILI NOW! IRON LOTUS!!!!! GONE ANGELS!!!!!!!

Story 10/10
Ah what to say about the story, I personally loved it. It is however told in fragments, so to uncover the story you will need to piece together the information yourself. I do like this type of storytelling however to some this may seem like a con. Don't let this sway you from buying the game however as the story itself is very well made. Throughout the game, for every boss you killed you are able to uncover a bit of the story through memories. How it came this way, what happened, and so on.

Gameplay 9.5/10
The game gives you 2 "loadouts" to put your spirits into I like this feature of the game being able to pick and choose what you use without overwhelming yourself with control. The game also has you mixup the spirits you use when you fight each different boss and each area allows you to slowly build up your arsenal!

Conclusion:
Honestly, I suggest you buy this game no matter what type of game you like. It's a great way to start metroidvanias being relatively easy to beat and 100% as well as being extremely forgiving. Please GET THIS GAME

140648446.review:
I abhor this style of control.  I don't know why people love this.  Movement is slow and stilted, attacking removes all momentum from your character even when attacking in the air.  There is no reasonable hit stun on enemies and your character gets animation locked.  Hope you like dodge rolling because they have you doing that right off the bat.  Oh, and slowly jogging through the map.  I played all of 6 minutes and that was enough to tell me I would absolutely hate this game.  You can claim I didn't play enough, but if I'm this irritated with the controls in the first 6 minutes, there is no way I am giving it more time.  This isn't button placement, and I was already using a gamepad,  It just feels terrible to move the character around, and it feels terrible to attack.  Just another Metroidvania plagued by terrible controls that people love because they think it's fun for enemies to ignore everything you do.  (I don't care if there is a weapon later in the game that actually causes stun, the feedback at the beginning of the game is terrible.  I can only imagine the people giving it positive reviews enjoy memorizing attack patterns of every enemy in the game and care more about length than quality.

Enemies ignoring your hits is not good combat.  Long grindy combat is not good combat.  Terrible controls that you're fighting to get to do what you want is not good combat.  Yes, they make the game take longer, but it feels terrible to play.

I really wish people would stop calling games like this Metroidvania.  This is more "side scrolling dark souls" as both Metroid and Castlevania largely understood pacing, fun combat, and smooth animations.  Long fights were used to show you what zones you aren't ready for (and honestly in later installments got really hand-holding)  Both Metroid and Castlevania have hit feedback from the monsters, have momentum carry you through, and are more about exploration and boss fights than generic unit combat.  This is the opposite of all of that.  

It's fine to like something like this, but it's not a metroid game, and it doesn't feel like castlevania.  Bloodstained Ritual of the Night feels like Castlevania.  The game is actually fun to play because it uses what Castlevania does great.  It's not about getting "hours" of play time, because if that playtime is terrible and boring, who cares.

A lot of people don't mind that stuff.  I do, if you do as well, avoid this game like the plague.

TL;DR: If your looking for a simple game to turn your brain off to and enjoy good music and atmosphere this is for you. If you want satisfying movement and combat that feels like your moves have impact look elsewhere.

140323697.review:
So i will preface this review with that this is my first metroidvania-style game, and thus certain gameplay aspects will likely be subject to bias or lack of experience. With that out of the way though, I want to say that Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights is an absolutely phenomenal game in several aspects and well worth a try.

First let's discuss the visual and auditory design. This game, simply put, looks and sounds incredible. The landscape and entity designs are done extremely well and are very pleasing to just stop and stare at when you have a moment. Everything truly looks and feels the part of being in this decrepit and somber world while also maintaining compelling and interesting designs. And these beautiful set pieces are accompanied by a stunning OST; each area has a main theme with bosses having their own themes. The OST alone is incredible, but each track really helps lay down the vibe and mood of whatever it is you happen to be doing at the moment depending on the area. Props go out to the teams in charge of these aspects.

Now with all of that said, great design doesn't mean that much without good gameplay right? Well, in that regard I believe that Ender Lilies is...pretty good. I would not say fantastic; a lot of animations lock you into them for a bit too long (which some enemies will ruthlessly punish if you want to use those powers), the guarding option feels too weak in a lot of cases (either putting you in disadvantage even if it works or being too precise to really slot into your attacks), some of the movement for puzzle solving does not feel intuitive (though this was like 3-ish times throughout the whole game), and there's a distinct lack of good anti-air attack options that don't have very limited ammo (which I wouldn't normally complain about, but there's also a decent amount of enemies that fly around that can be hard to chase down in the air horizontally). A smaller nitpick that I also have is that your jump-based vertical mobility doesn't really change that much from the start, which wasn't really a problem but was definitely weird that there was absolutely nothing else to get for that. Other than that though, the world exploration and combat was not bad at all and both eases you into concepts that you'll run into later and gives you plenty of chances to test out whatever you get before the next area and difficulty (minus one area I'm sure most players know about...). As previously mentioned air combat mostly sucks, but ground or low air combat is great, and there's plenty of different powers to get that facilitate a wide variety of play styles depending on what you want to use. Something I will additionally note in regards to the world exploration is that there's actually quite a lot that you can reach without certain power-ups if you can figure out how to use the powers you do have effectively (there's at least 2 areas I cheesed the intended strategy with clever use of spaced air lag and recoil from an attack); this game also values freedom of progression, as for the most part you can do any of the areas in whatever order you choose (though granted some areas will only be unlocked by beating the pre-requisite ones to my knowledge). So again, not amazing gameplay (and probably rougher than usual for metroidvania players) but I think it's perfectly serviceable with a fair amount of difficulty and freedom.

The last thing I want to talk about is the story; now while I'm not gonna spoil anything, I should note that the story is less told to you and more discovered in the form of notes and memories. Very little is directly "explained" to the player and is more inferred until you get more context as you progress. Despite this however, I feel that the story of Ender Lilies is one of the strongest parts of the game, giving you just enough background to really feel the situation that these characters found themselves in. It's truly worth the time and effort to fully piece together that story.

As for my final review, I believe that this game is quite a treasure; it has a riveting story, pretty good gameplay, and amazing aesthetic brought to life by gorgeous art and stellar music. I'm not sure if it's a great metroidvania, but if you are looking for a good game to sink some hours into I would definitely recommend at least trying this game out for yourself.

EDIT: Forgot the final score: 9.5/10. 100%'d and would definitely play again.

140158890.review:
Ender Lilies is a very Japanese metroidvania. You play as a small girl who is trying to stop the blight, a sort of "The Last of Us" fungus that makes everything insane and immortal. You fight and jump through boxy rooms smashing enemies and levelling up, interspersed with boss fights. The bosses are generally very good - although there are huge spikes in difficulty. Most bosses I killed in 2-3 attempts, but there were two which took me over an hour each. By defeating bosses, you gain traversal moves and combat abilities which you can swap out at every safe point. I did end up completely finishing it, but the story and cutscenes are bad - possibly due to lacklustre translation.

[b]Pros[/b]
- An interesting thing about that game is that your character doesn't actually do any of the work. When you attack, you temporarily summon a spirit who attacks for you, and you sort of shy away
- Instead of always having all abilities, you choose 6, and you can use 3 at a time, switching between sets
- Spirits can be levelled up to make them more effective, increase combos
- Some spirits are more effective than others in certain situations, so the main trick to bosses is working out which spirits would be best
- Bosses unlock permanent abilities like double jump, and unlock that spirit with a special move. For example, the first boss unlocks a mac swing attack. Annoying that they're limited uses between benches
- You can fast travel to any visited bench

[b]Cons[/b]
- The cutscenes and story are junk
- The level design is very boring
- Takes a really long time to get interesting
- Really annoying, repetitive music
- Levels. Enemies give XP
- Just like Hollow Knight / Dark Souls, there are relics (charms), a number of times you can heal between rest points, and resting brings back all the enemies
- Your character stops moving every time you attack, which makes combat feel very static
- The UI, or the attack values are bugged. When I was level 85, my attack was 175. Level 86 it was 209. Level 87, back to 179. It seemed to vary wildly every time I levelled up

140137419.review: I got a 100%. It was worth the grind, every single bit of it. I love the soundtrack. The plot is hella good. I want more games like this. I found the mechanics very smooth, albeit at times frustrating to get right. Overall, would recommend playing

140083767.review:
Excellent game, good story telling, incredibly fun combat mechanics and a proper metroidvania experience. The music is exceptional and the world is morbidly beautiful (with incredible artwork all round). Boss fights are fun and not frustrating, and there are a lot of QoL benefits -- like not needing to replay the game to see all endings, a nifty map color scheme for showing you rooms you've not completed, permanently unlocked warping between checkpoints, etc. The game also has a variety of equip-able attacks/spells, so you can really match your gear and loadout with your playstyle (go smash with big hammer, pew pew with long range magic, in and out with agile swords, etc. and combinations thereof).
It's a very similar experience to Hollow Knight (in terms of world building and high level gameplay), but in a good way. The combat mechanics are fairly different; if you liked Hollow Knight, you'll definitely like this.

Couple of small gripes: There are a couple of occasionally clunky movements and combat techniques. The boss fights were not all that challenging even for a first play through. I don't think any boss took more than 10 attempts to beat (with a large majority taking under 5 attempts, including the last few bosses). Map is kind of clunky and you can't easily look at room names unless you're at a respite (checkpoint/safe zone).

Overall: Excellent game with super fun gameplay, great music and art. If you like Hollow Knight, Blasphemous and other 2-D metroidvania souls-like games, you'll like this for sure.

140073530.review: Absolutely gorgeous game, at least ten of the 50 hours I put into this game must be from listening to the music and another ten to reading every finding. The story starts out as a simple "recently awoken chosen one, save the world" but as you go on, you get invested in finding the White Priestess of the Fount as well as purifying the poor soul that have fallen victim to the Rain as well as other factors. The main spirits all have their own well-written backstories as well, only making you empathise more with them as well as leave you wondering how the world looked before the blight. It's not particularly impressive or innovative in terms of mechanics or level design, the bosses can be a bit hard at first but once you get their moves they are just a thing of timing, the story is well-written and gets you more invested in the world the more you unveil what's happened, the visuals are stunning and the music is beautiful as expected of Mili. I would say it's a solid 8/10

139774440.review:
I don't leave reviews often, but I like to look at the negative comments before I do. And I can say this.

This game is universally praised in the art, music, atmosphere, and story. They are PHENOMENAL and I cannot stress this enough. However, that aside, there are some people that don't mesh with the combat and level design. And while I can understand why some of the fights/areas could turn people off, this game is an absolute home run for me.

This game is hard. This game doesn't walk you through where you're supposed to go. Most Metroidvanias don't, but you can 100% find your way into an area that is non linear and much too difficult for you. I also find it very VERY similar to From Soft games in terms of combat. I think this is where some people find issues with the combat in the game. AND JUST TO BE CLEAR, I'M NOT GATE KEEPING DIFFICULTY. I genuinely don't think this game requires you to 'git gud' but it does require you to think. You will acquire spirits throughout the game and most of them will be useful in some situations, but there will be the core 5-6 that you rely on. I think that since some spirits require you to explore optional areas to find, some players could miss them and those spirits would be a LOT of help during some encounters. There is a charge mechanic where some spirits truly shine during their charge attack. All this being said, the areas are difficult, and the bosses get HARD. If this turns you off of the combat, that is perfectly understandable. For me however, I'm glad they didn't shy away on the difficulty aspect of it. Overcoming difficulty is always going to elicit a good feeling, but this game makes it feel like a whole cinematic fight when you finally get it right. Shout out to [spoiler]Ulv[/spoiler] for being far and away my favorite fight and soundtrack.

The movement in this game isn't extraordinary, but even starting the game I was trying to use attacks to slightly lift me up after a jump to try and get somewhere that I shouldn't be able to get to yet. That feeling persisted throughout the entire game and I loved every second of it. That being said it is fairly conservative in how many movement options it gives you.

If this game even slightly interests you, AT LEAST buy it on sale. It is worth every penny.

139616203.review:
Be warned: this game's story is FULL of depression. I played the first 7 hours of a 16 hour playthrough and literally stopped playing it for a couple years (partly because I forgot) because the story really got to me. That's not to say it's a bad thing - I resonated with this game more strongly than some people, I suppose.

Anyway, the rest of the game is fantastic. I've played a gamut of Metroid-likes and true Metroidvanias like Symphony of the Night, so the gameplay wasn't overly unfamiliar. The fights are well-paced, barring one boss who is meant to be a game of patience, and the weapons and skills are nicely varied. Some of the common enemies are way more annoying than they need to be, and some have hitboxes that come out too quickly, but true to the genre, you don't have to fight EVERYTHING, especially since there are no drops to worry about.

The music and artwork complement each other perfectly. The music tends towards sad and somber, but has some darker tones for the boss fights. The artwork and scenery are beautiful: while the enemies are grotesque and the world itself is beaten down, there are bits and pieces that show you how the world used to look.

Overall, I wholeheartedly recommend this game. It can be tough in places and grinding for levels doesn't always help, but the game never felt unfair. The story got to me (not in a negative way) so I had to put it down for a bit, but getting back in and finishing it was rewarding.

139001162.review:
I came into this game with high expectations and they have been exceeded.  The art in this game is amazing as are the controls.  The game also has excellent QOL features including:

  - An excellent map that divides the game into "cells".  Each cell is colored blue or orange to tell you if you have collected every item in that area.  There are also red dots that show the presence of doorways that have not yet been taken.  It's a great mix of abstract and usefulness.
  - The only penalty for dying is that you go back to the last rest site.  It's quite refreshing to not lose something and the game has enough challenge that this does not make the game too easy.  It also means there is no penalty in pushing ahead on little remaining health, which can be fun too.
  - Great enemy design where sloppy play leads to taking quite a bit of damage but playing attentively allows most enemies to be defeated without taking damage (similar to dark souls)
  - Teleport between rest site from the start.  Return to the last rest site at any time.  These things improve exploration efficiency.
  - Enemies stay defeated until you rest. Thus there is no enemy-respawn penalty to leaving an area and returning later, as long as you didn't rest.

For me the only slight downside is that there are so many skills/weapons to choose from but they are expensive to upgrade, so I played though most of the game with just a few.  Having upgrades cover all weapon types would make it possible to experiment with them more.

I'll also mention that I has zero crashes or other technical problems.  Framerate was locked at 60 on the steamdeck and 144 on my PC.  The game looks/plays great at 720, 1080 and 1440p.

Overall a benchmark Metroidvania IMO.

138434495.review:
For my first playthrough I spend 20-22 hours. 
This includes 100% Completion and reading all Notes and overall enjoying the game to its fullest.
Its short game but a extremely well made one.

The description of the game is indeed correct. 
Its an Action RPG (And half of it Souls-like) Metroidvania game with a few rogue-like aspects.
Please do not play the game with the expectation of a nice rogue-like because u couldnt be more wrong.

As my first completed Metroidvania game, it was a good experience. U travel across the map and return to locations after u collected more skills and experience. Depending on how u view it, It can frustrate u that u cannot slove this puzzle or more specifically blocked way because u havent been into the game far enough yet, but once u realize thats part of the game, it gets really fun because when u unlock certain skills u will have a neuron activation when remembering that u can finally cross this one area of the game or finally collect this piece of item. U can even choose after the prologue which area u wanna explore first so u are not forced to go through areas that u might not like. The further u explore the more choices u will have where to continue, it gets quite overwhelming at a certain point because u can explore so many areas but it makes u very excited and more curious to keep playing.

There are many different areas of the game and it makes u wonder if theres even an end. Therefore, there are various enemies u will meet and beat. The combat is simple and can get quite repetitive if u go across the same area. But the other half of the game is exploring. Because the combat is simple, its relatively easy to make mistakes at times. It may sound kinda confusing but u will see for urself.

There are Bosses aswell of course. The further u dive into the game the more unique the bosses get. Always more different compared to last one. The skill ceiling has great heights, u are easily aware of ur improvements mid-battle because of the simplicity of the combat. U will die multiple times when fighting bosses, u will probably clear the first one without death when u have some understanding and skills from similar games. But after that u need to learn the bosses and try to minimize ur mistakes. U will also learn strategies on how to fight the bosses along the way.

Its important to keep the lore in mind because this is also what the game is about. Try to get into it, but u wont have the full picture even after completing the game. There are very great videos of explaining the lore and they dont take that long.
There are multiple endings in the game and u can reach all of them in one playthrough.

The game also wants u to use "not intented" moves to reach areas and find items which is such a rewarding and satisfying feeling. I had to watch a couple videos because I just couldnt figure out myself how to reach certain points or collect specific items.

Once u complete the game theres still some "late game" content for u to play which is a good touch. U can even play again with changing difficulty settings.

The soundtracks are great which suit the moment or area u are in. But tbh there are some soundtracks that I didnt like so much than the others but all of them have a charm and are great.

Sadly I cannot re-expierence it again even after trying to. 
But u sure can and its worth it for 20 hours of playtime.
I recommend getting the game when its on sale.

Very rarely am I inspired by a game to full complete it. This game was a pleasure to play. I played the entire game on stream and so I'll keep the review short. If you like souls-likes, or metroidvanias, you'll enjoy this game. I came into it thinking it was going to simply  be just another souls-like contender as many before it have tried to recreate the formula. This game takes the formula and throws it out the window, the gameplay isn't wholly unique but it brings concepts and gameplay ideas to the table that are very much enjoyable to experience. Specifically, the combat. Using the spirits of enemies you've "purified" to further your quest through the game world is such a fun thing, especially with how varied and fun they are to actually put to use. Stopping not only at combat, but utility and puzzle/platforming as well. 

Not only is the game fun, and enticing to explore, but said exploration is assisted by the backdrop of beautiful art and scenery, with environments ranging from castle ramparts, to the depths of fungal caves, to even an overgrown hellscape, with background sounds that made me jump and wonder,"Who just made that noise???" 

If you own this game, I highly encourage you to play it at least once, give it a try. if you don't own it, I highly recommend you buy it and play it if you are a fan of souls-like games, or metroidvanias. As I was pleasantly surprised by this game.

I streamed this game over at twitch.tv/gloomaeve and will be playing other games there as well.

138231848.review:
Estamos en un mundo oscuro donde el reino de Finisterra a sido consumido por la impureza. 
La impureza corroe el cuerpo y la mente, llegando a convertir a las personas en inmortales y en monstruos.

Aquí nos ponemos en el papel de  Lili, una pequeña niña que no esta acostumbrada al combate, lo único que pude hacer es purificar la impureza, esto se puede ver en pleno combate, donde al principio para esquivar a los enemigos te tira al suelo. Es acompañada de un caballero fantasma que la protegerá, al principio parece que no va reaccionar bien en combate, pero se maneja muy bien.

Conforme avancemos, como en otros Metroidvania, adquiriremos mas habilidades y fantasmas de todas las categorias, con golpes pesados o ataques a distancia.

Ender lilies recompensa mucho a los que les gusta explorar, podremos encontrar reliquias que no darán pasivas, aumentar la veda o conseguir los objetos que necesitaremos para mejorar a los fantasmas, que estos se nos unirán a nuestras filas conforme matemos a los jefes principales y a los secundarios.

Es un metroidvania precioso, el estilo artístico y la banda sonora son espectaculares. La única peque que le veo y es muy pequeña y para gustos, las escenas deberían de tener doblaje, aun que fuera al japones o ingles para tener un poco mas de inmersión. por lo de mas es perfecto.

138211344.review:
Ender Lilies is a masterstroke of 2D action RPGs, presenting an immersive dark fantasy world cloaked in rain-soaked despair. Its atmospheric art style, with tones of a medieval, ruined kingdom, captivates you from the first frame, drawing you into a narrative that's as tragic as it is engrossing.

The game's somber ambiance is further amplified by a remarkable soundtrack. The score is a melancholic symphony that relaxes as much as it stirs, reminiscent of the Nier series. It creates a perfect harmony with the game's overall dark aesthetic, enhancing every encounter with its haunting melodies.

Ender Lilies offers a richly woven narrative, wrapped in a strikingly moody aesthetic and a poignant soundtrack. The experience is haunting, challenging, and ultimately rewarding [b]an unforgettable journey into a rain-drenched, fallen kingdom.[/b]

138139119.review:
I can see why people like this game since the atmosphere and music are really good. Unfortunately I didn't enjoy it and decided to refund. 
Here is my impression from the hour or so I played.

The combat is stiff and boring. It's like castlevania but without the weapon variety and no backstep animation cancel, which basically made the castlevania games feel fluid when they were otherwise quite rigid. You also continued the jumping motion in castlevania, whereas in this one you jarringly stop in the air and hover until your attacks are done. 

Speaking of castlevania, the 'recruit dead knights' was a part I was really looking forward to, having been a fan of Aria of Sorrow and Dawn of Sorrow, where you could absorb enemy souls to gain new abilities. However, this is not at all the same. The abilities are from static encounters, not from a drop chance, so they're more like pre-placed upgrades than unexpected new things to enjoy having fun with. 

Secondly, the abilities have limited uses and cooldowns. So you're just encouraged to use the starting sword knight all the time. Even when you do use them they're pretty weak. You can upgrade them as the game goes on but there's really no point using them instead of the basic attack in the early game. You can use them in addition to the basic attack but there's little to no point unless you come across a kind of elite enemy. Even then, you're using up a resource that you might not get back for a while. So most players will likely get 'rpg syndrome' and try to avoid using them in case they need them later. Which basically means you might as well just 'get good' at using the sword and dodging. At which point there's no point having the extra abilities. 

Another issue I had with the game was that the atmosphere and story feels a bit too edgy and like it's trying too hard to be depressing. The music is pretty much all very nice sounding but minor slow haunt-y songs. They're good songs but again it just feels like the game is trying to be more depressing than dark souls. I think even the choice of main character was intended to do this, as a young girl having to basically go around and 'purify the dead' is essentially having a young girl go around saying goodbye to everyone she ever loved while she regains her memories of how much she loved them as she says goodbye. 

All in all, I can see this game appealing to people from an atmosphere and music perspective. The combat is passable and the one boss design I saw did seem cool and engaging. Ultimately though, it just didn't live up to the expectations I've grown to have of this kind of genre. There are a lot of much better metroidvanias out there. 
Plus, this game just rubbed me the wrong way. Castlevania combat but worse mixed with dark souls story but worse.
