137979991.review:
Ender Lilies is a fantastic Metroidvania experience. Here's a comprehensive spoiler-free review of it.

Story: 9/10
The story in this game is told in a similar fashion to Dark Souls. Similarly to there, you play as a witness of a dying world, and most of the story and past events is told through environmental storytelling and item descriptions. While I do generally like this manner of storytelling, I sometimes lost track of where the story was, certain characters involved, etc. I think the game could generally benefit by making things a bit clearer, but that might just be my own skill issue.

Gameplay: 8/10
The exploration and combat here are stellar and rival other Metroidvanias such as Hollow Knight. The main character, Lily, can't fight for herself, so she summons spirits of those she defeats to fight for her. You can have two sets of three spirits equipped, giving you the chance to mix and match them. On top of that, as you defeat bosses, you gain more abilities to traverse the world with, such as a dash, wall jump, and hookshot. The abilities and combat feel great to use, and a lot of the enemies throughout the world demand full use of that. It's interesting to see what combos work for each person. My one complaint is that a lot of rooms in the game seem like they just have enemies thrown in there, and it makes for a more tedious experience than a fun one.

Progression: 7/10
I've heard some reviews say that the game gets a bit empty towards the early midgame, but I never felt that. However, I did feel stuck in a lot of areas due to not having the required equipment. If you get this game, be prepared to backtrack. A lot. Additionally, the map doesn't help all that much. While it does have a room completion marker (which a lot of games DESPERATELY need), I can barely tell what area each room is in without having to teleport to a bench nearby.

Boss Fights: 7/10
A lot of the bosses strewn throughout the world are glorified enemies, allowing the player to get their spirit and use them in combat, which works pretty well. However, the real stars of the show are the true bossfights. They all have different phases, and keep you on your toes. In general, they're a lot of fun. However, true bosses are loaded with HP and take a while to kill. Add that to the fact that there are a few fights that feel a lot more tedious (looking at you Herrod) than the others, and some fights become more of a drag than a challenge. 

Score: 10/10
The soundtrack of this game is amazing. It perfectly encompasses the theme of every area, boss, and cutscene. I definitely added certain ones to my own personal playlist. My favorite has to be Accolades, both the Intro and Outro, though Bulbel gets a close second place.

Graphics: 10/10
Ender Lilies has a soothing artstyle that, like the music, ties together well with the game's atmosphere. It gives a lot of contrast between certain areas, especially between the bleak and dreary top half of the world and the vibrant colorful bottom half. 

Tl,dr:

Pros:
-Interesting story hidden throughout the game
-Fun gameplay which players mix and match for their own preferences.
-Fun bossfights and enemies.
-Amazing score and artstyle.

Cons:
-Story can get confusing at times.
-Progression requires loads of backtracking.
-Map should have the area on it.
-Many gank rooms and certain tedious bosses.

Overall though, despite its flaws, Ender Lilies has rightfully earned a spot in my top Metroidvanias. Beautiful work. I would love a sequel, DLC, or even another game entirely that expands upon the concepts introduced in this.

137974929.review:
Warning: This is a Soulsvania, not just a metroidvania.

This game is gorgeous. The graphics and the music are awesome.
The game itself is a metroidvania but with a big spoon of Darksouls. Nothing bad with that, if there weren't a few problems that make it frustrating:

1. Ennemies don't get staggered when you hit them with most attacks. Only some strong but very slow strong attacks can do that.
2. Ennemies can attack you while you are hitting them...
3. Whenever you use a spirit, your priestess does her own animation that is independent of that of the spirit. Problem is, you can't move or dodge until that animation is over, even in the air. 
4. Most enemy projectiles home on your position, either fully or partialy. The fast ones curve to get to you, which makes them annoyingly hard to dodge. Whoever thought that this was a good idea is crazy. lol
5. The game and the bosses are not really hard...until the last area. There are a TON of ennemies that can kill you in two hits and take a lot of punishment before going down. You are going to die a LOT. 
6.. The two last bosses have a ton of health and if you haven't grinded to level 90 at least, you will suffer.
7. The last boss... He spawns flying monsters that shoot fast curved fireballs on you that do a ton of damage. If you could easily destroy them, that would be fine. But no: even at level 90, having a fully upgraded umbra Knight and  a few others, they were hard to take down. And there can be up to 3 on screen, on top of the boss...
And there is more: to have the true ending, If you manage to beat him, you then have to beat him again while he does the same thing + new moves... And if you die, you restart the whole fight.

It's a gorgous game, but punishing for the wrong reasons.

137910456.review:
Overall, a nice Metroidvania that is challenging, but more than fair to the player and gives gives a LOT to work with.

- Gameplay is nice and smooth.  Nice and responsive controls that allows for a lot of movement options late in game.  It's not the most open movement, but it makes sense for the character.  Fighting feels decent with little to no delay (unless you go deep into combos).  Bosses are tough and REALLY emphasize pattern recognition, but are fair, especially with benches/ respites nearby.  Speaking of gameplay, there is a dodge mechanic and is nice & forgiving.  
- The utilizations of the spirits makes gameplay itself varied.  It allows a player to play the game the way they want to play.  Thumbs up, there.  
- The map in this game is one of the better ones that I've come across.  The color changes for item hunting and the clearly marked entrances makes things easier for exploration.  May still have to do some trial-and-error with exploring for progression, but it is still good.  
- There isn't much sign-posting, but the way this game is set-up allows for natural progression through the game (for the most part).  It also gives a good job of letting you know EXACTLY what to do to unlock special spoiler-free things.

Overall, highly recommend this game.  It's not my favorite Metroidvania, but it is super solid and can very much hold its own.  It's tough, but extremely forgiving in its execution (hard, but fair)

At first I wasn't going to give this game a chance. Many games get extremely good reviews just for having an anime aesthetic, and I thought this one was just another case of that. But after noticing the amount of reviews it has and not only the score, I decided that the game had to have something going for it. And oh boy if it has.

Ender Lilies is one of the best metroidvanias out there, and I've played most of them. I've seen reviews from people that don't like it saying it's too stiff but honestly I think that people forget that you also start the likes of Hollow Knight without abilities like the dash.

The game is beautiful, with the ever-present contrast between the pure and fragile protagonist and the rest of the world of corruption and agony you travel. The OST doesn't fall behind with most of the songs evoking the feeling of finding the beauty in a decaying world, I love it. And of course, the level design, combat and general game structure are really solid or I wouldn't be recommending it no matter how good it looked.

137762313.review:
Playing this after after experiencing some of the best metroidvanias of the last decade (Ori and the blind forest, Hollow Knight, Blasphemous, etc.) made me realize that the best word to describe Ender Lilies sadly is: Generic.

I'm a sucker for most souls-likes and metroidvania types of games (i've 100% every PC From Soft game except Sekiro), so the fact that i can't really recommend this game pains me deeply, since playing almost the entire game feels like a repetitive never ending experience where most encounters offer 0challenge (until you reach 2-3 extremely annoying difficulty spikes). 

The concept of a world ravaged by a Rain of Death instantly caught my attention, only to lose it after 2 hours of play. The fact that it dosn't interacts with any aspect of the gameplay was a complete disappointment, and though the effect of the rain is seen in the landscape to a great extent, the originality of the setting is let down by the repetitive areas and uninspired story and lore of the game. The word to describe most areas is again: generic. You explore a castle, a magic forest, sewers and catacombs that offer little to none redeeming qualities and have a soundtrack that can be a complete hit or miss, either it fits perfectly or it feels weirdly out of place. 

While the animations of the different movements you unlock by defeating mini-bosses and bosses are outstanding, the fact is that most of this abilities are gimmicks that you will most likely try once, see that they are inferior to the standard light and heavy attacks, never use them again.

Despite having an excellent art style, most enemies and bosses are boring beyond belief. You fight an amazing variety of enemies like a slime, bird, knight, knight with hammer, knight with spear, knight with shield knight with horse, gargoyle and so on. And the fact that the lackluster variety of enemies are recycled in later areas makes fighting them a chore. The same boring design is also applied to all the bosses (including the dissapointing final boss).

Luckily, the experience is not long at all, having managed to complete the game with all it's achievements in under 14 hs. 

Only buy this if you are desperate to play another metroidvania and if the game is on sale, but be aware that there are better alternatives almost everywhere.

- Abilities gathered from defeated bosses. You can choose 2 sets of 3 abilities bound to X, Y and B buttons. Feature which certainly elevated the gameplay, it was fun to experiment with different combos to defend Emily and reach secret areas.
- Map + unpicked collectibles indication. The map is implemented well. Individual areas were displayed in the form of boxes with lines between them indicating open paths. Also the box color (blue vs. yellow) simply indicates whether or not you found everything there. Simple, functional, no handholding too much.

Negatives:
- Soundtrack, definitely the weakest aspect of the game. People are praising it because of its author and they like her songs, I don't care as a game soundtrack it's trash. Unfitting, unreactive, inconsistent, repetitive, and maybe 20% percent of areas are in complete silence... awful I've not heard worse background "music" in a game for a long time.

Nitpicks:
- I still have no idea, what the benches are sorted by in the Fast Travel menu. It just jumps around the map.
- After you spawn on a bench, you have to click to get up which takes a few seconds and then if you want to access it you have to click to sit again. Does it make sense not really, is it annoying, definitely.
-  The shield cuck knights are not very well designed. No vulnerabilities, block everything and does a tun of damage. No they're not nowhere near the ending area.

Technical notes:
- runs flawlessly on Steam Deck
- getting 100% is attainable on the 1st playthrough without too much grind

Muy sólido metroidvania. Al principio no me enganchó, pero poco a poco me fue gustando cada vez más.
El diseño de niveles es bastante bueno y hay mucha variedad de enemigos y entornos. Muchos jefes que cada uno te da un tipo diferente de arma que hace muy variado el gameplay, un sistema de amuletos muy similar al de hollow knight que permite que cada uno adapte la jugabilidad a su manera de jugar y por último una enorme variedad de entornos. 
Después en el apartado artístico tenemos una hermosa banda sonora con muchos pianos y ilustraciones y animaciones excelentes.
Pero no todo es tan hermoso: hay muchos jefes, pero los que no son de la historia principal son simples rediseños de enemigos comunes con más vida y daño que no presentan ningún reto, y los que sí son de la historia son tremendas esponjas de daño que no tienen sentido. Aún así son muy variados (los de la historia) y divertidos de luchar, pero creo que si tuvieran la mitad de la vida serían incluso mejores. También el combate tiene MUY poco feedback, con lo que me costó agarrarle la mano al principio, pero una vez te acostumbrás no resulta un problema.
De la historia no me enteré una mierda porque te la cuentan mediante documentos que encontrás explorando y me dió mucha paja leerlos

En conclusión, es un gran metroidvania, no lo posicionaría como uno de los grandes de los últimos tiempos como Hollow Knight o Aeterna Noctis, pero sí que es una propuesta bastante sólida con un toquesito soulsliek que le queda de maravilla

137080385.review:
[h1]Pros[/h1]
 + Combat feels great. It's the exact kind of slower paced methodical fighting that you find in the Dark Souls series when they're at their best.
 + The atmosphere is fantastic, music and environments come together to really create the sense of a world that has fallen entirely to ruin.
 + The platforming is pretty good, Heonir's ability in particular is a lot of fun to play around with.
 + The main bosses are very good. And are foreshadowed pretty well. There's only one name I read and expected to be a boss who wasn't one, other than that, whenever the game made me think "oh boy, I bet I'm gonna fight [name]", that was on the mark.
 + Pretty much all enemy types also have a miniboss variant, so if you want completion, you have to really learn how to beat each of them.
 + Beating a boss (main or mini) always gives a new spirit, which means each boss feeds directly into unlocking new options in combat.
 + This game has an interesting approach to the classic Metroidvania issue of "how do we try and set this ability up for both combat and exploration use" by simply saying, "alright, whenever we give an exploration ability, we also give a spirit (a new attack) at the same time." This does work pretty well.
[h1]Cons[/h1]
 - The game could have more content. There's only 9/10 main bosses (depending on how you count it). Getting all endings and fully exploring every room on the map took me only 20 hours.
 - The final boss was a bit underwhelming, particularly the rematch for ending C, which just adds a new fight vs. the same boss, that judging by my single fight with it is easier than the original.
 - While I did eventually solve them, some of the optional puzzles kinda broke the norms established by how exploration worked in the entire rest of the game, making their solutions a bit unintuitive to me.

All in all, I think if you like Dark Souls, I suspect you'll like Ender Lillies. I'd wish there was more game to play, but for €25, this is still a pretty good deal. And "I'd wish there was more of it" isn't the worst complaint you can have about a game.

137079372.review:
If you like the metroidvania genre you'll love this game. The art at first was kind of meh to me (it was good but nothing crazy) but towards the end I fell in love with it. Incredible character designs and all the zones are beautiful. My personal favorite part of this game was the music, I'll usually play a video on my phone while I play games but with this game I found myself pausing the music during every boss fight because the music for each is so fitting and whenever the boss's phase changes, the music does as well (mostly keeping the same sound but with added stuff that makes it even more intense/stressful (look up Knight Captain Julius's theme, absolute banger.) Imo the story was cool but kinda lacking (then again I hardly ever pay close attention to the story in most games. All the different abilities and attacks you get mesh together really well and allow you to do some sick movement and chain attacks on bosses, once you figure out whats possible. The exploration is a little confusing because it lacks a little direction (its fine enough to get to the end but if you want to 100% you'll need a little googling) but compared to most metroidvanias I'd say it does a little better (the maps let you know if you're missing anything from the zone, real completionist friendly.  

My only complaints on this game have to do with the more early game content: for a platformer, the movement (like walk speed and jump height is pretty low) but once you progress its fine enough (still kinda slow imo but i guess thats personal preference).  Secondly the boss difficulty was a little over the place, most of the bosses had a similar difficulty (a welcome challenge, not so difficult to the point of annoyance, maybe like 5-10 attempts) but some were really hard (still the fun level of challenge) and idk if its because I had a cheesy build or what but the final boss was incredibly easy. I didn't mind this too much because I really liked the bosses design (probs top 5 imo) but it would've been better otherwise. And lastly, my only pet peeve of this game: autoclimbing ledges. Idk who you think you are but never put auto mantling in any game, especially a platformer. You can turn on a setting that lets you cancel auto mantle with a down input, but at that point why not just make that default and make a setting to disable it entirely?

TLDR: I had a phenomenal time with this game and 100% it with all achievos, and unlike most games, it didn't feel like a chore to 100%. It was fun the entire time, isn't annoying to grind, and is a game you can set down for months, come back and still enjoy (which is what I did cuz of time issues.) Highly recommend for anyone that likes indie games, souls-like games, and/or platformers. I think it takes some of the best aspects of many game genres and bundles them together in a way that isn't overwhelming.

Ты просто исследуешь локацию, тут же внезапный босс файт, а музыке просто алмазно наплевать на происходящее, я тут чилю нафиг.
Боёвка... Боже блин, какой это позор. Перекаты неудобные от слова пипец. Оружие = закликивание одной кнопки. Да, тут есть попытка разнообразия геймплея за счёт механики духов, которые кастуются, как спелы на отдельные кнопки, но это дичь. Возможно я избаловал себя метроидваниями в лице ori или hk, не знаю, но вот вообще не могу в это играть.

Ender Lilies es un juego precioso, toma el estilo narrativo de "descubre la historia leyendo objetos" y lo combina con un estilo estético que evoca la fantasía de cuentos clásicos, sumado a una banda sonora para la cual la palabra "preciosa" se queda corta, la combinación de estos elementos logran construir un mundo oscuro y melancólico, un reino caído en la ruina que como jugador debes explorar para descubrir que sucedió y lo más importante, como se resuelve la historia de Lily.

Ender Lilies boasts stunning art and beautiful music, which are the highlight of the experience in my opinion. 

The gameplay can be challenging, but it never feels too unfair, and it encourages you to experiment with different attacks. However, it can feel a bit clunky at time, especially during the first hour of gameplay, until you get the first ability of the game.

The game tells its story through beautiful animated panels, environmental storytelling, and a few item descriptions. While it lacks a bit of depth, it's not bad at all. If you're willing to invest some effort into it, you can find some interesting aspects in the story, even if things appears unclear during gameplay. 

Overall, it's a good Metroidvania game, even though it doesn't revolutionize the genre and is a bit short. Nonetheless, it's still a good buy.

136725264.review:
This game has moved its way into my top 10 favorite games of all time.

The Pros:
— Generally open-ended Metroidvania. Only one or two areas are mandatory for one of the endings.
— The music is AMAZING. It breathes life into the game in a way I have not seen in a long time.
— The visuals and attention to detail is superb. Area designs are distinct enough you can tell each one apart easily
— The writing for this game is surprisingly deep. It legitimately surprised me how in-depth it is

Cons:
— Combat’s a little clunky. Just like Dark Souls you can work your way into it and it feels satisfying at the end of it all, but certain mechanics weren’t worth mastering.

— Stilted setup for 100% completion. Around the 98% complete mark there were certain jumping puzzles where it felt necessary to utilize extra mobility from particular spirits. If you were to miss them for a most of the game it would leave the player confused for many hours.

— Difficulty plateaus too quickly.  I beat all of the content in the game aside from the ‘Level 100’ achievement by level 90. The last 10 levels were a grind-fest and if not for the achievement I would of stopped playing before hitting it.

Overall the game was an amazing play. I was able to approach the game my own way and even did a few areas to completion in different ways than would normally approached. 

The game rewards keen eyes and good location-based memory. Remembering trends of the environment can lead to genuine ‘aha!’ moments after unlocking certain abilities and back-tracking to see if it works.

Even with its faults, this game is an absolute masterpiece and its music will forever live on my cell phone!

Pros:
 1.Great Combat system where you have to mix up your guardians to achieve different builds. 
2. Enemies are varied and offer different challenges due to placement throughout level, they also act as foreshadows to boss encounters. 
3. Level design is text book but offer alot of opportunity to explore.

So uh... Don't get me wrong, this is not a bad game. However it's also not good one. It's... Decent I guess. The story is deep and well written, art style is overall nice and music is really great. However, let's address the elephant in the room: Metroidvanias are mostly about exploration and combat. And the latter here sucks. The attacks are clunky, most of them are worthless (either lack of range or speed) don't feel impactful and their animations are janky because of the art style. While the art style itself is beautiful, it's much more fit for static imagery, not animated objects, and it certainly shows. As for music, there's Mili, which means it's fan freaking tastic. But apart from Mili other songs are also really nice and fitting. The way the character changes across the game is also something really nice and I appreciate it's on the in-game model and not just kept for story bits.

TL;DR: Game good, combat sucks ass.

136562913.review: Ender Lilies is the underdog rogue-like video game that I never thought to try before. At the start you feel super weak your dodge is a leap that has you slide on the ground and then slowly stand up for example.

While your toolkit will be the same as other player end game you may have completely different combat Spirits then I did. (Giant Mace FTW)

The world of Ender is in a ruined kingdom ala Dark Souls, everyone is dead or stuck undead/mutated from the corrupting rain that killed the lucky and mutated the rest. 

You'll journey across the huge ruined kingdom getting bits of lore and the occasional chime in from your trusty knight.

All I can say further without spoiling it is.

If you're looking for a stellar Metroidvania then look no further.

Here's hoping a sequel of sorts gets made.

136500072.review:
Ender Lilies is an excellent game and deserves to be recognized as such. If you're a metroidvania fan, you'll appreciate the game's challenging difficulty, which is very similar to the Souls series, especially with regard to the bosses.
The story of Ender Lilies is one of its strongest points. It is told in a non-linear way, through cutscenes and interactions with the characters, which makes the plot quite interesting and captivating. The game world is full of mysteries and secrets, and it is a pleasure to explore and find out more about it.
The game is also visually stunning. The art style is dark and macabre, with a dark and oppressive color palette, which perfectly matches the melancholic atmosphere of the story. Each region in the game is unique and presents specific challenges, making exploration even more enjoyable and rewarding.
Ender Lilies' soundtrack is one of its highlights. It is composed of beautiful and emotional music, which creates a perfect atmosphere for the story and gameplay. Each song is carefully chosen to match the events of the story, making the experience even more immersive.

All in all, Ender Lilies is an amazing game that combines challenging gameplay with an engaging story and an outstanding soundtrack. If you're a metroidvania fan, you can't miss this game!

136378365.review:
To preface this review, I want to say that I have played a lot of metroidvanias, and a lot of souls-likes. Ender Lilies is a game that wants to be both, but really kinda fails to hit high marks on either. I finished the game with the "bad" ending, and I truly have no desire to play it any further to get the good one. This game frustrates me for a few reasons.
[olist]
[*][b]Pacing.[/b] Each major boss is an ordeal that when beaten rewards you with a weapon, a movement ability, and sometimes a slight increase to the amount you heal, and that's it. There are health upgrades in the game, but they're scattered around, usually hidden in boxes or behind secret walls, often inaccessible until you gain the aforementioned movement abilities, and usually for a measly +5HP apiece. When everything in the game deals a minimum of 30 for just touching them, this feels like an insult for the effort spent to get the extra health in the first place. Contrast with, say, Metroid games, where an energy tank might take similar effort to get but provide enough to survive more than a few hits on contact from fodder enemies on its own.

The leveling systems are also a major pacing issue for me. Most of the spirits in the game upgrade with one of two resources, which are available in small chunks in some areas similar to health upgrades, but you can also get them in smaller amounts seemingly by just breaking pots. These upgrade resources are lacking a clarity of purpose that could have instead gone hand-in-hand with the hilariously neglected player leveling system. Maybe leveling up could have provided you with at least a handful of these resources rather than just a flat (and negligible) boost to attack. Why does this game have a leveling system for the player at all? Even with what I thought was a fair amount of struggle and re-killing enemies over and over, I ended the game at a far lower level (low-60s) than other people seem to have. Was I supposed to be grinding? Big no-no. If I want to grind, I'll go play a JRPG. 

To give an example, I experienced no worse feeling in the game than finding a creative solution to get to Ulv (parrying the flying enemies with Headless Knight kills them almost instantly where otherwise they were quite tanky) only to realize upon reaching him and finding some guides that I was hilariously underleveled and lacking in health, relics, and spirit upgrades. So I had to LEAVE, grind up, gain about 100 health, and then come back, and the fight became easy. Thankfully, the fast travel system in this game is very open, otherwise I might've quit then and there. If you want the player to not explore an area until they are higher level, that should be made clear much earlier than right at the boss's doorstep. Contrast to Dark Souls, there is an early game trap where the player might go a couple different places by mistake, but it's clear almost immediately these are places you should not be yet.

[*][b]Combat.[/b] I'm not here to say it's too hard. I certainly struggled, but I get that that's the point. What bothers me most about the combat is that it rarely asks more of the player than some smartly timed dodges/parries followed by mashing the damage-dealing button of your choice. This in effect presents the souls-like element of the game, which is frustratingly dull in 2D. It's lacking the spice that I would hope to see in a metroidvania, especially one that gives you abilities like a grappling hook and a wall cling. Without integrating those into combat, not only is combat itself left out to dry, the movement abilities are also relegated to little more than fancy keys. It would've been nice to see a boss arena or two with close walls or grapple points scattered around, and forced you to use them to avoid attacks. Instead, every arena is an empty rectangle of varying dimensions.

Combat itself, in the way the devs intended, can still get a bit fiddly. Big AOE attacks and pillars and things aren't always clear about when their hitbox starts and stops, or even sometimes WHERE they start and stop. This leads to some amount of trial and error and a lot of "really? that hit me?" that I didn't care for. The when and where could've both been fixed with more clearly-defined borders rather than soft gradients. I'm also just not a fan of damage-on-contact in general, but it's especially pronounced here when the player's true position can get obscured between your spirits, enemies, and their respective projectiles and other visual effects. That buildup of clarity loss led to more deaths than I care to admit. Contrast to another game with damage-on-contact like Hollow Knight, there are rarely clarity issues there because you and many enemies are big mono-color things with thick black borders.

The one credit that I will give to Ender Lilies' combat is that the variety of attack options is quite refreshing, even if I found myself sticking to three or four options. There are a variety of playstyles that seem to be viable, even just hanging back and throwing projectiles, which is quite unusual to see in a melee-focused game like this.

[*][b]The Map.[/b] Oh my god, the map! I don't know what they were thinking with this, the damn thing provides less useful information than I would've gotten from no map at all. If you do buy this game, do yourself a favor and find a map online or in one of the guides on Steam. It's so bad. You will get lost, because the connections between rooms are unclear, and every room will eventually bleed into one another in your brain because even though the game says it's split into ten or so unique areas, it doesn't show this on the map at all.

[*][b]Art Direction.[/b] While the hand-drawn aesthetic is very technically impressive and I'm sure a lot of love went into it, it's just so, so depressing. Aside from some slightly-different color cues, the areas are barely distinguishable from one another. Foreground objects will look like walls in cases where they quite often are not, leading the player to second-guess and hump every wall on the off chance that it's either a secret or just a poorly-placed pillar. Background objects are sometimes walkable platforms and sometimes not. Enemy animations are mostly tweened because I'm sure the budget went almost entirely to just drawing them with as much detail as possible. Every aspect is lacking consistency in some way or another.

[*][b]Story.[/b] Or... what there is of one. It's at the bottom of my list because I recognize that it's the least important aspect of any metroidvania, but what's here is incredibly hard to want to engage with. Every story beat is told either through ambient dialogue from the first spirit you pick up, or bits of paper penned by various seen and unseen characters, or slideshow cutscenes. The sum of those parts is the standard hits of a dark fantasy "world's gone to hell but maybe you can make it better" plotline without much new to say or new ways to say it. 
[/olist]
So, yeah. I can recognize that Ender Lilies on the whole is a very pretty game, and definitely a strong first outing for its developers. However, there are too many little things that add up to a major detraction from the overall experience for me to recommend with my whole chest the way I will for some other metroidvanias and souls-likes. I recognize also that public opinion seems very love-it-or-hate-it split on this game (even though that doesn't seem to show in the Steam reviews), and while I think "hate it" would be a strong term for my feelings on the game, I definitely don't love it or even like it all that much.

If you haven't had your fill of drab dark fantasy, by all means buy this game. Maybe get it on a sale if you're not sure. Maybe you'll fall in the "love it" camp, but for your reference I would consider the metric for that to fall right around the fight with Gerrod. If you're not having a good time with the game by then, you probably will not magically start having a good time further in.

In my opinion, if the game had these specific elements more organized, more composed or maybe a little bit more complicated, it would've been a masterpiece;

So game's map has these elements; showing up which level ur at, which levels does that level connect to, which routes have you not cleared yet, and if you've completely explored that level or not. Can't believe I missed this game for so many years. Finally played, and loved every minute of it.
- Amazing music
- Beautiful character, graphics.
- Love the girl using "stand" spirits, the effects are nice.
They are well balanced, and using them to perform "tricks" to reach hidden areas is fun.
- Most MV games I often feel overwhelmed when there's so many places I can't go, so many items I can't reach. But this game make that "gated progress" amount just right.
Especially with the smart map that changes color when you've fully explored / found hidden items, is really really great idea.
- The souls-like formula is perfect. No enemy respawn when you change screen. The difficulty is perfectly challenge. The NG+ is absolute fun if you love Sekiro / Wo Long NG+ / Nioh challenge.
- Small enemies have "move sets" that is souls-like. The boss fights are fun.
- No pitfalls and spikes!! I really have to admire dev for not putting them in!
I mean I've been playing games since late 80s, and dying from pitfalls, spikes are just lame and old.
I didn't finish Hollow Knight because of the annoyance of all the spikes ant pitfalls.
It's already 2000s, why still using / giving these same obstacle to gamers?

I might sound a bit over, but I really really enjoyed EL much more than I expected.
Only thing I wish is dev could add and "infinite parry spirit mode" that I can play it like Sekiro on NG+

Devs, thank you for this masterpiece.
Cheers.

136045938.review:
Ender lillies is a game that I've had in my sights for a long time, almost since launch I've had an interest in the game, but I never found the time to actually get it. Recently I've been going through my wishlist looking for promising games that work well on the Steamdeck, and this one finally got enough reasons for me to actually get. 

Owh boy, I should've gotten this game way earlier.

I started my playthrough on the steamdeck, where it ran without any issues (as advertised, really), and immediately after defeating the first boss I knew that this is a game I would want to 100%, as the fluid and smooth gameplay immediately stuck with me. 

The game is quite open ended, especially compared to most metroidvanias, where you can even get the metroidvania-style abilities in different orders. (without using sequence breaks) Along with this it doesn't feel unnecessarily challenging to go to a "later" area before you've gone to prior areas, as I found no impassible challenge exploring some of the later areas before you're supposed to be there. (with one small exception which will be quite obvious when you find it)

It took me about 20 hours to get 100% in this game, 14 of which were played on the steamdeck and the final 6 were played on my home pc, neither of them had any issue running the game, infact, playing it on my pc made me realize that the game natively detects ps4 controllers and adjusts the button prompts, which is a much appreciated feature for someone that often switches between a ps4 controller on pc, and the steamdeck (which uses xbox buttonfaces)

The music and atmosphere in this game is amazing individually, but not just that, they compliment eachother a lot, and this, along with the design of the characters in the game, are used as a storytelling tool, something the game does really well without pushing it in your face with long cutscenes that drag on.

Difficulty wise the game feels easier to me than some other metroidvanias, especially if you are persistent in gathering items and powerups, yet it doesn't feel like the game doesn't put up a fight, for some of the final bosses I really felt like I accomplished something beating them, yet they never felt too spammy or unfairly balanced, not even when fighting them out of order.

The game has multiple endings, and personally they, in a way, remind me of Hollow knight's endings, albeit more happy. Infact, if any of you are waiting for Silksong and probably have 20 ish hours to spare before its release, I highly recommend you pick it up!

My only "complaint" with the game is that it is a little bit on the expensive side for how much time it takes to 100% (blind), especially since the soundtrack (which is worth getting) is € 15,99, with the game being € 24,99, that makes for basically € 40, with 20 hours played, that's roughly € 2,- per hour, which is a lot for me. That being said, the game has build in challenge and boss rush modes that I am probably gonna get another 20 or so hours out of, bringing it down to a potential € 1,- per hour.

All in all I give this game a 9/10 rating, 9.5/10 if bought on sale for sure.

136027115.review:
The game may seem to be overpriced upon initial glance, but the soundtrack, the plot, and the experience of persisting through the endless nightmare of the blighted rain, came truly priceless. Sure, the combat system and the map design is arguably poorly conceived, yet it does not diminish the positive aspects of the game. 

Would definitely recommend this game to others. After finishing the 3 endings, I oftentimes just open the game, jump to a checkpoint of my choice, and let the music play on the background. At times, I would recall all the scenes of me beating this game. How I danced with Ulv, battled with Julius, and put Miriel to sleep. At times I would ask myself: "why didn't I do more." Unfortunately, I can't. 

As of now, I hope the game can have a sequel, as the experience is something that I will remember for years. The game is a solid 10/10 for me.

136020724.review: An enchanting metroidvania with beautiful visuals, lovely OST (by Mili), and fluid gameplay. There's plenty of relics that affect your stats (like increasing your health, your speed, upping your defenses etc.), as well as spirits that serve as different type of attacks which you acquire after you have defeated bosses and mini bosses. Of course, you can only equip a limited number of relics and spirits otherwise it would have been too easy. It's not a difficult game especially since there's no penalty upon dying and fast travel is available early-on in the game which makes backtracking a lot easier. My only complaint about Ender Lilies is its story. It's very cliche and predictable but considering everything else about the game is solid, it's not much of a big deal. I also like that you can replay boss fights and that the map shows if you've found all of the collectibles in each area which is handy for completionists.

136013527.review:
Ender Lilies is a beautiful and hauntingly poetic game with a deep and engrossing lore. The game's stunning art style perfectly captures the game's dark and mysterious atmosphere, immersing players in a world of ruins and corruption. The haunting soundtrack adds to the game's eerie ambiance, creating a sense of foreboding and unease that perfectly matches the game's tone. I just love how everything comes together.

The boss battles are challenging, but very rewarding. Defeating bosses unlocks abilities that they previously used against you in the battle, which allows players to expand and customize their arsenal of attacks. This feature adds a nice layer of strategy to the game, making it even more exciting to progress and obtain more abilities.

The game absolutely nails it's setting, the atmosphere and story elements are really well executed, the art is gorgeous and the soundtrack really completes the experience. Absolutely a 10/10 game that I could happily recommend to literally everyone.

135851068.review:
Fans of Vanillaware games would be right at home with the amazing artwork and music. There's some pretty deep lore and history behind the world & characters, despite how stingy the game tends to be at spoon-feeding the details to the players. The player essentially has to piece together clues (the environments, along with items they pick up) the series of events that took place through multiple eras, leading up to Land's End falling to the Blight.

The gameplay can be pretty slow at first. But that's fairly standard for games such as this one. I've seen several reviews complaining about the controls - specifically the dodge function. I never actually noticed anything wrong with it. The player is controlling a somewhat defenseless child, after all. And the dodge does get upgraded eventually. The density of the number of enemies in the latter stages did get a bit crazy down the line, but it wasn't unbearable. It's just difficult enough to be incredibly satisfying once you clear a difficult area or make it to the next respite. And unlike many games in this genre / style nowadays, it doesn't really punish you very much for dying. You always feel a sense of progress and forward momentum even during the times where you do end up dying and respawning at the previous checkpoint. I try to complete as much of every game I play, but I'm not quite a completionist. There are some achievements and challenges which simply take too much time and effort for me. But Ender Lilies' pacing was just right, so that I organically reached 100% completion without going out of my way for specific achievements.

If you're thinking of picking this game up but are still on the fence, I suggest just pulling the trigger and getting it. I was in that position for a few months, and I don't regret my decision at all.

135668411.review:
Ender Lilies is a somewhat okay game, with fatal flaws that are unacceptable.

I won't touch on the graphics and sound design of the game, it's good and deserves praise.

My main complaints are:
1. The story is a blatant, boring, convoluted and meaningless copy of Hollow Knight.
2. Bad game and level design.
3. Enemy and boss damage scaling is INSANE.
4. Genuinely pointless leveling systems.
5. Relics don't offfer a lot variety.
6. Abilities/spirits offer variety but no usefulness and upgrading is a chore.

I'll go through my complaints point by point to stay concise, but i'll most likely ramble so have fun.

1. The story is an actual nuisance to the game.
The only way to describe Ender Lilies' story is cringe. Not only because it's quite literally a copy of Hollow Knights story (to the point you can't even argue that it's using common metroidvania tropes), but also because it's so painfully trying to be deep and mysterious.
The story starts in a dilapitated kingdom, where all residents succumbed to a mysterious sickness and became these emotionless, hollow, zombified creatures without consciousness. You, as the Vessel, err I mean as the White Priestess are tasked to purify these people by taking on their Blight. Sound familiar? I mean Ender Lilies' STORY CULMINATES IN AN AREA THAT'S LITERALLY CALLED THE ABYSS. 
The story is told through cutscenes after boss fights, and lore letters. The letters were fine to read, but didn't add that much to the game. The main problem with the cutscenes is that the game expects you to have an emotional connection with the characters from the get go. I think every boss fight is meant to feel like a fight to offer your friends salvation - but it doesn't. You don't know these characters, you start as a girl with no voice and no memories. These characters do not mean anything to you. All cutscenes play out the same. It's nothing but a depressed circle jerk containing one of two phrases: "I couldn't protect her" or "I'm full of guilt".
Towards the end of it the story genuinely left a bad taste in my mouth. Because there is no narration they cannot convey a wide spectrum of emotional depth and resort to cringe ass dogshit LiKe wRiTiNG lIKe ThiS BEcAuSE tHe cHaracTer is SAd.

2. Unremarkable areas and bad game design for a metroidvania.
Most areas look good, but that's about it. Mid- to late-game areas are a convoluted and disorienting mess. The map tells you only in which room you are, but because room sizes differ wildly, but still look the same on maps, you have no real sense of orientation.
The only memorable area is the Verboten Domain (why this needs the german expression of forbidden, I cannot say) , but for all the wrong reasons. The other areas were tolerable at best but this dogshit had me contemplating to uninstall the game and remove it from my account. This area is a cesspool of poison clouds, insanely strong enemies and poisoned water. Just standing there does like 10 damage a second. You're pretty much required to equip a relic, which you can only find if you go through 1 of the 2 entrances of the Verboten Domain. But even with that, you can't freely explore because your healthbar becomes a clock counting to your inevitable death.
Most areas offer collectibles in every room, and you'll have to backtrack to every room after every boss. The game tells you which rooms you have fully cleared, but the game will put you in rooms where you need ability 1, 2, 3 and 4 just to collect all items. And the worst thing is, there are no real collectibles. You'll only find relics or upgrade materials, thats it. There is nothing more to explore.

3. Enemy and Boss damage scaling is the worst I've ever seen.
It's not even funny how fucking bad enemy health and damage is. I kid you not even with all three damage reducing relics equipped enemies in the last area kill you in 3 hits, they're all playing with actual military grade lasers while you're standing there with a soft dick in your hand. It's just not fun. It's not even an issue of skill anymore, it's just plain old bad game design. The game feels like it has no real progression. Yeah you get more stuff and new abilities and enemies get stronger, but it always feels like you're stuck in the first stages, where you can't really do anything. What's really bad as well, is that the game punishes you severely for getting hit, but expects you to kill everything hitless while being locked in 30 different 5 second animations you can't cancel simultaneously. It just gets so tiring.
The bosses were okay until the penultimate and final boss. I won't even do the true ending because it's way too punishing. The game went from semi-challenging boss fights to undodgeable bullet hell fuckery.
Also all bosses feel the same, because they play out the same. First Phase until 60% boss health, then second phase at 20-40% boss health and finally third phase at 0-20% boss health.

4. Pointless leveling systems.
You have Exp in this game and can level to 100. Nice, but for what? There is no point to actually leveling your character, it's just something that happens. You don't get extra hp (you get these by collecting amulet fragments that give you +5 hp, again really bad game design), there is no skill tree, there are no deep stats, there is however an attack stat that gets progressively higher. But it's all just so pointless. Once you're halfway through enemy damage scales considerably while your damage output remains almost the same until the very end. 

5. Relic/charm system is bad.
It's Hollow Knights charm system but considerably worse. Relics just offer procentual stat increases. Move a bit faster, increase you EXP, increase your damage, decrease your cooldown. Thats it.  There is no depth to it, it's just there to be there. And anyways they don't do shit. As I said before, even with ALL health upgrades, all health increase and enemy damage decrease relics equipped, enemies in the last area kill you in 3-5 hits.

6. Abilities offer no usefulness.
Technically there is a lot of variety to the abilities you can use. But there are no real combos and synergies between all these variants and a lot of them feel the same. The game just throws them at you and expects you to praise them for including all of these abilities on the surface level. The other issue at hand is the way you upgrade your skills. You collect blight which randomly drops from breakable objects or which you can pick up as collectibles. Then you upgrade your abilities. But you cannot respec. You basically have like 30 sub and main abilities but no way of interchanging them because all blight you invest is gone. So if you find ability variant 1 2 hours into the game, proceed to use and upgrade it for the next 8 hours, then find the same effect in ability variant 2 you've basically wasted your resources. 

I geniunely can't recommend this game.

135643434.review:
Bought it during EA years ago, played a bit, realised I liked it and decided to wait until it fully launched to play it all the way through. Over this past weekend finally had the time to play it since it's launch in 2021 and it was a great experience.

Glad I waited for the game to be done before putting my full time into it, and regretting not playing it sooner after it's launch.

The art is gorgeous! I really love this painterly puppet/spine style animation. However so often in games it looks awkward and stiff but the animators that worked on this did a killer job keeping all the motion feeling tight and fluid. Plus the absolute top quality!

The game respects your time too. There wasn't any grind heavy moments. They put a marker on map areas that don't have any secrets left, they have a marker for map transitions you haven't gone through. Outside a couple collectables I managed to find them all without looking them up after I beat the last boss. 

[b]Here's a bunch of smaller things that I liked:[/b]
The areas felt distinct, and the drip feed of new mechanics and moves kept exploring feeling good. Each of the enemies attacks had a readable tell that was easy to spot even in a hectic multi enemy fight. The different skills felt fun to use and experiment with. The boss fights were great, and a whole bunch of them took several attempts to beat! The game wasn't punishing for dying, which was nice because it had some really challenging areas that took a bunch of tries to fully explore. The game ended with me wanting more, which is awesome because so often I get bored of a game before the end.

[b]These negatives are pretty minor but:[/b] 
If you want to max out every skill the grind for materials after the non-re-spawning loot piles are gone is... veeery slow. However you get a lot more materials than you'd need to max out a full set of skills, plus maybe 3-4 extra. The game left me wanting more, which is nice but at the same time I still kinda want more.

I can't wait to see what this studio makes next!

135438041.review: Considering I had this game at the top of my wishlist for about a year, I was honestly really surprised at how disappointing it was when I finally purchased it.  Watching videos of it made me assume this game would totally be up my alley.  Ended up being nothing but a slog to play through, with virtually no high points at all.  The graphics are kinda nice, I guess I can say that, although hardly mind-blowing next-gen stuff here.[hr][/hr]The killer for this game are the controls.  They're just sluggish and bad, with commitments to slow animations that can't be canceled.  Overpress a command once and you're committed to the attack with no way to cancel out of it and dodge.  Every button press has to be deliberate and methodical with no room for mistakes.  That's fine enough in general combat, but irredeemable on boss fights.  The fact that bosses are given insane reach and teleporting abilities doesn't help.[hr][/hr]Boss fights are just boring slugfests with HP sponges where you can't even combo without the AI getting in a cheap shot.  That means every strategy is just single hit, dodge, dodge, dodge, wait for an opening, single hit, dodge, repeat.  Long and slow, with terrible command response.  You saw their attack coming from a screen away and you hit dodge for the millionth time?  Too bad, we're gonna get wonky with the timing and make you take two hits anyway, just to spice things up.  There's no way to tell how big your character's hit box actually is because you'll be taking hits even when you dodge out of the way.  Why even bother to play a game when they punish you the same whether you're hyper-aggressive or hyper-cautious?  Honestly, this game goes in the trash heap.

135279274.review:
I fell out of playing games for a few years besides some world of warcraft. Recently I was homeless and having a bad time, so I decided to try and fill my time with hobbies. I started hiking/walking for an hour every day. I also decided to start playing castlevania games. I had heard so much about SOTN but never played it much.I got sucked in. I'm currently playing 5 metroidvanias right now. Out of all of the ones I've played, outside of the castlevania series, Ender Lillies is by the my favorite. Something the castlevania series (aside from maybe order of ecclasia) lacked was difficutly with the bosses. Most difficulty derived itself from just being unfair but the games had ways to overcompensate either through grinding drops or finding secrets or learning enemy weaknesses, or whatever. The bosses were almost always easier than expected in those games. With many games invigorated by souls-like boss complexity and it's mixture with 2-d being well explored in other games it was natural that it would come to metroid vanias. Ender Lillies perfectly captures the reward for exploration and bosses that are hard but not too ridicolously hard. I got a house and pulled out my computer for the first time in like a year to play some games. Naturally I turned to metroidvanias on the PC. Ender Lillies was among one of the ones I originally pirated. I got Gerrard and the witch dead before I KNEW I NEEDED TO BUY THIS GAME ON STEAM. I have not completed it yet but this game is great. The difficulty thing though? In my first fight of Gerrard I think I was level 25. This play though I killed him at level 14. If you know the enemies well enough and have the tenacity, then you can fight most things in this game regardless of level. At least so far I think that. Meaning mechanics are rewarding to learn. Mechanics are relatively simple too and you need only learn the enemies attack patterns. It's interesting enough for roaming and puzzle solving. The bosses are touch but they all have 3 phases and you'll get better at these each fight without it being so entirely demanding you want to break stuff. Sometimes it gets close I guess lol. Leveling doesn't increase your health. It increases your damage, 1 for odd levels and 2 for even levels. It is more significant to upgrade your abilities for singificant damage increases but levels are there too. I just don't think you need to spend hours grinding out levels to fight a boss for the before mentioned reason and this one as well. It's much better to just get good at predicting the bosses attacks and making use of dodge or jump and getting your hits in. Sometimes bosses have periodic animations that knock back without doing damage. I like to heal when these happen, because the boss cannot be hurt during this animation but also doesn't do any damage to you. The game rewards exploration and back tracking. You'll get new items or spells with new bosses and minibosses and going back will net new rewards. These are usually so far affects on the environment. Like a new spell or ability can be used to open the way to a new route or item or needed resource.

The game can eventually become a bit overwhelming with exploration mechanics. To the point they are probably too far in number and sometimes leave you frustrated, because of no clear direction. The game will certainly reward you with exploration but also attempt to overwhelm you with many areas and the rewards have a lot of variety. I think this aspect of the game was done best at the beginning and becomes too numerous and time consuming later making me want to close the game after a short while of exploring.

135192106.review:
[h1]=== SETUP ===[/h1]
CPU🔩: Intel Core I9 13900K
GPU📼: RTX 4090 24 GB (AORUS GIGABYTE)
RAM⚙️: Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro, 5600 MHz 32GB


[h1]=== GRÁFICOS ===[/h1]
[b]Resolución:[/b] 2560x1440
[b]Calidad gráfica utilizada:[/b] Máxima
[b]RTX:[/b] No tiene
[b]DLSS:[/b] No tiene

✔️Muy buenos

El juego artísticamente es muy bonito a la vez que tenebroso al igual que el diseño de personajes y enemigos



[h1]=== RENDIMIENTO ===[/h1]

[b]*FPS limitados a 144*[/b] 
[u]Rango de FPS[/u]
[b]Mínimo:[/b] 142
[b]Average:[/b] 144
[b]Sin límite:[/b] 2300≈

✔️Impecable

El juego va como la seda, he preferido limitar los FPS a lo máximo que deja el juego porque 2000 me parece algo excesivo.


[h1]=== PRECIO/CALIDAD ===[/h1]
[b]Comprado por:[/b] Regalado

✔️Acorde a lo que ofrece.

Basándonos en el precio oficial me parece un juego que tiene un precio justo.


[h1]=== REQUISITOS ===[/h1]

✔️Pc´s Medio.

El juego no requiere de un PC muy allá para poder jugarlo con una tasa estable y decente.


[h1]=== DIFICULTAD ===[/h1]
[b]Jugado en la dificultad:[/b] No se puede elegir

✔️Dificultad media con algunos momentos y jefes un poco más difíciles

El juego no castiga mucho los errores, a veces la dificultad se suma debido a que hay enemigos que vuelan y el personaje no puede pegar hacia arriba con lo cual te tienes que poner al frente para pegarles y si entras en contacto con el enemigo te hace daño. Hay algunos jefes que cuentan un poco mas pero que una vez mueres un par de veces, pillas el truco y se pasan sin problema.


[h1]=== HORAS DE JUEGO ===[/h1]

✔️ 12+ horas

Completar el juego al 100% me ha llevado unas 20 horas.


[h1]=== HISTORIA ===[/h1]

✔️Nada espectacular pero con alguna cosa interesante

La historia se cuenta a base de textos que generalmente cuentan un poco de la zona y algunas cinemáticas después de los bosses.


[h1]=== DURACIÓN DE LA HISTORIA ===[/h1]

✔️8 – 12 horas

Hay varios finales, dependiendo de a cual llegues puedes tardar un poco mas o un poco menos.



[h1]=== BUGS ===[/h1]

✔️No me he encontrado con ningún bug


[h1]=== JUGABILIDAD ===[/h1]

✔️Excelente

A pesar de que las mecánicas no son algo que innove, la forma en que se implementan me parecen interesantes tanto a nivel de gameplay y visualmente. Lo único que me desagrada es que no se puede atacar hacia arriba.

135111916.review:
This game gives me Ori vibes, slow and continually boring, one thing to note also is how terrible the mapping is, most of the time I dont know where, when and how tf I came to be, and to access some rooms you have to unlock an item or whatever which is further the map before you can come back to enter, now good luck with that unless you have some top notch memory I recommend to take down notes where those places are so you can come back later.
Another thing I hate which is really common in these genres is how you take damage by touching the enemy, not really my cup of tea, not to be able to cancel actions is a down for me, also mobs and bosses are predictable(could be a positive or negative you choose), apart from that the combat are great and nothing to complain about, you could also battle bosses again through memories if iirc. Would also like to raise the difficulty in bosses and maybe mobs, idk if its an option available but I couldnt seem to find it.
For the controls, keyboard are just wacky and needs customization asap unless you are the guy who plays on arrow keys and likes their combo keys on zxc,
controller is plug and play and just perfect in default.

What I like in all games regardless of genres is a good story, initially I would abandon this game if it weren't for the lore which kept building up and it may not look like it with 6hrs in but I am currently deep within taking my time reading every notes and noticing every detail, paired with an art style that I prefer and soundtrack totally worth every spent dime, i'm immersed within its story, you could battle out every single mobs insight or just give zero fucks and advance searching for every tiny white specks to build up the story. 
 
I highly recommend this if you like hk and especially ori, great game and ost is a must if you enjoy classical and opera music, either way its just in between, either you will love this or just hate it, I like it so far so thats that, not like my review really matters
